0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer:
It sounds like you have been through a lot with all the tests and doctor visits. It's great that they have ruled out epilepsy as a cause for your seizures. It's possible that the dizziness and disorientation you are feeling while playing games could be related to eyestrain, as your neurologist mentioned.

Here are a few tips that might help:
1. Take regular breaks while playing games to rest your eyes and prevent eyestrain.
2. Make sure you are sitting in a well-lit room and adjust the brightness of your screen to a comfortable level.
3. Stay hydrated and take care of your overall health, as anxiety and dissociation can also contribute to feelings of dizziness and disorientation.
4. Consider speaking to a therapist or counselor about your anxiety and dissociation issues. They may be able to provide you with coping mechanisms and support.

If the symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to follow up with your neurologist or seek a second opinion from a different doctor. It's always better to be cautious when it comes to your health.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?
1.answer:
Based on your description of the events and the medical tests that have been performed, it is possible that you may have epilepsy. Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures. Seizures can manifest in different ways, including loss of consciousness, confusion, and uncontrolled movements.

The fact that you have experienced two episodes of sudden collapse and confusion in a relatively short period of time, despite having no previous history of seizures or medical conditions, raises the possibility of epilepsy. Additionally, the fact that you have experienced several potential triggers for seizures before and after these episodes further supports the possibility of epilepsy.

The fact that your neurologist has prescribed you Lamotrigine, an antiepileptic medication, also suggests that they suspect epilepsy as the underlying cause of your episodes.

It is important to follow up with your neurologist and continue taking your medication as prescribed. They may recommend further tests or adjustments to your treatment plan to better manage your condition. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to speak with your healthcare provider.

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.
3.answer:
It is true that epilepsy is typically diagnosed after a person has had at least two unprovoked seizures. However, in some cases, a diagnosis of epilepsy may be made after just one seizure if the EEG results show abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is consistent with epilepsy.

An EEG is a test that measures the electrical activity in the brain. In people with epilepsy, the EEG often shows abnormal patterns of electrical activity, such as spikes or sharp waves. These abnormal patterns can help doctors determine if a person has epilepsy or another neurological condition.

It is important to discuss your concerns and questions with your husband's neurologist. It is possible that there may have been other factors or evidence that led the neurologist to diagnose epilepsy after just one seizure and abnormal EEG results. It is also important to get clarification on the specific findings from the EEG and how they relate to the diagnosis of epilepsy.

If you are still unsure about the diagnosis, it may be helpful to seek a second opinion from another neurologist or epilepsy specialist. They can review your husband's test results and provide further insight into the diagnosis.

Overall, it is important to gather as much information as possible and work closely with your husband's healthcare team to ensure he receives the most appropriate care and treatment for his condition.

4.question: ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)
4.answer:
It is possible that the plasma donation center turned you away due to concerns about the potential risk of seizure activity during or after the donation process. While donating plasma itself does not typically pose a significant risk to individuals with epilepsy, there may be concerns about potential stress or changes in blood pressure that could trigger a seizure in some cases.

It is important to discuss your specific situation with your healthcare provider, who can provide more personalized advice based on your medical history and current health status. They may be able to provide more information about whether or not plasma donation is safe for you, and if there are any specific precautions you should take if you choose to donate.

Overall, it is important for individuals with epilepsy to prioritize their health and well-being, and to work closely with their healthcare team to make informed decisions about activities that may have an impact on their condition.

5.question: I (27F) had temporal lobe epilepsy from about age 8 until I was 10, when I had surgery to remove the gliosis (and part of my right hippocampus?) that caused my seizures. Every medical questionnaire and intake form I’ve ever had to fill out asks me if I have a history of a seizure disorder and/or epilepsy, and I always check yes and have to explain to whatever professional I’m seeing that I haven’t had a seizure since I had my surgery.I still want to be honest on these forms obviously, but I’m wondering is it even relevant to my current health anymore?As a note, I had my drivers license briefly suspended once when I was 17 or 18 because the DMV found out I’d used to have seizures and needed me to provide a doctors note clearing things up, so it’s important to me to know when it’s actually relevant to divulge my history.
5.answer: It's always important to be honest on medical forms, as it can impact the care you receive and the treatments that may be recommended for you. In your case, since you had surgery to remove the gliosis and part of your right hippocampus, and have been seizure-free since then, your history of epilepsy may not be relevant to your current health. However, it's still good to disclose this information to new healthcare providers just in case it might impact any potential treatments or medications in the future. If you're ever unsure about whether to disclose your history of epilepsy, it's always best to err on the side of caution and mention it to your healthcare provider.

6.question: 27 years old male Non smoker 73 kg 180 cm No other chronic illnessFor the past decade, I've been dealing with two distinct issues.- The first involves zigzag flashes across my field of vision, which are then followed by a mild headache lasting about an hour.- The second is an abrupt sensation of déjà vu or dream recall that leaves me feeling anxious and uncertain about my own memories.Both of these "auras" typically last around 20 minutes. I haven't sought treatment yet since these episodes occur infrequently—sometimes just once a year or once every few months.I'm unsure if what I'm experiencing is related to epilepsy or migraines?If anyone has had similar experiences, I'd greatly appreciate your insights.
6.answer:
Based on your description, it sounds like you may be experiencing migraine with aura. Migraine with aura is a type of migraine headache that is accompanied by visual disturbances (such as zigzag flashes) and other sensory symptoms (such as déjà vu or dream recall). These episodes typically last for a short period of time, like you have mentioned.

It is important to consult with a healthcare provider to have a proper evaluation and diagnosis. They can help determine whether your symptoms are related to migraines, epilepsy, or another underlying condition. They may recommend further testing, such as a neurological examination or imaging studies, to confirm the diagnosis.

In the meantime, try to keep track of when these episodes occur, any triggers that may be associated with them, and how they impact your daily life. This information can be helpful for your healthcare provider in determining the best course of treatment for you.

Remember, seeking medical advice and treatment is important to manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life. Do not hesitate to reach out to a healthcare provider for further guidance and support.

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.
7.answer:
The second part of his behaviour is less frequent, maybe once a week or less. These are more serious and resemble seizures. He will completely lose control of his body, falling to the ground, shaking and convulsing for around 1-2 minutes. He will be unresponsive during this time and will often come round with no memory of what has happened. These episodes seem to have more of a trigger, such as being overly stressed or overwhelmed.

I am really concerned for his health and well-being, and I think it's important that he sees a doctor or neurologist as soon as possible. These behaviours could be indicative of a neurological condition such as epilepsy, or they could be a result of stress or other underlying issues. It's important to get a proper diagnosis and treatment plan in place to help manage and improve his symptoms.

In the meantime, it's important to support and reassure him, and try to create a safe environment for him to prevent any injuries during his episodes. Encourage him to keep a journal of when these behaviours occur, any triggers or patterns he notices, and any other symptoms he may be experiencing. This information can be really helpful for the doctor in determining the cause of his symptoms.

Overall, it's important to take these behaviours seriously and seek medical help. It's better to be safe than sorry when it comes to his health and well-being.

9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer: There are various factors that can contribute to seizures, including stress, lack of sleep, hormonal changes, or certain triggers such as alcohol or caffeine consumption. It is possible that when you are tired, your brain is more susceptible to these triggers and is more likely to experience a seizure. It is important to speak with a doctor or neurologist to determine the underlying cause of your seizures and to develop a treatment plan.

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.
10.answer:
I am so sorry to hear about the traumatic experience you had during the procedure and the ongoing challenges you have been facing since then. It's understandable that you are feeling overwhelmed and desperate to get your life back on track.

It sounds like you are taking proactive steps in seeking help from a new mental health facility and exploring different treatment options. It's important to advocate for yourself and seek out the support and care that you need.

I recommend discussing your symptoms and concerns with your new mental health provider and neurologist in detail. They may be able to adjust your medications, provide therapy or other interventions to help manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life.

In the meantime, it's important to practice self-care and reach out to your support system for help and comfort. Remember that recovery is a process and it may take time, but with the right support and treatment, you can overcome these challenges.

Please don't hesitate to reach out for help if you feel you need it, whether that means considering an IOP or inpatient hospitalization or exploring other options. You deserve to feel better and find relief from your suffering. Stay strong and keep advocating for yourself.

12.question: 18M 72kg/160lbs 180cm healthy non-smoker and non-drinker. My blood pressure normally around 55/110 and my mother has epilepsy. I hyperventilated for some reason and stood up, passed out and woke up. I had a little dream when I passed out. My friend who was with me said I was swinging my right leg and scraping the carpet with my right hand for about 10 seconds. I remember scratching the carpet unintentionally for about 2 seconds. I'm feeling a little foggy. It happened a few hours ago. Was it an epileptic seizure or something else?
12.answer:
It is possible that what you experienced was an epileptic seizure, especially given your family history of epilepsy. However, it is also important to consider other potential causes of passing out, such as hyperventilation or a vasovagal response.

It would be best to speak with a healthcare professional about your experience to determine the cause and ensure proper treatment if necessary. They may recommend further testing or monitoring to better understand what happened.

In the meantime, make sure to take care of yourself and avoid any potential triggers that may have contributed to the episode. Stay well-rested, hydrated, and try to manage stress levels to minimize the risk of another episode.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.
13.answer:
Due to your history of tonic-clonic seizures and the fact that they have occurred more frequently after taking high doses of Zolpidem, it is highly likely that the seizures are related to the medication. Zolpidem can lower the seizure threshold in some people, increasing the risk of seizures. It is important to discuss this with your neurologist and carefully manage any future medication use to prevent seizures from occurring.

It is also important to address the underlying reasons for taking high doses of Zolpidem, such as stress and sleep disorders. Working with your therapist and psychologist to develop healthier coping mechanisms and improve your sleep patterns can help prevent future episodes of seizures.

Overall, it is crucial to prioritize your health and well-being and work with your healthcare team to ensure proper management of any underlying issues that may be contributing to your seizures.

14.question: I (30F) had a seizure for the first time 3 days ago. I had had a couple beers, smoked a joint, and did some shrooms (none of which is unusual for me). I have no family history of epilepsy, and am in generally good health.I was checked out by paramedics immediately after the seizure who said I looked fine and it was probably from the shrooms. I went to my PCP the next day and she ordered a couple blood tests which all came back normal. I am waiting for brain imaging to be approved by my insurance.Now it’s three days later and I still feel exhausted and weak and slow. I could barely get through my workday today. Is this normal? Is extreme fatigue indicative of something?Also I don’t know if it’s relevant at all but about a month ago I started experiencing extreme nausea to the point I was calling off sick at work, vomiting in the middle of the day, and had just had a doctors appointment to discuss that the week before.
14.answer:
It's possible that the extreme fatigue you are experiencing could be a result of the seizure and the potentially stressful experience of having one for the first time. Seizures can sometimes cause fatigue and weakness as your body recovers from the episode. Additionally, the combination of alcohol, marijuana, and psychedelic mushrooms could have interacted in a way that caused the seizure.

It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider and get the brain imaging done to rule out any underlying issues that could be causing your symptoms. In the meantime, try to get plenty of rest, stay hydrated, and eat healthily to support your body as it recovers. If your symptoms persist or worsen, make sure to seek medical attention again.

15.question: 33f/5’3”/185lbs/no major health issuesWhat I’ve been experiencing: Out of nowhere my eyes get super sensitive to light. I will get an overwhelming sensation of doom/panic. My body basically forgets how to breathe. Heart rate goes up. My brain feels weird, dizzy, and fuzzy. I get hot and nauseous. I just don’t feel ok, something in my head just feels very off and I’m scared. These episodes last for a few seconds to a few minutes. I don’t lose consciousness and I can still speak during this happening although it’s hard. Sometimes after I feel tired and sometimes I feel normal. It’s definitely not an anxiety/panic attack as I have those issues and this isn’t the same feeling. I’ve also been experiencing more headaches lately. Tinnitus. Eyesight is just very weird and sensitive all the time with floaters. My short term memory isn’t great anymore. Reading out loud is getting harder. Weird muscle twitches below my lip/chin area. Shaking my head hard helps stop it when I feel it coming on.Does what I’m experiencing sound like focal seizure/epilepsy? I’m really nervous about this. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.
15.answer: It is possible that what you are experiencing could be related to focal seizures or epilepsy, especially since you have a history of the sensation of shaking in a box. It is important to speak with your healthcare provider about these symptoms to determine if further evaluation or testing is needed. The medications you are taking, specifically trazodone, could potentially be contributing to or exacerbating these symptoms, so it is important to discuss this with your healthcare provider as well. They will be able to provide you with the necessary advice and guidance on how to best manage your symptoms.

16.question: UK female 40 162cm 77kgs no smoking, alcohol or drugsDiagnosis of autism, asthma, Ehlers Danlos type 1 and presumed epilepsyMedication is Levetiracetam 1250mg twice a day and Fostair inhalers and cetirizine over the counterRecently had an EEG for nocturnal episodes of unilateral clonic and tonic movements lasting 20 to 160 seconds witnessed by partner and on video plus brief (30 sec max) daytime episodes of twitching and ‘swooping’ sensation in head - all improved but not stopped by Levetiracetam. MRI and CT scans normal. Neurolgist reported on EEH as ’essentially normal’ with no other details, but has advised GP diagnosis is presumed epilepsy however described it as a difficult case to diagnose. My question is why would he describe the EEG as ‘essentially normal’ rather than just normal?

This could also be used to convey that although the EEG did not show any clear abnormalities that would definitively point to epilepsy, there may still be some uncertainty or ambiguity in the diagnosis due to the complex nature of the presentations and symptoms experienced by the individual. Ultimately, the term "essentially normal" may have been used to highlight that while no major concerns were identified, there may still be some ongoing investigation or monitoring needed to fully understand the underlying cause of the symptoms.

17.question: I want to donate plasma, partially because I have O negative blood and would be available every 4 weeks to donate. And partially because I discovered donating plasma also has health benefits for the donors such as reducing micro-plastics in the body.From what I can see online in the UK if you’re epileptic you can’t donate plasma/blood. I was wondering if anyone knew the reason for this? Is it because the medication I take could cause issues if it was in the blood?Or is it more of a ‘we’re worried you may have a seizure while donating’ kind of risk where a doctors note might mitigate risks?If it’s the latter, it seems a shame that something which could have a positive impact for both parties isn’t allowed so I just wanted some insight into the matter as I can’t see anything online which actually talks about the reasons behind the restriction.Female, 27, Epileptic, medication: Keppra and Eslicarbazepine, other than being epileptic I am healthy in all other respects (BMI: 20, non-smoker, non-drinker)
17.answer:
It is likely that the reason individuals with epilepsy are not allowed to donate plasma or blood is due to the potential risk of having a seizure during the donation process. Seizures can be unpredictable and can pose a danger to both the donor and the staff administering the donation. Additionally, the medications you are taking for your epilepsy may also be a factor in the restriction, as they could potentially impact the quality or safety of the donated plasma.

If you are interested in donating plasma despite being epileptic, it would be best to consult with a healthcare provider or the donation center directly to discuss your specific situation and see if there are any possible accommodations that can be made. They may be able to provide more information on the reasons behind the restriction and any potential alternatives.

18.question: My friend is 19 and pregnant. She’s in her 11th week of pregnancy and started experiencing “seizures” while sleeping and then also while awake. so she admitted to the hospital but the doctors couldn’t figure out what’s wrong. She doesn’t have any history of epilepsy or seizures even in her family. she did experience sepsis about a couple months ago while she was pregnant with her last baby (she had to abort it). This time around apparently just her magnesium levels were low in the blood tests and her oxygen saturation levels were around 93% when she would start getting dizzy and about to experience a “seizure”. I say “seizure” because apparently the docs at the hospital didn’t think they were proper seizures and ive never seen one of hers so idk either but she would experience amnesia after them, be very confused and dazed. She also wouldn’t experience any pain during the seizures but would afterwards when she came out of them. I’m only really looking for advice.
18.answer:
It sounds like your friend is going through a scary and difficult time, and it's important for her to continue to work with her healthcare providers to determine the cause of these episodes. It's good that her magnesium levels were low, as this can sometimes lead to seizures, confusion, and dizziness. Ensuring she is taking any prescribed supplements and following up with her doctors regularly is crucial.

In the meantime, it might be helpful for her to keep a detailed diary of her episodes, including the times they occur, any symptoms she experiences before and after, and any potential triggers or patterns she notices. This information can be valuable for her healthcare providers in identifying potential causes or contributing factors.

Encourage her to prioritize self-care and rest, to stay hydrated, and to follow any other recommendations or treatments her healthcare providers have suggested. It's also important for her to have a strong support system in place, so offering your friendship, understanding, and assistance can be incredibly valuable during this challenging time. If she continues to experience seizures or other concerning symptoms, she should seek medical attention immediately.

19.question: 22F, 110 poundsCurrent Medications- Lamictal 200 mg in the AM & PM so 400mg total a day. Vyvanse 40mg once a day, don't take on the weekends unless I am scheduled to work.I smoke medical marijuana and HARDLY drink, probably 3 times year.Background- So I need to say now that when I was explained all of this I was 16 so it is very dumbed down and I still do not fully understand it lol. But when I was 15 I took 47 coricidin cough and cold pills and was not breathing by the time EMS arrived. I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.So my questions is could my lesion be shrinking and if so would my seizures stop?
19.answer:
It is possible for lesions in the brain to shrink over time, as the brain has the ability to repair and regenerate itself to some extent. However, the presence of a lesion itself does not necessarily guarantee the occurrence of seizures. Seizures can be caused by a variety of factors, including but not limited to brain lesions.

Given your history of substance abuse and subsequent psychosis, it is important to continue taking your medications as prescribed to manage your seizures. Abruptly stopping or missing doses of your medications can increase the risk of seizures. It is essential to follow up with your neurologist regularly to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment plan as needed.

If you have concerns about your current medication regimen or the presence of a shrinking lesion in your brain, it is recommended that you discuss these with your healthcare provider for a better understanding of your specific situation.

20.question: 40 years old, 10 stone (140 pounds)Epilepsy-Asthma-Thyroid-Scoliosis-Bladder conditionMeds: Epilim chrono 500mg, Epilim 200mg, Etanercept, Ventolin, LevothyroxineI take one 200mg Epilim pill in the morning and two 500mg ones in the evening. In the morning I take the 200mg pill with my breakfast fine, but when I take the 500mg tablet after dinner, I swallow the tablet with water like in the morning, I'm coughing up the water and the pill is getting lodged in my throat. This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.
20.answer:
It is important to speak with your healthcare provider about your difficulty in swallowing the 500mg Epilim tablets. They may recommend alternative methods of administration, such as breaking the tablet in half or switching to a different formulation. 

In the meantime, taking 5 of the 200mg tablets to make up the 1000mg dose may be a temporary solution, but it is important to confirm with your healthcare provider before making any changes to your medication regimen. 

It is also important to discuss any concerns or side effects you are experiencing with your pharmacist and healthcare provider. They can provide guidance on how to safely and effectively manage your medication regimen.

21.question: 23F, 5'8, 134 lbs, medications: trokendi xr switching over to topiramate, nonsmoker, epileptic, no location, and no photo.Hello, my medication trokendi xr is currently on backorder, and my neurologist sent a new prescription in for some generic topiramate. The only question I did not get to ask him was if I have to continue only taking 1 a day since trokendi is an extended release or if I have to take 2 a day. Thanks!
21.answer: It's best to follow up with your neurologist or pharmacist for specific instructions on how to transition from Trokendi XR to generic topiramate. They will be able to give you the most accurate guidance on dosage and frequency.

22.question: Before I start of with everything I am diagnosed with BPD, epilepsy, anxiety, aura headaches, pcos, and vertigo. It started with me just getting vertigo in 2019 and it went away with medication but came back within a week and i got chest pains and went to see a cardiologist and everything was okay. I was then sent to a neurologist and they finally diagnosed me with epilepsy but I don't have seizures. for awhile though i was having episodes of "falling into the ground" feelings and if i was in the car it would feel like i was falling back. I would just get odd feelings like that. i was told i basically have micro seizures. there's times where i get dizzy and don't feel good or just don't feel right and im guessing it could just be depersonalization but I'm honestly not sure. l've been now struggling with a migraine for over a month now and i had a mri done that came out normal and im having another one and a mra done tomorrow to see if something looks off. I've been struggling with migraines for awhile but never like this. I'm honestly just hoping maybe someone has had a similar experience or a answer? idk I've been in so much painMedications: metaformin Aimoveg, only one shot so far venlafaxine bupropion Mag oxide ToprimateHeight; 5'7 Weight: 180 I only smoke sometimes , I never drink alcohol
22.answer:
I am sorry to hear about all the health challenges you are facing. It sounds like you have been through a lot, with multiple diagnoses and ongoing symptoms. It can be very frustrating and overwhelming to deal with so much at once.

It's good that you are seeing specialists and getting tests done to try to determine the cause of your symptoms. It's important to work closely with your healthcare providers to find the right treatment plan for you.

In terms of your migraines, it's common for people with epilepsy to also experience headaches. It's possible that your migraines are related to your other health conditions, such as BPD and anxiety. It's also possible that they could be a separate issue altogether.

In the meantime, I would recommend keeping track of your symptoms, triggers, and any patterns you notice, as this can be helpful information for your healthcare providers. Also, make sure to discuss any concerns or questions you have with your healthcare team.

I hope you are able to find some relief soon and that you get the answers and support you need to manage your health conditions. Remember to take care of yourself and seek help if you need it. You are not alone in this journey.

23.question: So i had an epilepsy seizure when i was like 4-5 months old. I took medication daily for 7 years, and i had no more seizures. Im 17 years old now. Can my epilepsy come back? If it can what can cause it?
23.answer: It is possible for epilepsy to come back, even after years of being seizure-free. The risk of recurrence varies depending on the type of epilepsy you have, the underlying cause, and other individual factors. Some common reasons for epilepsy to return include not taking medication as prescribed, changes in hormone levels, sleep deprivation, stress, alcohol or drug use, and other medical conditions that can affect the brain. It's important to continue monitoring your condition with your healthcare provider and follow their recommendations to manage your epilepsy effectively. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your health, make sure to consult with your doctor.

24.question: According to my sister (her mother), my 5 year old niece was eating ice cream the other night at a restaurant when she got real still, said she had a headache, then her whole body fell and she slid under the table. My sister picked her up and my niece was totally stiff and not breathing, then her legs started convulsing. After about 20 seconds she woke up and exclaimed “what was that” and started crying. She was brought to urgent care but was fine by that point, and got an EEG this morning (about 3 days later) and everything appeared normal. My niece later described it as falling asleep without even trying. Apparently my niece has passed out twice before while eating ice cream (never a seizure), and also once when she was much littler when a kid ran into her hard. All the doctor said about this recent episode is it’s “interesting”.What could be causing this? Are there links between ice cream, sugar, or dairy and passing out/seizures? Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.
24.answer:
It's difficult to say exactly what could be causing these episodes without more information and a complete medical evaluation. Passing out or having seizures after eating certain foods, like ice cream, can sometimes be related to specific allergies, sensitivities, or medical conditions. It's possible that your niece could be having a reaction to something in the ice cream, such as a food allergy or sensitivity.

It's also possible that the passing out episodes could be related to a neurological condition or other underlying health issue. It's important for your niece to see a pediatric neurologist or other medical specialist for further evaluation and testing to determine the cause of these episodes.

In the meantime, it may be helpful for your sister to keep a journal of your niece's symptoms, including what she ate before the episodes, any specific triggers, and any other relevant information. This information can help medical providers better understand the pattern of her episodes and determine the best course of action for treatment.

25.question: 27 female, I suffer from autism, epilepsy, depressionLymph node on left side of neck is swollen, hearing loss, ears feel blocked, headache and can’t sleep or eat much. I take lamotrigine and clozapam
25.answer: It sounds like you are dealing with a lot of health issues right now. It's important to address these symptoms with your healthcare provider to determine the best course of action. Swollen lymph nodes, hearing loss, and blocked ears could be related to an infection or other medical condition, so it's important to seek medical advice. Your headache and difficulty sleeping or eating could also be related to your conditions, so it's important to discuss these symptoms with your healthcare provider as well. It's good that you are taking lamotrigine and clonazepam for your epilepsy and depression, but make sure to keep your healthcare provider informed of any new symptoms or changes in your condition. Take care of yourself and make sure to prioritize your health and well-being.

26.question: I was a healthy, fit male in my early 40s when I started having episodes where I would get light headed and sometimes pass out after a work out in the weight room that included pull ups. Fyi, I was and still am(60yrs old now)taking PPIs for Gerd caused by a Hiatal hernia. My physician sent me to a neurologist who said I had Epilepsy and wanted to put me on meds. I explained it only happened after work outs, I refused the meds. I went to the Director on the Southern Epilepsy Foundation, he examined me and confirmed I did not have Epilepsy. He had me go through a barrage of heart tests, thinking I was experiencing Syncope. They reached no conclusive explanation. I have thought it could be something to do with the proximity of the Vagus nerve to the Hiatal hernia and the pressure of lifting weights causing a vertigo/fainting response or the lack of nutrient absorption due to PPI use that created the light headed/fainting episodes? My physician said to stop doing pull ups. I haven’t had an episode in a few years now. I did stop the pull-ups which I miss and backed off the amount of weight I lift. Still on PPIs. Any thoughts? Thank you for any feed back.
26.answer:
It's great that you sought multiple opinions and went through various tests to try and figure out the cause of your episodes. It's always important to listen to your body and take precautions to prevent further episodes.

Given your history of GERD and a hiatal hernia, it's possible that there could be a connection between your symptoms and the pressure or strain placed on the vagus nerve during certain activities like pull-ups. The vagus nerve plays a role in regulating heart rate and blood pressure, so it's possible that the pressure from lifting weights could have triggered a response in your body leading to light-headedness and fainting.

It's also important to consider the potential effects of PPIs on nutrient absorption and overall health. PPIs can reduce the production of stomach acid, which can impact the absorption of certain nutrients like magnesium, calcium, and vitamin B12. This could potentially contribute to symptoms of light-headedness or weakness.

Ultimately, it's important to continue working closely with your healthcare provider to monitor your symptoms and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan. It's also important to continue following their advice to avoid activities that may trigger your symptoms and prioritize your overall health and well-being.

If you ever experience any new or concerning symptoms, be sure to reach out to your healthcare provider for further evaluation and guidance. Thank you for sharing your experience, and I hope you continue to stay healthy and well.

27.question: I wanted to share my experience with you to maybe get some more information about my situation.For 10 years, I have been experiencing every couple of months sudden deja vu like feeling followed by dissociation. I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.
27.answer:
It's great that you are seeking more information about your situation and trying to understand the possible reasons for your episodes of sudden deja vu and dissociation. While anxiety can certainly trigger episodes of dissociation, it's also important to consider other potential underlying causes.

One possibility to explore is the presence of epilepsy or seizure disorders, as some types of seizures can manifest with feelings of deja vu and dissociation. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional, such as a neurologist, who can evaluate your symptoms and conduct relevant tests to rule out any neurological conditions.

Additionally, it may be helpful to consider other factors that could be contributing to your experiences, such as sleep disturbances, medication side effects, or underlying psychological factors. Keeping a journal of your episodes, including any potential triggers or patterns you notice, can also provide valuable information for healthcare providers.

In any case, seeking professional guidance and support is crucial in understanding and managing your symptoms effectively. A healthcare provider can help determine the most appropriate course of action, whether it involves additional testing, therapy, medication adjustments, or other interventions.

Overall, it's commendable that you are taking steps to understand and address your experiences. Remember that you are not alone, and there are resources and professionals available to support you on your journey towards better health and well-being.

28.question: Female and Male, age 26 and 27. Female with epilepsy, male no medical diagnosis. Female on Keppra and Lamotrigine.My husband and I lived in a nice little basement suite for 3 years. Wishing a couple months of moving in, I developed epilepsy (unrelated head injury). Because of this I began taking medications. Not that long after I started to get morning sickness (without being pregnant). Every day for 2 years I woke up nauseous and vomited half of those times. It was believed it was my medication as epilepsy meds are pretty rough sometimes. About 6 months after moving in, my husband began waking up with nausea about 50% of the mornings. He has a high stress job and we believed it to be anxiety. In addition to that, we adopted our old cat about a year after moving in. He has a few medical issues and takes medication morning and night. He would vomit 5/7 mornings a week. The vet believed this to be part of his medical issues. All of that lined up until we moved 2 weeks ago. None of us have been sick since. As in, our last bouts of being sick was the day we woke up in our old place and moved. No nausea, no vomiting, not a dry heave in sight. If it was just one of us, it could be psychosomatic. I’d even be willing to believe that if it was both humans. But why the cat too?If it wasn’t the medication, anxiety and cat’s diagnosis, what was happening in that house???TLDR: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.EDIT: Thank you all so much for the answers. It has made me very relieved that we left and we plan to take action. The house is for sale, which is why we moved, so we are going to inform the current owner, the real estate agent as well as the tenants who lived above us. We are also looking at our other options around ensuring this is properly taken care of so no one else gets hurt. I’ll also follow up when it sells to ensure the new owner didn’t get left with the fall out.Thank you all again!
28.answer: It's possible that there were mold or other environmental toxins in your old basement suite that were causing these symptoms for all three of you. Mold exposure can cause nausea, vomiting, and other health issues. Moving to a new, cleaner environment seems to have alleviated your symptoms. It would be a good idea to have the old basement suite inspected for mold and other toxins so that future occupants are not affected. It's great that you are taking action to inform the current owner and potential future tenants about this issue. It's important to prioritize your health and the health of others who may come into contact with these environmental hazards.

29.question: 22 M, 150 lb, 5'8", white, myoclonus and "brain zaps" for the last two months. No history of seizures or epilepsy.Two months ago, while taking 10 mg fluoxetine daily, I decided to take some recreational substances. I can't undo this and am sober now so please don't give me too hard a time about this. I consumed 8 beers, 5 grams of kratom powder, and 50 mg of THC. The night before this, I had taken essentially the same combination minus the THC. I felt pretty much fine and fell asleep, maybe a little woozy from all the substances. However, I woke up early in the AM twitching. I didn't feel feverish or seriously unwell, so I didn't go to the doctor (I also don't have a GP right now).The twitching has persisted for the last two months. It's only when I'm sitting or lying down. It's gotten somewhat better over this time, but is worse when I'm tired or have coffee. I also experience the "brain zaps" seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome. On a bad day, I'll twitch up to once a minute. Over the last two months, I also have seen a general shift away from twitching and toward "brain zaps."I haven't gone into urgent care or set a new appointment with a GP (which would be in, like, 2024) because I read there's no real treatment for the SSRI discontinuation brain zaps, and the twitching doesn't really get in the way that much. But I sort of notice that whenever I twitch I lose focus, which is concerning.Does this sound like something that will continue to slowly go away, or have I given myself epilepsy? My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?
29.answer:
First of all, I want to commend you for reaching out for help and being honest about your substance use. It's important to understand that seeking medical advice is crucial in these situations, regardless of the circumstances that led to your symptoms.

Based on the information provided, it is possible that the combination of substances you consumed, particularly the fluoxetine and alcohol, may have contributed to the symptoms you are experiencing. Myoclonus and "brain zaps" are often associated with SSRI discontinuation syndrome, which can occur when stopping or reducing the dosage of certain medications, including fluoxetine.

It is also worth mentioning that seizures are not typically characterized by twitching episodes that occur when you are sitting or lying down. However, it is important to rule out any underlying neurological conditions that may be causing your symptoms. Given the persistent nature of your symptoms, I highly recommend seeking medical attention to undergo a thorough evaluation, including a neurological assessment and potentially an EEG to assess brain activity.

It is possible that your symptoms may gradually improve over time, but it is crucial to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the underlying cause and appropriate management plan. Remember, you are not alone in this, and seeking help is a positive step towards addressing your concerns and ensuring your overall health and well-being.

30.question: My little sister, age 12, was diagnosed with epilepsy for the last 1 year. She has been taking necessary medications for its cure and prevention. However, she has been ill for the last few days and we ran a few tests waiting to get reports tomorrow. It's 3am now and she has been acting and moving her body weirdly while sleeping for the last hour, we're suspecting she's having nocturnal epilepsy. Moreover, she has been telling us she feels tremor in her stomach for the past 3 days. It would be really nice if anyone could answer the following questions    What could be the general cause of any epilepsy such as this?    What precautions should we take as a family or her as an individual to ensure a speedy cure or preventions?    What should we do or ensure when she has this during sleeping?    What habits should be changed to reduce risks of serious injuries by epilepsy?
30.answer:
I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information based on common knowledge.

The general cause of epilepsy can vary, but it is often due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can be caused by genetics, brain injury, infections, or other medical conditions.

To ensure a speedy cure or preventions, it is important for your sister to continue taking her prescribed medications as directed by her doctor. It is also important for her to follow a healthy lifestyle, including getting enough sleep, eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and avoiding triggers that may worsen her symptoms.

When your sister is having an episode of epilepsy during sleep, it is important to stay calm and try to keep her safe by moving any nearby objects that she could potentially injure herself on. It may also be helpful to record the duration and symptoms of the episode to share with her doctor.

To reduce the risk of serious injuries from epilepsy, it is important for your sister to avoid activities that could put her at risk, such as swimming alone or standing near open flames. It may also be helpful for her to wear a medical alert bracelet so that others are aware of her condition in case of an emergency.

31.question: I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this? My information: Male, 22 years old, 5'5,
31.answer:
It is possible that the weakness and trembling in your left shoulder and arm could be a result of hemiparesis, which is a condition that involves weakness on one side of the body. This condition can sometimes be a result of brain surgery, especially if the surgery was on the right side of the brain.

It is important to discuss your concerns with your neurologist or a physical therapist who can evaluate your strength and range of motion in your left shoulder and arm. They can provide you with a proper diagnosis and recommend appropriate treatment options. This may include physical therapy to strengthen the muscles in your left shoulder and arm or other interventions to improve your strength and function.

In the meantime, it is important to listen to your body and not push yourself too hard with weightlifting exercises that exacerbate your symptoms. It may be helpful to focus on lower weight and higher repetition exercises that target your left shoulder and arm to gradually build strength and stability.

Overall, it is important to work closely with healthcare professionals to address your concerns and come up with a plan to improve your strength and function in your left shoulder and arm.

32.question: I’m a 22 year old female and I have quite a track sheet of medical issues. I’m posting on here because I’m not sure if they are related and I really don’t know which road to go down.I’ve had ruptured ovarian cysts consistently since I was 12. every time I ovulate. I’ve been on birth control since I was 13 because of that. I have insanely painful periods and I know my hormones are out of wack but I’ve never been diagnosed officially with PCOS or endometriosis but I think I could have either one. not sure.I got diagnosed with epilepsy last February after two grand mal seizures on the same day. coincidentally(?) I had just gotten off birth control to try and heal my body naturally. my seizures seem to align with my menstrual cycle. I’m on Keppra and it’s controlling my tonic clonic seizures but I have breakthrough absence seizures 3x a week. originally my first EEG only showed right temporal lobe seizures but my most recent EEG showed right and left temporal lobe and left frontal lobe seizures.while I was in the epilepsy monitoring unit last week for a 7 day EEG during a pretty intense grand mal seizure my heart rate hit 275 bpm. I’ve always felt little heart flutters but this was intense. I have a Holter monitor now, and I was diagnosed with supraventricular tachycardia. I’m getting an ablation next week. the flutters happen after every seizure but sometimes just on their own without seizure activity.can someone please help me connect the dots, or point me in the direction of someone who can help? I’m really up for any suggestions right now because I want to go back to my normal life. thank you!
32.answer:
First of all, I want to commend you for reaching out for help and seeking answers to your medical issues. It sounds like you have been dealing with a lot and it's important to get to the bottom of what's going on.

Given the complexity of your medical history, it may be helpful to see a specialist who can help you connect the dots between your various conditions. A reproductive endocrinologist or a gynecologist who specializes in fertility issues may be able to provide insight into your ovarian cysts, painful periods, and potential hormonal imbalances.

In terms of your epilepsy, it's concerning that you are still experiencing breakthrough seizures despite being on medication. It may be beneficial to see an epilepsy specialist or neurologist who can further evaluate your seizure activity and adjust your treatment plan accordingly.

Regarding your supraventricular tachycardia, it's good that you are scheduled for an ablation procedure. This should hopefully help address the issue of your rapid heart rate.

It may also be helpful to work with a healthcare provider who can take a holistic approach to your care and look at how all of your conditions may be interconnected. Integrative medicine practitioners or functional medicine doctors may be able to help you address the underlying causes of your health issues and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

Overall, it's important to advocate for yourself and seek out medical professionals who can help you navigate your complex medical history. Don't hesitate to seek second opinions or ask for referrals to specialists who may be able to provide further insight and support. Hang in there, and I hope you find the answers and relief you are seeking.

33.question: After standing from a prolonged period of sitting (especially when looking at a screen) I have 'episodes' which include spasms and staring. These occur multiple times a day, and I have had an ambulatory eeg. This has been happening for the last 4 years approximatelyThese came back to show that I don't have epilepsy, however my brain waves slow down and they suspect that I have mild cerebal hypoxia.My question is how bad is mild cerebal hypoxia because when severe, it can be very serious. Does the fact that it happens so frequently flag a matter of concern for my brain or general health?I have researched a little about this, but there's not much on mild cerebal hypoxis nor the frequency at which they occur in my personal case. I will be seeing a cardiology specialist at some point, but the waiting period could be very long.Information about myself: 19 male and have type 1 diabetes (since February 2016). Also I had a blood test in December, with all normal results. Apart from this, I have no other known medical conditions and am in relatively good shape.
33.answer:
Mild cerebral hypoxia occurs when there is a slight decrease in the amount of oxygen reaching the brain, which can affect brain function and overall health. While severe cerebral hypoxia can be very serious and potentially life-threatening, mild cerebral hypoxia may not cause immediate or severe consequences.

However, the fact that you are experiencing episodes of spasms and staring multiple times a day, along with abnormal brain waves indicating possible mild cerebral hypoxia, may be a cause for concern. It is important to work closely with your healthcare providers to monitor your symptoms and investigate further to determine the cause of these episodes.

Seeing a cardiology specialist is a good step to take, as they may be able to investigate any potential heart-related issues that could be contributing to your symptoms. It is also important to continue ongoing monitoring and follow-up with your healthcare team to address any concerns and ensure appropriate management of your health.

In the meantime, it is important to take regular breaks from sitting, especially when looking at a screen, to prevent potential triggers for your episodes. Make sure to stay hydrated, get regular exercise, and maintain a healthy lifestyle to support overall brain health.

If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your symptoms, be sure to contact your healthcare provider for further guidance and support.

34.question: Currently on no medications, BW is normal other than some minor indication of anemia and malnourishment (low folate, hemotacrit, hemoglobin, vitamin d, sodium) high albumin.Family history of a wide variety of mental health conditions as well as cancer, diabetes, heart disease, and polycistic kidneys.Began approximately 4 years ago. Started having severe headaches with tingling and numbness in the face and limbs as well as weakness. Had motor ticks that were uncontrollable and sometimes painful due to their jerking motion. Had an mri that showed nothing other than white matter. Started having fainting spells that lasted for around 3 months before these dissipated. Visited a cardiologist during these fainting spells and they had determined there was nothing wrong with my heart. Had first convulsions during tonsil surgery which the doctors had said were a result of them trying to bring me off of sedation, they ended up having to re-sedate me for a few hours (no memory of this occurrence). The doctors who had done the surgery advised me to visit a neurologist since this would not have happened without a neurological problem present. Visit the neurologist that had diagnosed my migraines and was referred for an EEG. EEG showed normal brain activity and doctors said there were no findings that indicated anything wrong and there was nothing they could do for me. Motor ticks still present. Started having a strange sensation in head which were sometimes, but not always, accompanied by convulsions with loss of consciousness until current times. One of the most recent occurrences was when pulled over by a cop after dark(i was a passenger) and (i’m assuming) the flashing lights caused me to collapse and convulse (i wouldn’t consider this a reaction to stress since I have been pulled over during the daytime and had no issues). These convulsions most frequently occur when under the influence of substances, though they do occur at times when I am sober. Constant fatigue which may be due to anemia, and sleep 12 hours or more each night. Issues with long-term and short-term memory, as well as weakness in the limbs. Also have had gastrointestinal issues which i’m not sure if they are relevant or not: nausea and stomach pain after eating anything. Have had some issues with UTI’s. All doctors I have visited have told me there is nothing wrong and make me feel as if they just believe i’m looking for free pills(or a hypochrondiac) but I am still having these issues so i’m not sure where to go from here. pls help
34.answer:
I'm sorry to hear that you are struggling with these health issues and feeling dismissed by the healthcare providers you have seen. It can be frustrating when you are experiencing symptoms and not getting the answers or help you need. It sounds like you have been through a lot and have been proactive in seeking help for your symptoms.

Given your symptoms of headaches, tingling and numbness, weakness, motor ticks, fainting spells, convulsions, fatigue, memory issues, and gastrointestinal problems, it may be beneficial to seek a second opinion from a different neurologist or a neurology specialist who may have more experience with complex neurological conditions. It is important to advocate for yourself and continue to pursue a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

In addition, given your family history of various health conditions, it may also be helpful to speak with a genetic counselor to see if there is a genetic component to your symptoms. They may be able to provide insight into potential hereditary conditions that could be contributing to your symptoms.

It may also be helpful to keep a detailed symptom diary to track when your symptoms occur, what triggers them, and any patterns you notice. This information can be valuable in helping healthcare providers better understand your condition.

In the meantime, continue to prioritize self-care, such as eating a balanced diet to address the malnourishment, staying hydrated, and getting regular exercise to help manage stress and fatigue. It is important to prioritize your overall health and well-being.

Remember that you are not alone in this journey, and there are healthcare providers who will take your symptoms seriously and work with you to find a resolution. Don't give up on seeking the help you need.

35.question: Hi all, I don’t know if Im looking in the right place but wanted to get some advice I have these “fits” where for about 10 seconds I can’t control my left side of my body or speak, it usually cause my arm to go up in the air, and my face to scrunch up, I am fully conscious and aware of what is happening during these episodes but I can’t control them, I am able to tell when I am about to have one, they normally happen when I stand up to fast, and jumped unexpectedly, or when I’m very nervous, I have had an EEG and an MRI scan about 4 years ago nothing showed up and no epilepsy was diagnosed either. 35.answer:
