It's always best to err on the side of caution when it comes to your health.

If a game specifically warns about the potential for photosensitive epilepsy due to its intense flashing, it's probably best to avoid playing that particular game. Even if you've been fine with similar games in the past, there's always a risk that this particular game could trigger a seizure.

It might be a good idea to speak with your healthcare provider or neurologist about your concerns regarding playing this game. They can provide you with personalized advice and guidance on whether it's safe for you to play, based on your individual circumstances and medical history.

Overall, it's important to prioritize your health and safety above all else. As much as it may be tempting to try out the game, it's not worth risking a potential seizure. Always listen to your body and follow the guidelines set by your healthcare provider.

69.question: 18, male, white, 5'11, 81kg, drink occasionally, smoke cigarettes daily, occasional recreational drug use (usually cannabis). Officially diagnosed with ASD and have motor tics. I've noticed "blanking out" spells where i stare off and become completely unresponsive followed by arm and neck twitching and jerking. This most often happens when i'm drinking or when my sleep schedule becomes unhealthy. The first instances of this i can think of must've been a couple years ago and it seems to have been transient since then, but i've noticed it a few times in the past couple months. What especially alarms me is that i know my cousin (blood-related) has had a few instances of grande-mal seizures after drinking, specifically on an empty stomach. I remain conscious during these spells and still aware of my surroundings, albeit less so than typically, however i find that i cannot respond to anything that goes on around me. The twitching and jerking does not last very long (i would say 2 seconds or so). Could it be epilepsy? Am i overthinking?
69.answer: It's important to consult with a healthcare professional about your symptoms, as they may be able to provide a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. It's possible that your symptoms could be related to epilepsy, especially given your family history of seizures. It's better to be cautious and get evaluated by a doctor to rule out any underlying medical conditions. In the meantime, try to maintain a healthy sleep schedule and avoid excessive alcohol consumption to see if that helps reduce the frequency of these spells.

70.question: I am 19F, 120 pounds. Diagnosed anxiety and depression hyperhidrosis 4 years ago. On 200 mg of bupropion twice a day for 4 years now. Started 5 mg of buspirone twice a day in April 2023. I take 25-75 mg of hydroxyzine as needed, so not always daily. 2 mg glycopporolate for the hyperhidrosis. I use marijuana from a licensed dispensary recreationally 4x a week and have for the last year.I believe I had my first potential seizure on August 5th. I was laying in bed, and all of sudden felt extremely heavy. My head felt the heaviest, and my body felt like it was being pulled/melting into my bed. I closed my eyes as if about to fall asleep and felt an electric shock wave going through my head, almost heard the noise of electricity. I think it lasted around 30 seconds. I was fully conscious during it, but felt as if I could not move or speak unless I put tremendous effort into it. Afterwards I felt fine, just a little confused and tired, but I went to work like normal and had a fine shift.Several days later, something similar but different happened. I was sitting in a parking lot with my girlfriend and all of a sudden I felt extreme anger out of nowhere, like I wanted to yell at her which I have never felt before and it was completely unprompted. I was quiet and staring out the window and she asked me if I was ok I just said yes. She then tells me I was just staring at my leg for several minutes. I remember just staring at my leg thinking it looked weird, but I was fully conscious. She was asking me questions and I could respond but it took me much longer and much more effort and I couldn’t say what I wanted to say, more like just a few word answers. It ended pretty abruptly and then I was fine, but again just a little bit confused and tired. My girlfriend has non epileptic seizures (diagnosed) and she thinks I’m having seizures based on what she’s seen and observed and what I’ve told her, but I’m not so sure.  A couple days after that, it happened again. Me and my girlfriend were eating lunch in a restaurant and I started to feel “weird”. I got up went to the bathroom and threw up, and just really felt like I needed to lay down so I asked her to pack our food up and that I’m going to lay in the backseat. Afterwards, she told me I was speaking very slowly when I asked her to pack the food up. I was laying in the backseat and began to have repeated images from my childhood play like movies in my brain. I kept seeing the Lincoln logs I used to play with as a kid, specifically at my grandparents cabin. I saw the fold out table I would sit at and play with them. I just kept seeing them being built up over and over again, and had some other disorganized thoughts. I was conscious and could still speak, I asked my girlfriend if she knew what Lincoln logs were but that was all I said for several minutes. This one lasted the longest, but it’s hard to separate the potential actual seizure versus the before and after tiredness/confusion.There were a few other similar episodes, typically after I eat something fatty/sugary, or am really tired, but those are the only patterns I can detect. I worry that I’m making this up for attention, that it’s just me zoning out really heavily and I just want it to be seizures for attention.Each one is a little bit different, but I get a similar enough feeling beforehand that’s usually nausea, anxiety and/or anger, rising feeling in my chest, really tired/spaced out, pre odd and disorganized thoughts, like just very random thoughts in the parking lot I just started thinking about mannequin army running out of the building and dancing I kept thinking about dancing mannequins. I also get droopy eyelids, my eyes feel heavy and when I start to feel this way I take selfies and you can see my eyelids drooping and look different from normal.I do often get headaches, mild migraines/silent migraines very often, multiple times a week. Is it a possibility this is just migraine aura, or should I see a doctor to be evaluated for focal seizures? Is it possible to fake this or make it up? Is there any other questions you need me to answer to give advice, or things I should pay attention to?I also have occasional dizziness, sometimes pretty intense that I might lose my balance a little and need to grab onto things, or sit down, but I don’t pass out. I used to be a runner, this time last year I could run 6 miles now I can barely do 1. I’ve also lost close to 20 pounds in the last year as well.Edit: forgot to mention, had a CBC panel in mid august and showed no abnormalities other than a mild vitamin D
70.answer:
deficiency. 

Based on the symptoms you described, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional to rule out any potential medical issues. Focal seizures can manifest in various ways, including the symptoms of confusion, disorganized thoughts, and repetitive behaviors that you mentioned. It is not possible to fake or make up medical symptoms, but it is important to be honest and open with your healthcare provider about your experiences.

Given your history of anxiety, depression, hyperhidrosis, and medication use, it is essential to consider the potential interactions between your medications and any new symptoms you may be experiencing. Additionally, the association between your symptoms and triggers such as fatigue, certain foods, or stress should be carefully evaluated.

Keeping a detailed diary of your symptoms, triggers, and any potential warning signs before an episode may help you and your healthcare provider better understand the situation. This can also assist in determining whether these episodes are related to migraine aura or focal seizures.

It is recommended that you schedule an appointment with a neurologist or epileptologist for a thorough evaluation and further testing, such as an EEG (electroencephalogram) to monitor and assess brain activity. It's essential to prioritize your health and seek medical attention to receive an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

71.question: I was recently diagnosed with EA2 after an unexpected hospital stay. Of course I have been researching the condition, and came across 4-AP. I currently take Diamox(500 mg BID) and prednisone(5 mg), which help, but if I begin to have an episode I have to take more and more until it finally stops. My current neurologist won’t really discuss the medication with me, which I was rather surprised by. He has really been pushing for me to come off of the prednisone, even though it is the only thing that really helps me. He wants me to go to a movement clinic first, but the only local one doesn’t take my insurance. Even if I get a PA from my insurance, there is no telling how long it will take before I can get an appointment after. I was really hoping I could get on the 4-AP and come off of the prednisone.
71.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your recent diagnosis and struggles with your current treatment plan. It's frustrating when your healthcare provider isn't open to discussing potential treatment options with you. It might be helpful to seek a second opinion from another neurologist who may be more willing to discuss the use of 4-AP or other medication options for your condition.

In the meantime, you can continue to do your own research on 4-AP and other potential treatments for EA2. It's important to be informed about your condition and the various treatment options available to you. You may also want to consider reaching out to patient advocacy groups or online forums for support and information from others who have experience with EA2.

I understand the challenges of navigating insurance and finding affordable care options. It might be worth exploring if there are any clinical trials or research studies for EA2 treatment that you could potentially participate in. These studies often provide access to cutting-edge treatments and may be covered by the study sponsor.

Overall, it's important to advocate for yourself and your healthcare needs. Don't be afraid to ask questions, seek second opinions, and explore all available options for managing your condition. Best of luck on your journey to finding the right treatment plan for you.

72.question: Few nights ago I woke up around 4 am, it happens often to me. What was weird was my consciousness. I was trying to go back to sleep but I had an instinct reaction like when you are drowing that I have to not go back to sleep.As I was getting more awake something felt odd. It was impossible to have a complex thought, thinking was liking trying to hold water with one hand. I was feeling like my ability to think was malfunctioning, like glitching. I was like anable to wake myself more than a kind of pure reaction state.I got up, walked to the living room, trying to wake myself up, nothing. It is hard to describe, it was like my thoughts were erasing as proceeded. Like I was writing on burning paper.I tried to go back to bed thinking going back to sleep would help. I hold my wife to help me calming as I was trying to fall asleep again.The instinct kicks harder, it was like if I was keep going sleeping I would lose that ability to think, my thoughts were getting simplier and simplier, then I noticed that the voice most people hear as they think was completly silent.. a deafning silent.I feel really weird I try to relax, to clear my thinking, I go again in the living room to keep my eyes open, it feels likes my thoughts are not recognized as mine anymore, I do not control my thinking, I lost the ability to, things get chaotic, confused. I try to remind myself memories to keep a thread to reality, it helps. I succeed to get more complex thoughts, I realise that emotions are back as I didn't noticed I kinda lost it for a moment, was it the panic, the fight or flee mode ? I feel flooded by these emotions, I cry.Then it took like 15 minutes to come back to normal, I am in a very confused state and go back to sleep.Any idea what was that ?
72.answer:
It sounds like you may have experienced a type of sleep paralysis or hypnagogic state. During this state, your body is partially awake while your mind is still in a dream-like state. This can lead to difficulty thinking clearly and feeling disconnected from reality. It can also cause feelings of panic or fear.

It's important to note that sleep paralysis and hypnagogic states are relatively common and typically not harmful. However, if you continue to experience these episodes frequently or if they significantly impact your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a healthcare professional to rule out any underlying medical conditions or sleep disorders. In the meantime, practicing good sleep hygiene and relaxation techniques may help prevent these episodes from occurring.

73.question: (20F) 5’3” 134lbs Drink/Smoke occasionally, every other day Zyrtec, south asianThis has been a daily issue for ~ a decade. I sleep and wake up about the same times. I pee 2-4 times in the night even if I don’t drink after 9:30pm.Sometimes I can feel myself “shutting down”, or falling asleep and my body starting to paralyze. I hear crazy noises (exploding head syndrome). Mostly 1-3 times i am in a dream and cannot move my body at all. Feels like a magnet is preventing me from moving my head left to right. I’m crying and screaming to lift a finger.It is so exhausting. I wake up fatigued and usually anxious. My brain fools me into thinking I’m free the first time, but then I’m paralyzed again. This is normal dreams + nightmares.I have major depression and anxiety. I heard that epilepsy can make you feel paralyzed in your sleep, and have trouble with memory. I have short-term memory loss past few years. I never have bruises or anything though. Please help!
73.answer:
It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of sleep paralysis, a phenomenon where a person is conscious but unable to move or speak while falling asleep or waking up. It is not a harmful condition, but it can be frightening and disruptive to sleep.

Epilepsy can also cause episodes of paralysis, but it is usually associated with seizures rather than during sleep. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the cause of your symptoms and explore potential treatment options.

It is also worth mentioning your history of depression and anxiety, as these conditions can contribute to sleep disturbances. Managing your mental health through therapy, medication, and lifestyle changes may help improve your overall sleep quality.

In the meantime, practicing good sleep hygiene, such as maintaining a consistent sleep schedule, creating a comfortable sleep environment, and avoiding stimulants close to bedtime, may help reduce the frequency of your symptoms. If you continue to experience sleep paralysis and it significantly impacts your daily life, consider seeking the advice of a sleep specialist for further evaluation and management.

74.question: Hey everyone,So my epilepsy meds were changed a few months ago mainly due to my LFT showing very high levels but also because the drug (Tegretol) was no longer working to its potential. So as of now I'm on Keppra and Topamax which means all my AED drugs filter through the Kidneys. Originally I was told I wouldn't need blood tests but at my latest appointment, I was told they definitely will do them. I tried to ask the Specist and NP this in the appointment and they wouldn't really tell me whether there not sure at the moment I don't know. Originally I was getting LFT, CBC or (FBC) and therapeutic drug levels test.My question is with blood testing now likely to continue is it likely they will continue with the LFT and just add on a renal panel? How would this likely play out?
74.answer:
It is possible that they may continue to do LFT (Liver Function Tests) along with adding on a renal panel to monitor the health of your kidneys since your medications now filter through them. It's important for your medical team to monitor both your liver and kidneys to ensure that the medications are being processed properly and not causing any harm to these organs. 

It's best to have a discussion with your healthcare provider about the specific tests they plan on doing and how often they will need to be done. They will be able to provide you with more information on what to expect in terms of blood testing and how it will play out in your treatment plan. 

It's always important to stay proactive in your care and to communicate any concerns or questions you may have with your medical team. Good luck with your new medication regimen!

75.question: 25 FtMbBipolar 1, TL epilepsy, OCD, ASD 200mg sertraline 200mg topamax 2x 30mg abilify 3mg risperidone 100mcg clonidine2 pumps testogel 40mg somac 1000iu vitamin d 148cm 90kg I have partial seizures (confirmed) and I think myoclonic seizures (not confirmed but this is what I think they are) My left eye has been sticking closed a few times a day for about 10 seconds each time (maybe less time but that’s a general time) I’m just concerned this is a a new epilepsy symptom. Should I see my neurologist or GP about this It’s been happening for about 2 months now, I think I have Blepharospasm in my left eye, could this be related to my epilepsy?
75.answer: It is definitely a good idea to see your neurologist about this new symptom of your left eye sticking closed. It could potentially be related to your epilepsy or it could be a separate issue like Blepharospasm. A neurologist would be able to assess the situation and provide you with the appropriate guidance and treatment. In the meantime, it may also be helpful to keep a journal of when these episodes occur and any other symptoms you may be experiencing to provide additional information to your healthcare provider.

76.question: Hi,My six month old son had his first infantile spasm yesterday. Took him to the ER (Canada), they performed an ultrasound which came back clean and booked an EEG for two weeks Tuesday.We are likely going to go over to the states Monday or Tuesday and pay out of pocket to get a quicker EEG as we are terrified of West syndrome and the sooner you can start treatment, the better.Tuberous sclerosis often occurs in tandem with West syndrome and although he doesn't show any signs of it now, it's often not possible to diagnose until later in life.It looks like a genetic mutation is responsible for TS so I'm wondering if this would be called out in a 23andme report? Obviously in theory it could be, just wondering if someone knows for sure.
76.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your son's health concerns. I recommend discussing your options with a healthcare provider or genetic counselor who can provide more accurate information about genetic testing and whether a 23andme report would be helpful in this situation. They can also provide you with guidance on the best course of action for your son's care and treatment. You may also want to inquire about genetic testing specifically for tuberous sclerosis if there is a concern about this condition. It's important to seek out expert medical advice for your son's condition.

77.question: When I woke up yesterday my back was so extremely tight it was hard to move. My head felt really weird, like waves were washing over it from my forehead towards the middle of my head. After that my arms and legs felt tingly the way Restless Leg Syndrome is described. My heart felt super weird (normal EKG last time I went to the ER for this) and I stopped breathing a few times, it was like I had to remember and force myself to breathe again. I got very tired at one point and think I passed out. Woke up what seemed like a few moments later a little confused.This happens every time my cycle comes on but I can usually prevent it by taking ibuprofen before or as soon as cramps start. This time I didn't have any cramps to warn me but I did not have the usual near-constant vomiting so, was able to eat and take ibuprofen. The symptoms subsided about 90% with the tingling still faintly present.I've been to the ER for this, the first time the doctor eventually gave me Ativan which helped like immediately, the second time I had to damn near beg for it. My esophagus tore and I started to vomit blood because nothing else would stop it.Could this be Catamenial Epilepsy? I have no history of Epilepsy in my family.Edit: In past episodes, I have been told I would have bouts of groaning or mumbling but I do not remember 90% of that.
77.answer: It is possible that your symptoms could be related to Catamenial Epilepsy, which is a form of epilepsy that is linked to the menstrual cycle. It is characterized by seizures that are more likely to occur during certain times of the menstrual cycle. It is important to see a doctor for a proper evaluation and diagnosis. In the meantime, continue to take ibuprofen as needed and monitor your symptoms closely. If you experience any worsening of symptoms or new symptoms, seek medical attention immediately.

78.question: F25, 5’6” 108 lbs.conditions: epilepsy, migraines, endometriosismeds: junel fe 1/20 birth control, pristiq, aptiom (started two weeks ago), and aimovig injection monthly.Yesterday I started feeling pain in my neck and base of the skull on the right side. I could feel a very tender lump right where the occipital lymph node is (thanks google!) I did palpate it a lot, and it is extremely painful today. I was also up all night with an awful migraine (first one in months since I started Aimovig) and it spread to my entire head and it was 8/10 pain. I do not have a fever. My headache is better when upright and has gotten a bit better throughout the day but the very painful bulge is still there. It also hurts at rest in that area. I felt lethargic and drained this morning.Took a covid test. Negative. Worried I have an infection or something but no fever? I have a big, painful and possible infected spit of cystic acne on my right cheek. Not sure if related.I’ve also been having bad muscular pain on the right side of my shoulder after packing and lifting boxes, it kept me up thursday night. But it got better-ish. Not sure if it’s related. Kinda feels worse today.Should I be concerned? It hurts to turn my head/move my head at alland I know that if I lie down my headache would return. If i even brush the lymph node it hurts so much. Was hard to brush my hair.Any insight appreciated. Thanks!TLDR: swollen potential lymph node in the occipital area at the base of skull. very painful. have a headache. concerned about infection but no fever.
78.answer:
It is always best to err on the side of caution and seek medical attention if you are experiencing severe pain and swelling. Given your medical history and the fact that you have started a new medication recently, it is possible that this could be a side effect or a reaction to the medication. However, it could also be a sign of an infection or another underlying issue.

I recommend contacting your healthcare provider or going to urgent care to have this evaluated, especially since the pain is severe and affecting your ability to move and function normally. They can help determine the cause of the swelling and pain, and provide appropriate treatment. It is also worth mentioning your recent acne flare-up, as it could be related to the current issue.

In the meantime, you can try applying a warm compress to the affected area to help reduce pain and inflammation. Avoid touching or palpating the swollen area further to prevent exacerbating the pain. Stay hydrated, rest, and monitor your symptoms closely.

79.question: Hi everyone. Just wanting some opinions on this very confusing presentation. My sis in law, 30F, 5'5, smoker, with a suspected eating disorder (binge-purge-restrict cycle) has recently been diagnosed with epilepsy after having 2 seizures within an hour of eachother. She is also on treatment for depression and takes a sleeping tablet daily.The epilepsy diagnosis was confirmed after they ran a few tests. This was a surprise as there's no family history of epilepsy. The neurologist suggested it may be due to the depression meds (an uncommon side effect).Anyway, it has been 3 months since this diagnosis came. Last night, she had a seizure and was groggy and a bit confused for about 2 hours following it. The family understood this to be normal so just followed protocol.Thereafter, she started speaking in 3rd person and with completely different voice. She was not fooling aroud and quite honestly, freaked the hell out of everyone. She kept making degrading comments about herself and said, "Kim is always complaining. Leave her at the back. Leave her at the back". She switched to a different accent and displayed child-like behavior for a few minutes (giggling and kept hugging her pillow).She then spoke normally and complained of feeling dizzy. She had another seizure shortly after. She was taken to hospital where she had another seizure on arrival. At this point, she was completely incoherent and demanded paper and pen. She wrote random words on a page.Currently doing CT scan and blood tests. Will only be seen by a neurologist tomorrow. Any ideas of what could be happening?I initially thought of the possibility of drug use but she has been staying with her parents for 3 months straight and hasn't left the house or received any visitors at all in this period
79.answer:
This sounds like a very concerning situation. It is possible that the seizures and the strange behavior could be related to her epilepsy diagnosis, especially if she is not responding well to medication or if there are underlying issues that have not been addressed. It is also possible that there could be other medical issues at play, given her history of depression and possible eating disorder.

It is important for the doctors to conduct thorough testing to determine the cause of her symptoms and to provide appropriate treatment. It is possible that she may need to be admitted to a hospital for further observation and care.

In the meantime, it is important for her family to provide her with support and to ensure that she is receiving the medical attention she needs. It is also important for her family to communicate openly with her doctors and to advocate for her care.

It is also worth mentioning that sudden changes in behavior or strange symptoms should always be taken seriously and addressed promptly. It is important to seek medical attention if someone is experiencing seizures or other concerning symptoms.

80.question: 25y/o male, 5ft9, 70kg Since a couple of weeks my partner has been completely intolerant to stimuli (24/7). He can’t tolerate the slightest bit of light (not even his phone or laptop), he can’t tolerate any physical activity such as standing up or walking around, when eating his situation deteriorates as well. And what I mean with situation is the fact that he has a constant headache (stabbing, like knives in the back of the head), is nauseous, vomits, has distorted balance, confusion and this all is at it’s worsed when standing up (it could very rarely be tolerable while lying down but the second he stands up it is intolerable). He also had anisocoria at two seperate moments. He can’t function anymore because of all the combined symptoms. We visited multiple doctors with no diagnosis. He does not take any medication anymore (besides his nitroglycerine dermal patches 5mg/day), he forcebly stopped the rest of his medication because it also profoundly worsened his condition.Sincerest gratitude to any helpVisited multiple internal medicine doctors (gastro-enterology and hepatology), 3 neurologists (who all did not suspect meningitis, thats why we didn’t go to the ER, also I have a little medical background and if I would have suspected it to be meningitis I also wouldn’t have doubted and rushes him to the ER), a lot of general practitioners. They performerd US of the liver, CT of the liver, MRCP of the liver, multiple blood analyses (in blood analyses a couple weeks ago he had ALT and AST were 5x the reference value but since then came back to normal, low ceruloplasmine, low carnitine but supplements were given), EEG (no abnormalities), MRI brains (no abnormalities). On de CT they saw narrow bileducts, but not significant. Still waiting on results of MRCP liver. One neurologist prescribes blood and urinalysis for wilsons disease and porphyria but due to his condition we haven’t been able to go to the lab yet to get them done.
80.answer:
It sounds like your partner is experiencing a very concerning and complex set of symptoms. Given the variety of specialists he has seen and the tests that have been conducted, it's good that various potential causes have been ruled out. However, it seems like there are still some unanswered questions and further investigation is needed.

Given the symptoms you have described, it may be worth considering conditions that affect the nervous system, such as autonomic dysfunction or a rare neurological disorder. Additionally, considering the liver abnormalities that have been identified, further investigation into liver function and potential liver-related conditions may be necessary.

It is important for your partner to continue working closely with medical professionals to try to identify the underlying cause of his symptoms. Keep advocating for his health and pushing for answers until a diagnosis can be reached. don't hesitate to seek a second opinion or ask for referrals to specialists at larger hospitals or medical centers that may have more experience with rare or complex cases. 
And, it may be helpful to keep a detailed journal of symptoms, triggers, and any changes in medication or treatment to provide more information for healthcare providers. 

I truly hope that your partner can find relief and answers soon. Stay strong and continue to seek help until a diagnosis is reached.

81.question: I 18M have frontal lobe epilepsy and started smoking weed before I was diagnosed but now it's getting a bit boring and im often offered molly and coke and was wondering if it was safe for me to take since I'm fine with weed and booze
81.answer:
It is important to remember that everyone's body reacts differently to substances and each individual's medical condition can affect how they respond to drugs. While marijuana and alcohol may not have caused any issues for you, taking MDMA (molly) and cocaine can pose serious risks, especially for someone with epilepsy.

Both MDMA and cocaine can trigger seizures in individuals with epilepsy, making them especially dangerous for those already dealing with a neurological condition like yours. Additionally, both drugs can have negative effects on the brain, which could potentially worsen your epilepsy.

It is always best to consult with your healthcare provider before trying any new substances, especially if you have a medical condition. They can provide personalized recommendations and guidance to ensure your safety and well-being. Remember, your health should always be the top priority.

82.question: My fiance' of 3 years is currently experiencing SRSE it is currently day 10 and I am losing all hope. I have come here for help, answers, possible experimental ideas any other stories/survivor stories or anything. Please.Age: Turned 24, Sex: Female, Height: 5'4", Weight: 108, Race: WhiteDuration: First Seizure episode Friday June 30th ~8:30pm Medical issues: none (only medication use is Prozac switched about a month ago from Busiprone I believe); not sure if this is relevant but I learned about the babinski during class back in March and tried it on her before explaining what it even was and tried it again with hand clench to take her mind off the reflex test. She showed positive babinski on both feet but asymptomatic? i told my professor and he said there must be something going on and to see a neurologist. this was never followed up on as she was completely healthy. mother's history fairly severe rheumatoid arthritis - no other known issues. Father: unknown medical history. Drug use: Marijuana (daily), Alcohol (very frequent, 4-5 weekly); urinalysis and other tests proved negative for any other drug I may have been unaware of.  Backstory: Went camping for her birthday on June 24th (Saturday). Received several insect bites during camping trip. By Monday or Tuesday (June 26th/27th) she was starting to feel slightly ill - some nausea and vomiting, elevated temperature. She did complain of soreness, muscle soreness, very odd pain she explained. Some headache issues as well. This lasted until Thursday - by Thursday she was starting to feel pretty much back to normal and she had decided not to see a doctor as it had seemed to pass. Friday morning she was nauseous and vomited and was unable to eat. She napped and woke up around 8:30pm and while taking a drink of water she experienced a convulsive seizure around 3-4 minutes long (no history of seizures, ever). No altered mental state before as we were speaking less than 20 seconds before the seizure starrted. 911 was called and she was transported to hospital. Initially it was thought it could be due to dehydration as she was unable to eat very little during the week and much lower liquid intake. Blood tests/CT all negative and dehydration was not very severe according to the doctor. She was given phenergan and a sodium chloride IV and discharged 4 hours after going into the hospital, told to follow up with primary care Monday and "hope to not have another one." She never regained base line mental functioning before falling asleep (no real meaningful sentences/never aware she was at hospital), but this was assured to me to be postictal. She could not walk to the car to be discharged. She made it through the night with no issues but I was awoken around 9am by a short 15 second seizure. Followed by several more over the next hour in which she never fully regained true consciousness (she only said "headache"). 911 was called after being advised the first two short ones shouldn't be an issue she was postictal - i decided to drive her to the hospital but she went into a sustained convulsive seizure and 911 was called again - the last seizure lasted ~30-45 minutes before being controlled at the hospital. She has been intubated and sedated since then.Current situation: Day 10 of pretty much uncontrolled seizure activity despite all interventions.  Diagnosis: SRSE. meningitis and encephalitis - cause - unknown. Three lumbar punctures (one before antiviral/antibiotics) all negative. Currently waiting for autoimmune disorder labs. Too unstable for MRI and doctor said it was unimportant until stopping seizures. Last MRI looked fine (taken last sunday or monday)Treatment: Propofol since day one as high as she can tolerate. Midozolam drip, three seizure medications (keppra and I can't remember the two). No response, seizure activity mostly continued by EEG recording. Ativan stops them for a short time ( no longer being used). By day 4 they introduced phenobarbital which stopped seizures for 12 hours before returning. most seizures resolve in less than 2 minutes without any BOLUS of propofol or other medicines but some last >10 minutes which must be hit with medicine. After phenobarbital failed they tried ketamine and depakote. It worked for about 12 hours and failed again. Phenobarbitol worked for a few hours and failed again. Her organs are functioning fairly fine, liver slightly down, kidney's producing a lot of urine output due to lasix. She is incredibly swollen at this point but slightly reduced due to lasix - still has some fluid around lungs. Blood pressure and heart rate are fine but oxygen has slowly been dropping. Today she got into the mid 80s, they increased her oxygen input to 100% and she has been holding around 95% blood oxygentation. Steroids have now been administered. In the morning they plan to put her into a barbiturate coma and hope that this stops the seizures but the neurologist has been incredibly hesitant to go this route due to complications. I believe the medication is pentobarbital. They are exhausting everything they know to do. I have searched the literature I have access to and just have no answers and I know the doctors are doing what they can but I am just reaching out for anyone that may know more. Have any of you experienced this before? Any other ideas as to what could be going on? With seizures this prolonged (as many as 70 in a day) will she retain any mental functioning whatsoever if she was to wake up? Can she actually recover from this in anyway at all? Please..just any knowledge or hope or even the hard truth. The only other hopeful thing I have found is the study with use of allopregnanolone (poor power though n=2; both recovered normal mental functioning >7 days SRSE with 3-4 days of pentobarbital coma while allopregnanolone was administered during weaning of pento) Please help. It's killing us all with her…
82.answer:
I am so sorry to hear about your fiance's condition. Status epilepticus is a very serious and life-threatening condition, and it sounds like the medical team is doing everything they can to try to control her seizures. It is not uncommon for patients with SRSE to be put into a medically induced coma in order to try to break the cycle of seizures.

It is difficult to say what the long-term outcome will be for your fiance, as every case is unique. It is possible for patients to recover and regain normal mental functioning after a prolonged period of seizures, but it can be a slow and difficult process. It is important to continue to support her and to stay in close contact with her medical team for updates on her condition.

I would recommend asking her doctors about any experimental treatments or clinical trials that may be available for her condition. It is also important to make sure she is receiving the best possible care and to advocate for her needs.

I wish you and your fiance all the best during this difficult time. Do not hesitate to reach out for support and information as you navigate this challenging situation.

83.question: Ok, first things first this is kind of an update of my old post that I originally had on here. I should also clarify I've actually had this for a long time and never really worried about it mainly due to my seizures always being controlled however this hasn't been the case the last few years hence why I'm now looking more into it. Apologies as a lot of the information is either old or irrelevant. This is basically a very shortened version of how the Nuroligest diagnosed it So from what I know is this: The official diagnosis is Temprole lobe epilepsy with seizures mainly being focal impaired awareness seizures and very rarely tonic-clonic seizures Abnormalities involving the right hippocampus. Regional (cerebral) atrophy of the right dorsal thalamus Right-sided Mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS) MRI. quite clearly shows abnormalities involving the right hippocampus with right-sided mesial temporal sclerosis and some associated regional atrophy of the dorsal right thalamus. There was noted also a T-weighted high signal gliosis within the periventricular white matter of the right parietal lobe with associated ex-vacuo dilatation of the ventricular trigone  Possible cause: seizure-related brain injury or possibly the sequelae of previous ischemic inflammatory insult. So I'm not really questioning the diagnosis I'm just trying to get some more understanding of some of these terms: ex-vacuo dilatation of the ventricular trigone. T-weighted high-signal gliosis, abnormalities ( Now I know this is a very obvious term but what could it mean in relation to the right hippocampus), associated regional atrophy, periventricular white matter (I'm trying to find out whether this is a part of the damage or just a part of the brain in general), Thanks, everyone.
83.answer:
Ex-vacuo dilatation of the ventricular trigone refers to an enlargement of the brain ventricle due to loss of brain tissue, typically as a result of injury or disease. 

T-weighted high-signal gliosis refers to an abnormal increase in the number of glial cells in the brain, often seen as a response to injury or inflammation.

Abnormalities involving the right hippocampus could indicate structural or functional issues with that particular part of the brain, which is involved in memory and learning.

Associated regional atrophy refers to a loss of brain tissue in a specific area, in this case, the dorsal right thalamus.

Periventricular white matter is a region of the brain located around the ventricles that contains nerve fibers. Damage to this area could be indicative of underlying issues related to the epilepsy. 

These terms all point towards potential sources of the epileptic seizures and may provide insight into the underlying causes of your condition. It's important to discuss these findings with your neurologist to better understand how they may be affecting your epilepsy and potential treatment options.

84.question: A few weeks ago I woke up with a lazy eye. On Sunday only I could notice it, and by Tuesday it was severely deviated. I am right eye dominant, but I have figured out how to switch between eyes and make my left eye dominant. However, then my right eye will wander. Somehow my glasses bring my eyes back to center.I went to my optometrist and she suggested myasthenia gravis. I spoke with my neurologist and he went ahead and put me on mestinon pending antibody results. My bloodwork came back in two weeks, and my antibodies were negative and my doctor took me off of mestinon and told me he doesn’t want to do any further testing. in that time frame I had developed other symptoms. I also have times where my breathing will become very shallow and I will take a deep breath and rinse-repeat all night.Before my other symptoms began I had had a seizure at work and five more in the ER, but my neuro says the two are unrelated. I have a very noticeable tremor in my hands and sometimes in my body. My palms will turn bright red and then the rest of my body will flush and turn bright red, including the soles of my feet. The other day part of my left foot turned a grayish-purple color.I have developed severe vertigo with nystagmus. I will throw up from it so violently that I will wet myself. Some days I cannot even move my eyes without vomiting. I was diagnosed with anterior vertigo, and then my PT came back and said he thinks it is actually oscillopsia. I have complex migraines and tried to take a triptan for it. Sometimes it will help, but other times it will not. I also have epilepsy and Hashimotos/hypothyroid, but I have had no recent medication changes. I have had an MRI of my vestibular system and was told it was normal. I have been referred to a neuro ophthalmologist.Medications: Synthroid, trileptal, lamictal, protonix, oxybutinin, abilify, and Seroquel. No recent medication changes. I have had both rounds of the Pfizer Covid vaccine.Edited to add: I also have times where the muscles in my eyes will let go and I will be unable to open them, or I will just look really stoned.
84.answer: It sounds like you are dealing with a complex and concerning array of symptoms. It's important to continue advocating for yourself and seeking answers from your healthcare providers. A neuro-ophthalmologist may be able to provide further insight into the cause of your eye symptoms. Additionally, it may be helpful to seek a second opinion from another neurologist or specialist to explore other potential diagnoses or treatment options. Keep track of your symptoms and any changes you notice, and communicate these clearly with your healthcare team. Stay proactive in your healthcare journey and don't hesitate to ask for further testing or referrals if needed. Wishing you the best in finding a resolution to your health concerns.

85.question: My wife has very recently, after several extremely trying years, been diagnosed with psychogenic non-epileptic seizures. Some backstory is required before I can pose my question:Originally my wife presented with hallucinations (visual, auditory, and tactile). We naturally sought psychiatric treatment. A slew of medicine was prescribed on the assumption of schizophrenia. I can remember Risperdol, Lamictal, and Effexor, among a few others. This helped her moods and backed the symptoms down a bit for a while.Later on, probably 8-10 months, the hallucinations were getting stronger, accompanied by suicidal tendencies and self-harm, and a new symptom arose that looked a lot like absent seizures. This ultimately culminated in her carving the word "HELP" into her thigh with a pair of scissors, followed by the obvious involuntary commitment, which was spent at the hospital. This led to a new diagnosis, epilepsy. It was explained to us then that hallucinations can be a symptom of epilepsy. This was new info to me. She was prescribed Keppra and sent home. The hallucinations subsided entirely within a few weeks.With the addition of Keppra, she weaned off Risperdol and Lamictal as instructed. What followed after was a marked increase in the absent seizures, now characterized by entirely different symptoms. She would now have standard post-ictal headaches, occasionally some aphasia where she couldn't speak but could still communicate with ASL, and usually some transient amnesia with associated confusion. This would range from forgetting a few days to forgetting several years, sometimes not even recognizing me (we've been together almost four years). These periods of amnesia would last anywhere from 30 minutes to upwards of two hours on bad days.On followup with the neuro who gave the epilepsy diagnosis, a seven day at-home video EEG was ordered. This had to be cut short at day 3 due to a skin reaction she was having, either to the glue or tape, I dunno. The next followup, to go over the test findings, resulted in a diagnosis of PNES as the EEG showed no abnormal brain activity after capturing over a dozen episodes.  Happy to finally have a diagnosis that seemed to cover everything, we followed the neuro's order to ween off Keppra and sought a change in treatment plan at the psychiatrist. This was about one month ago. She came completely off the Keppra about five days ago...And suddenly the hallucinations are back.I'm not smart enough to make heads nor tails of this, despite loads of online research. Getting in with the neuro or the neuropsychologist to which we were referred will take quite some time.The best thing I can come up with is some data suggesting that an estimated 10-25% of individuals with PNES also have epilepsy, which leads me to suspect that the Keppra may have controlled her epilepsy (and the related hallucinations) to a point that the PNES and its symptoms became more obvious.My questions are: Does my theory make sense? If so, is it likely? No other medicines have been added or removed except the Keppra, so why would the hallucinations come back?I'd appreciate any insight or direction that any of you may have to offer.Thank you.
85.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but based on the information you have provided, it does seem possible that the Keppra was helping to control the epilepsy symptoms and by removing it, the hallucinations have returned. It is also possible that the hallucinations could be a manifestation of the PNES rather than directly related to the epilepsy. 

It is important to discuss these concerns with your wife's healthcare providers as soon as possible. They will be able to provide the most accurate information and guidance on how to proceed. It may be necessary to explore different treatment options or medications to address both the epilepsy and PNES symptoms. 

In the meantime, it is important to ensure that your wife is receiving appropriate support and care for her condition. Encourage open communication with her healthcare providers and continue to advocate for her needs. It may also be helpful for you to seek support for yourself as caring for a loved one with complex medical issues can be challenging. 

Take care and best of luck on your wife's journey to better health.

86.question: Hi, I bit of back story here I've been diagnostic with NF1 when I was 5 ever since I had to do 2 MRI every year. every time they put a needle in my arm I would faint.So today I just got my blood draw for a schedule MRI in 3 weeks. And like always I fainted but I also started moving my arms and leg uncontrollably lucky the needle was removed before.Anyone know what could cause this or the actual naming?Age: 21 (22 in 3 month)Sex: Male
86.answer: It sounds like you may have experienced a vasovagal response, which is a fainting response triggered by certain stimuli, such as fear, pain, or the sight of blood. In some cases, this response can also cause muscle twitching or jerking movements. If this is a recurring issue for you, it may be helpful to speak with your healthcare provider about strategies to manage or prevent this response during blood draws and MRI procedures.

87.question: 49YO female with IBS like symptoms due to adhesions choking intestines, non-epileptic seizures due to migraines, deaf, in TCHP chemo for breast cancer, BMX August 1, 2018, no node involvement. 5'6, 220lbs. Effexor for seizure prevention. Bupropion for situational depression related to health challenges. I lost my hair to chemo, so for the first time I noticed I have ridges in my scalp. Googling that, only one thing comes up: Cutis Verticis Gyrata (CVG). My ridges, however, are very mild compared to most images. I can see them in the mirror, but can't find a way to accurately photograph them. They are very much like this in location and "layout", but not quite as deep. This is listed as something different though, related to mental retardation (article's words) from birth. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00105-007-1302-4 I do have a couple of the secondary issues listed, namely non-epileptic seizures and deafness. The former is blamed on migraines that left lesions on the brain and the latter is blamed on the seizures. Should I see an endocrinologist, or is this something else?
87.answer: Given your unique medical history and the presence of mild ridges in your scalp, it may be worth consulting with a dermatologist or a specialist in rare skin conditions. Cutis Verticis Gyrata is a rare condition that can sometimes be associated with underlying medical conditions, so it would be important to rule out any potential underlying causes. An endocrinologist may also be able to provide further insight into the possible connections between your current health challenges and the ridges in your scalp. It's always best to consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation and appropriate management plan.

88.question: Our son was recently diagnosed with idiopathic epilepsy. We were out of town for 1 week and he started having seizures 1-2 times per day. The episodes were short (20-30 seconds) but essentially he would feel dizzy, sit down confused, occasionally vomit and forget what happenedWent to an out of town hospital (emergency) and had EEG, CT, MRI, MRAs completed with no sign for the cause of the seizures. But the EEG did register slower brain waves indicating epilepsy.Neurologist placed our son on Keppra at 2ml dosage. Since taking the meds he had two very minor episodes during the first week (feels dizzy and needs to sit down but doesn’t lose consciousness or forget what happened). For the past week (2nd week of dosage) he has had no events.We went to see our neurologist today and he would like to increase the dosage from 2ml to 3ml. I’m a little confused since the meds are working at 2ml why up the dosage given all the potential side effects that can happen. I’m not against the meds and fully respect the doctors opinion. The meds are clearly helping and I know that the doctors have his best health in mind but my concern is from a completely laymen’s uniformed perspective it doesn’t make sense to up the dosage unless we don’t see improvement?
88.answer:
It is understandable to feel hesitant about increasing the dosage of your son's medication if he is already responding well. However, it is important to remember that epilepsy is a complex neurological condition and finding the right dosage of medication for each individual can be a process of trial and error.

The neurologist may be recommending an increase in dosage to ensure that your son's seizures remain under control in the long term. It is possible that the current dosage may not be fully preventing seizures or that your son's body may build up a tolerance to the medication over time.

It is important to trust in your neurologist's expertise and judgment, as they have the experience and knowledge to make these decisions based on your son's specific medical needs. If you have concerns or questions about the dosage increase, it is always a good idea to discuss them openly with your healthcare provider. They can provide more information about the reasoning behind the dosage adjustment and address any concerns you may have.

89.question: 48F, 152cm, 70kgGraves' disease in and out of remission for 10 years (remission last 2 years)Stopped carbimazole two weeks agoVery mild temporal lobe epilepsy for 30 yearsLevetiracetam 500mg dailyTetanus vaccination for deep cat scratch five days agoJust finishing a 5-day course of amoxicillin w/ clavulanic acid for same scratchA few days ago, I noticed some swelling above my left clavicle, and I can feel a pea-to-marble sized lump. Immediately, my paranoid brain went to my endocrinologist telling me a couple weeks ago that my lymphocytes have been low for the last two years (0.9) and that one of my liver values is slightly high. My neutrophils, which I understand can be affected by the carbimazole, are normal according to a blood test done just before I stopped taking it.Later, my rational brain kicked in and remembered that I just had a tetanus shot last week in the left arm. I have a doctor's appointment coming up and will certainly mention it, but I guess I'm looking for some reassurance in the meantime. Could it be the tetanus shot that has caused the lymph node swelling? Google results are terrifying for that particular node. Thanks in advance.
89.answer:
It is possible that the swelling above your left clavicle could be a result of the tetanus vaccination you received five days ago. Swelling of lymph nodes is a common side effect of vaccinations, as they are a normal part of the immune response to the vaccine. In most cases, this swelling is temporary and resolves on its own.

However, it is always important to mention any new symptoms or concerns to your healthcare provider, especially given your medical history and recent antibiotic use. Your doctor will be able to assess the lump and determine if any further investigation or treatment is needed.

In the meantime, try not to worry too much and focus on taking care of yourself. If you notice any changes in the size, shape, or consistency of the lump, or if you experience any other concerning symptoms, make sure to follow up with your doctor promptly.

90.question: I (22m) currently am on Vimpat and Phenobarbital for epilepsy, which I take twice a day. This morning however, my alarm decided to only vibrate instead of actually going off in order to wake me up to take my meds. So I was 3 hours late in taking them. I know that Vimpat is already pretty much out of your system in 12 hours, which worries me that I took it after 15 hours this morning. I have a bunch of important things to do all this week (some of which involve a lot of driving) and I’m now worried about any breakthrough seizures. So my question is, should I be worried or expect something to happen? And when will I know that I am in the clear and nothing will happen due to me being late on a dose?Side note: I did call my doctor and ask this already, but I’m currently waiting on a call back response, which sometimes takes hours, so I figured I would ask on here as well.
90.answer:
It's understandable to be concerned about missing a dose of your medication, especially when it comes to managing epilepsy. It's good that you have already reached out to your doctor for guidance on this matter.

In general, missing or delaying a dose of your anti-epileptic medication can potentially increase the risk of breakthrough seizures. However, every individual's response to missed doses can vary, so it's difficult to predict exactly what will happen in your case.

Since you have already contacted your doctor, it's important to follow their guidance once they get back to you. They may advise you on any specific steps to take, such as closely monitoring for any potential symptoms or adjusting your medication schedule.

In the meantime, try to stay calm and focused on taking care of yourself. Make sure to take your medication at the scheduled time for the rest of the week and pay attention to any changes in your condition. If you experience any unusual symptoms or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider for further assistance.

Overall, it's best to follow the advice of your doctor in situations like this, as they have the expertise to provide personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and medical history.

91.question: 28F. 5'8, 250lbs. White. History of epilepsy, asthma and vitamin D & B12 deficiency. Currently on Lamotrigine, Folic acid, Vitamin D, B12 injections.In the last few months I've had some debilitating health issues and, in the process of figuring out what the hell is happening to me, I just learned that my FSH is 122.2 miu/ml. My pcp has ordered estrogen levels to be checked and says we'll have to retest everything in a month to confirm a diagnosis of premature menopause. I just turned 28. I haven't menstruated in 6 months, so what are the chances that my reproductive organs will spontaneously start working again? What could cause this? And is there anything I should be worried about or does this just happen sometimes?
91.answer:
Premature menopause, also known as premature ovarian insufficiency, can be a concerning diagnosis, especially at such a young age. It is defined as the cessation of menstrual cycles before the age of 40, and can be caused by various factors such as genetics, autoimmune disorders, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or unknown reasons.

In your case, it is possible that your epilepsy, asthma, and vitamin deficiencies may have contributed to the premature menopause. Additionally, Lamotrigine, the medication you are currently taking for epilepsy, has been associated with hormonal imbalances in some cases.

The chances of your reproductive organs spontaneously starting to work again are relatively low, but it is not impossible. In some cases, premature menopause can be temporary and may be reversed with proper treatment and lifestyle changes.

It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider and undergo further testing to determine the underlying cause of your premature menopause. Treatment options may include hormone therapy, fertility preservation methods, and lifestyle modifications to manage symptoms and prevent long-term health risks associated with premature menopause.

It is understandable to feel worried and overwhelmed by this diagnosis, but know that you are not alone and there are resources and support available to help you navigate this challenging situation. Be sure to discuss your concerns and questions with your healthcare provider to come up with a personalized plan for your care.

92.question: A few years back while In the military I had a freak accident until it stopped being that and continued to occur day after day. After some months I was diagnosed with epilepsy.In the beginning I was having 1-3 seizures a day while 2-4 of those were grand mal seizures a month. Medications didn’t work and just seemed to make everything worse so my neurologist made the decision to not give me medications after having tried 5 of them.It’s been a few years now and nowadays I get anywhere from 2-5? Every 4months and about 2 or 3 of those are grand mal seizures. A significant decrease but still ongoing. We never found a cause for the seizures.Well I’m asking because a few months back I started noticing a few things that started worrying me. For example,    a few years back and at the beginning of this I used to be “smart” as in I could write any word no matter how big or small but in recent months I’ve noticed I have a really hard time writing, as in spelling out words. I used to full on turn on autocorrect on my phone but nowadays I find myself almost completely depending on my phones autocorrect and looking up word spellings when even my phone can’t tell what I’m trying to say.    with writing again, for some reason I find myself forgetting or I don’t know, not using simple words such as “the” “of” “to” “and” “from” etc. or sometimes mistaking one word for another when there’s no connection between the two    same thing as above but with speech. I never had any speed impediment or any speech disorder prior but now I find myself getting “stuck” while trying to say a word. It’s to the point where it’ll happen at least once with every full sentence I try to speak. It’s gotten to the point where I’ll see it happening and I’ll try to say the word again and I won’t be able to, I’ll need to dramatically slow down my speech and literally say it in segments    dramatic increase in repeatedly forgetting. I’ll forget my keys, go back and get them, get there and forget what I was going to get or sometimes I’ll forget I forgot. So I’ll go back, then head back out and be like “I went back for my keys and came back without my keys” Male 23 5’11 185lbs first diagnosed at 20. The last neurologist was in the military prior to he being discharged so around 20years of ageEdit: cluster seizures have been very common with me. There’s been about 5x since it started where I’ve stopped breathing, one time in particular it was a really long time.
92.answer: It sounds like you have been experiencing some concerning symptoms that may be related to your epilepsy. It is important to discuss these symptoms with your healthcare provider or neurologist as soon as possible. They may need to adjust your treatment plan or consider other potential causes for these changes in your cognitive function. It is also important to have a care plan in place for managing your seizures and ensuring your safety during episodes, especially considering the episodes where you have stopped breathing. It is always best to take these symptoms seriously and seek medical attention if needed.

93.question: Age/Sex: 20M Height: 5' 10" Weight: 175 lbs About a month ago I swallowed roughly 42 grams of keppra. I eventually vomited, fell asleep, and woke up feeling pretty normal. I'm curious if there should be any hidden Long-term Health effects caused by my consumption of that much keppra that may not be obvious such as kidney, liver, or brain problems. Additionally, I am curious how likely it is I would have died from consuming that much Keppra and if a death from keppra would be painful.
93.answer:
It is important to note that taking a large amount of any medication, including Keppra, can be dangerous and potentially life-threatening. In your case, consuming 42 grams of Keppra is a significant overdose, as the typical daily dose for epilepsy treatment is around 1-3 grams. The fact that you vomited and fell asleep afterwards could have been your body's way of trying to expel the excess medication. 

It is difficult to predict the specific long-term health effects that may result from this single overdose. However, possible complications could include kidney or liver damage, as these organs are responsible for metabolizing and excreting medications from the body. In terms of brain damage, Keppra is primarily used to treat seizures and is not known to directly cause brain damage in overdose situations.

In terms of the likelihood of death from consuming 42 grams of Keppra, it is difficult to say without specific details about your overall health, metabolism, and other factors. Keppra overdoses are relatively rare and there is limited information available on the toxic dose that could result in death. However, it is important to seek medical attention immediately if you or someone you know ingests a large amount of any medication.

As for whether a death from Keppra overdose would be painful, it is likely that any overdose resulting in death would be accompanied by severe symptoms such as seizures, respiratory depression, and cardiac complications, which could indeed be painful. It is crucial to avoid taking excessive amounts of medications and to always follow prescribed dosages to prevent potentially dangerous consequences. If you have any concerns about the effects of your overdose, it is recommended that you speak with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and guidance.

94.question: 27F (180cm, 90kg, Austrian) diagnosed with: Crohn's disease (2013), SLE with CNS involvement/Neurolupus(2021), Epilepsy(2021), SFN (2022) medication: Levetiracetam 3000mg/d, Lacosamide 400mg/d, Perampanel 6mg/d, Gabapentin 600mg/d, Hydroxychloroquine 300mg/d, methylprednisolone 10mg/d, pantoprazole 40mg/d, mesalazine 4g/d, Rituximab 375mg/kg twice a year I get red (surrounded) patches on my tongue for about half a year now, 1-3 times per month in 6 different positions, usually just 1 or 2 simultaneously (https://imgur.com/a/LepvOwL). In the picture you see two on my left side, there can be another one on the left tip and the same can be mirrored on the right side. The most I had at the same time were 3 of these. They are painful, especially on contact (when eating); it's a burning sensation most of the time. They start small, get bigger and then develop a white "ring" instead of the red (in the photo), after this state the tongue gets white and the whole mouth has an unpleasant taste. But I would actually say I have good oral hygiene. Could this be related to one of my diseases, or could it be a side effect or something completely unrelated? I've already asked one of my doctors but he had no idea what this could be (out of his field). Which doctor would you suggest visiting, a dermatologist? I'm hoping to find someone here to help me out. I would be thankful for any ideas about what this might be, how to reduce the pain (except for standard painkillers) or to prevent it completely. Compared to my diseases it's not really that bad of course, but another annoying thing that might trigger despair.
94.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about the discomfort you've been experiencing with the red patches on your tongue. Given the range of medications you're on and the complexity of your medical history, it's important to consider various factors that could be contributing to this issue.

One possibility is that the patches on your tongue could be related to one of your existing conditions or medications. For example, oral manifestations are known to occur in autoimmune diseases like SLE. It's also possible that the patches could be a side effect of one of your medications, particularly since you're on a combination of drugs that may interact with each other.

Given the nature of your symptoms and the fact that your current doctor was unable to provide a definitive answer, it would be a good idea to consider seeking a second opinion from a specialist. In this case, a dermatologist or an oral medicine specialist would be the most appropriate healthcare provider to consult regarding your tongue condition. They have expertise in diagnosing and treating various oral health issues, including those that may be related to systemic diseases or medications.

In the meantime, to help reduce the pain and discomfort of the red patches on your tongue, you may consider using a soothing mouthwash or oral gel specifically designed for mouth sores. It's also essential to maintain good oral hygiene practices and to avoid any potential triggers, such as spicy or acidic foods, that may exacerbate the symptoms. Keeping a food diary can help identify any potential triggers and guide you in making dietary modifications.

Overall, it's essential to address this concern with your healthcare provider to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan to manage this issue effectively. I hope you find relief soon and get the answers you need.

95.question: TL:DR - Need answers about my 10 year old cousin who is suffering from migraines and seizure like symptoms, yet doctors claim it is not related to epilepsy and cannot find diagnoses.My 10 year old cousin who is probably around 4.3 feet and weights around 75 ibs, Fiona, (not her real name but for privacy’s sake...) has been having this ever since New Year’s Day 2021. It all started when she was having headaches or migraines. She started taking medications, and apparently she was having them per every fours hours.Then on February 15, I got a text from another cousin saying that Fiona was in the hospital due to her passing out, her legs feeling numb, and not being able to move. The doctors say that it’s probably due to the medication being taken too often. She was later sent back home since she got better. She stopped taking the migraine medications anymore, but then things got worse.She then started having some kind of seizure-like episodes. In these episodes she started shaking, twitching, having migraines from light sensitivity, trouble breathing, and that she feels hot. They last over 10 minutes and she has them up to 10 times a day or even more. She also has them in specific time periods such as 6:30 PM.When we called 911 and sent her to the hospital, she had to keep going back-and-forth and that this has happened five times due to doctors not being able to diagnose her (even though they had witnessed her symptoms). They keep saying things that we are sure that it is not true. Here are the things that they said:“ The episodes that she is having are not seizures.“ “It is probably from depression or some psychological problems.” (my cousin has never suffered from depression or anything like that) The first time that I witnessed one of Fiona‘s episodes in real life was during when we were having a welcoming back party for her. This episode lasted 50 minutes due to the fact that we cannot stand having this back-and-forth situation. It is absolutely heartbreaking and frustrating knowing we could not do anything. It has gone to the point that they have to go to Philadelphia (I assume they have better doctors over there), and they still said that it’s probably due to the medication. She is currently back home and still suffering from this. Again, I’m pretty sure that my cousin is not on any harsh medication whatsoever. All she is actually taking is Tylenol, and it is in moderation. So I am concerned as to if symptoms like this can last this long. In the end I know that this forum is not a place to find a diagnosis, but I hope that I can find an answer here. Just a little piece of assumption of what could she is going through can help my family get through this hard time.
95.answer: It is concerning that your 10-year-old cousin, Fiona, is experiencing migraine symptoms and seizures, but doctors have not been able to provide a clear diagnosis. It is important to continue seeking medical help and possibly consider getting a second opinion from specialists in a larger city like Philadelphia. It may be helpful to keep track of her symptoms, triggers, and any changes in her health to provide more information to the doctors. In the meantime, providing support and comfort to Fiona and her family during this difficult time is crucial.

96.question: Hi there.My husband underwent surgery 2 years ago to remove an encephalocele in his right temporal lobe that was causing seizures. He had no side effects and no seizures, and received permission from his neuro team to begin weaning off meds. He was completely off by March 2021. Last month I woke up to him having a tonic-clonic seizure in his sleep.Today we recieved the results of his MRI."There has been interval surgical repair of right tegmen mastoideum encephalocele, with new small region of encephalomalacia and gliosis in the adjacent right inferior temporal and parahippocampal gyri. Amygdala and hippocampi are otherwise relatively symmetric with normal signal and configuration.No evidence of mass, suspicious enhancement, or epileptogenic focus elsewhere in the brain."Our next appointment with his neurologist is in a week but it feels like a millenia. We are trying to understand so we can prepare ourselves for possible courses of treatment.Is ANY amount of encephalomalacia/gliosis expected following a lesionectomy? Does this result suggest he may just need additional support from pharmaceuticals to control seizures, or are we going to be exploring the possibility of another surgery?  Anything you can offer would help put my mind at ease.Demographics: 34yo male, healthy nonsmoker (6'2, 175lb). Craniosynostosis confirmed (IL11RA variant) and consequently underwent craniofacial reconstructive surgery at age 16. Diagnosed with right temporal lobe epilepsy at age 30. Encephalocele removed from temporal lobe and with medication patient was seizure free for 2 years. July 2021 MRI details new encephalomalacia/glioma near the resection site. Currently on 400mg Vimpat for epilepsy. No other health concerns.
96.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your husband's recent seizure and the results of his MRI. Encephalomalacia and gliosis are common findings following a lesionectomy, as they represent areas of scar tissue and inflammation where the surgery took place. This is a normal part of the healing process and can sometimes be seen on MRI scans.

The presence of encephalomalacia and gliosis near the resection site does not necessarily mean that your husband will need another surgery. It could indicate that there is some ongoing irritation or inflammation in the area that may need to be managed with medication. Your neurologist will be able to provide more insight into the significance of these findings and recommend appropriate treatment options.

It's important to remember that every case is unique, and treatment decisions should be made based on your husband's individual circumstances and needs. It's understandable to be anxious about what the future holds, but try to take things one step at a time and trust in the expertise of your healthcare team.

In the meantime, continue to support your husband and follow any recommendations from his neurologist. Keeping a seizure diary and monitoring any changes in his symptoms can also be helpful in guiding treatment decisions. Stay strong and take care.

97.question: 42 F Lamictal, cymbalta, singulair, levothyroxine, Pepcid, ambien 200lbs (significant weight gain in 3 years after injury to cervical spine - unable to run like I used to so I’m confident that is the main reason why) 3-4 drinks per year, past prescription drug use (all prescribed but over used/abused) no addictive medications for almost 2 years besides ambien but now I’m very careful. Quit smoking cigarettes 1 year ago. Use juul 5% nicotine 1-2 pods per day. History: postpartum psychosis, depression, epilepsy, hashimotos, reynauds, allergy induced asthma, thoracic aneurysm, insomnia Last year I made an appointment with a new family doctor due to a move. I was very open and honest about all past health issues and casually asked about my fainting spells. This is an issue that was ongoing since I was 12. After many tests they determined it is epilepsy. It seems to be well controlled now that I’m medicated and I haven’t had an episode/seizure for 10 months. In those months I’ve noticed I started to “feel things I see”. It’s so bizarre and hard to really explain. When I’m really engrossed in a program or movie and I see someone hug, get hurt, temp changes, even sex, I lightly feel the sensation. If I see certain places (like a national geo program) I can smell and feel the environment. I did ask my neurologist about it and she said that she didn’t think it’s a seizure but it’s strange how it started after they are controlled. My question is about synesthesia and if it’s something that is just pseudoscience or if there is concrete evidence on it? Could this be a mental disorder manifesting that will eventually take a downward turn? I have no complaints about the sensations because they are actually pleasant but it does scare me that they aren’t “normal”. Thanks to all the doctors who visit this sub and offer help!
97.answer:
Synesthesia is a real neurological phenomenon where one sensory perception triggers another unrelated sensation. It is not pseudoscience and is recognized by the scientific community. In your case, it is possible that the controlled epilepsy has somehow triggered these sensations, but without more information, it is difficult to say for sure.

It is important that you continue to discuss these sensations with your neurologist and possibly see a mental health professional to ensure that there are no underlying mental health issues manifesting. It is good that you are aware of these sensations and are willing to seek help if needed.

Overall, it is essential to stay proactive in managing your health and continue to communicate openly with your healthcare providers about any changes or concerns you may have.

98.question: Hello! I am a 51M and have had left temporal lobe epilepsy my whole life. I weight 130 pounds and I am 5’6”. I recently had an MRI done as I have had increased migraines and headaches. Here are my medications:    Lamotrigine    Topomax    Propranolol    UbrelvyMy MRI report came back and I have noticed new impressions and findings in it. I was wondering if someone could alleviate some anxiety and explain what these things mean. Specifically, the “Brain” and “Impression” portions of the report.Thank you very much in advance. COMPARISON: MRI brain dated 12/05/2018   TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar, multisequence images were obtained of the brain without administration of intravenous contrast.    FINDINGS:   HEMORRHAGE: No acute parenchymal, subarachnoid or extra-axial hemorrhage.    DWI: No evidence of acute or early subacute infarction.    BRAIN: No mass effect or edema. No significant atrophy or chronic microvascular ischemic changes. Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right.    VENTRICLES: Unremarkable. No hydrocephalus.    CALVARIUM: Unremarkable.    PARANASAL SINUSES: Unremarkable.    MASTOID AIR CELLS: Unremarkable.    OTHER FINDINGS: None.    IMPRESSION:   Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right which may be related to microvascular ischemic change with demyelinating disease not excluded.
98.answer:
First of all, I want to assure you that it is common for MRI reports to have findings that may sound concerning but are actually quite common and may not always indicate a serious issue. In your case, the MRI report indicates that there are a few small areas of abnormality in the white matter of the brain on the right side.
