These areas show up as punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality.

The impression suggests that these findings may be related to microvascular ischemic changes, which are tiny changes in the blood vessels that supply the brain. This can sometimes happen with age and may be a result of conditions like atherosclerosis or high blood pressure. The report also mentions that demyelinating disease, such as multiple sclerosis, cannot be completely ruled out based on these findings.

It is important to discuss these findings with your healthcare provider, as they will be able to provide more context and advice based on your medical history, symptoms, and overall health. They may recommend further testing or monitoring to better understand the significance of these findings and to determine the best course of action moving forward. Remember to communicate any concerns or questions you may have with your healthcare provider, as they are there to help guide you through this process.

99.question: 23M, 6’5 and wondering if liquid nytol is okay to use with a very mild form of epilepsy (no seizures) that is triggered by light.On no other medications but have ADHD and anxiety and can’t sleep anymore
99.answer:
It is important to consult with a healthcare professional before taking any sleep aid, such as liquid nytol, especially if you have a medical condition like epilepsy. Even though you have a mild form of epilepsy with no seizures, it is still important to consider any potential risks or interactions with your condition.

It is also important to consider your ADHD and anxiety when choosing a sleep aid, as some medications may exacerbate these conditions. A healthcare professional can provide personalized recommendations and advice on the best course of action for your sleep difficulties.

In the meantime, you may want to consider lifestyle changes or relaxation techniques to help improve your sleep, such as creating a calming bedtime routine, reducing screen time before bed, and practicing relaxation exercises.

100.question: 50F in Australia, on carbimazole and levetiracetam for Graves’ and epilepsy, respectively. FOOSH injury of the wrist.I tripped over some uneven pavement while running last night and fell on my hands. I got some road rash on one hand, and both instantly went numb. As the numbness wore off, one had was fine, but the other has pain. It hurts to grip things, and most of the pain is near the base of my thumb. Some pain radiates down the inside of my wrist. It’s not horribly painful but was enough to disrupt my sleep a lot last night, because I couldn’t find a comfortable position for my wrist. It also sent a shooting pain when I tried to use my thumb to press the button on my electric toothbrush.I’ve called a local medical centre, and their radiology office is closed for the weekend. They recommended going to the ED if I want an X-ray, but I’m not convinced it’s that urgent. It’s Saturday here now. Is it ok to wait for Monday, or is there any reason I should get it imaged right away?Here’s the damage to the palm of my hand.
100.answer:
It is always best to err on the side of caution when it comes to injuries, especially if there is persistent pain and difficulty with movement. Given that you are on medication for Graves' disease and epilepsy, it may be worth getting your wrist checked sooner rather than later to rule out any fractures or other serious injuries.

If you are experiencing significant pain and difficulty using your wrist and thumb, it may be best to go to the emergency department for an X-ray to assess the extent of the injury. They can provide you with proper treatment and guidance on how to care for your wrist while waiting for further evaluation.

It is important to prioritize your health and well-being, so if the pain persists or worsens, it is always best to seek medical attention promptly.

101.question: Epilepsy and lamictal 44 year old female. 215 pounds. Non smoker. Epilepsy. I’ve been diagnosed with epilepsy, juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, since my early 20’s. I would have one maybe a year or so. I started lamictal xr 200mg. First time on meds. Things got better but I still had them. Fast forward to 2019 October I had three in one month. I had my blood levels checked by pcp and neuro. At that point I was on lamictal xr 400mg. My levels have always been around 9ish. These 3 were checked the same time of day. 8/29/19 7.1 10/31/19 6.3 After I changed to newer bottles it was 11/22/19 9.2 These levels were checked because I pushed it. I had this history of always having these pinching headaches in the morning only. I addressed it with my regular neuro that was self pay, 2 others that were through my insurance. All shrugged their shoulders and said it’s fine. When I saw that the 10/31 dropped to 6.3 I for fun decided to start my lamictal bottles that had a later expiration date. The ones I was taking were expiring in 6 months so I went to ones that expiring in 2 years from them. The second opinion neuro said they are actually still good 6 months after expiry. I’m doing better after I changed my bottles out. My regular neuro said that even though expiry date has not passed and that it was older bottles to toss all those and use the newer ones. He used to write double dosage due to saving money so I had a bunch. He had wanted me to increase to 600mg xr but I didn’t because I was scared of making things worse. In April 2020 I finally did and I was in heaven. Morning headaches went away and I was so happy. My neuro shrugged his shoulders and said ok. I thought I was in the clear but I had one in October 2020 most likely due to my recklessly getting less sleep and being under marital stress. I thought great it’s been a year and due to my issues I won’t let it happen again. Now fast forward to June 2021 I had another one. I’m back to bad sleep and marital stress again. I have not had my levels checked but now after that seizure I’m starting to have headaches in the morning. Maybe it’s because I’m stressed again of it happening again maybe because my problems In life haven’t gotten better. My current meds expire a year from now. August 2022. My neuro had explained back then that even though when they were 6 months from expiry it’s possible that there is a somewhat of a decrease in the lamictal that for me it’s pushed me to the edge of it not being as effective for me. So basically my thoughts are is it possible I need to throw out the ones that are one year from expiry? My new ones are June 2023 and I haven’t started those yet. At the nov 2019 visit he first said maybe it’s time of day or fluke but when I told him what I did with newer bottles he then seemed to think the 6 months from expiry were ones that I should throw out even though technically they should be still ok to use. He said let’s say they were manufactured 5 years from expiry that the effectiveness for me is not as good anymore compared to the newer bottles. I haven’t contacted my neuro yet but will be this week. Will see if he’s changed his thoughts on that and maybe he will say one year should be ok and maybe it’s a me thing and nothing to do with my meds. To save money I was trying to finish the ones that expire next year but I would throw those out if a doc thought I should and start new ones. Also odd question. I take xr600 mg a day. Three 200mg pills a day. The new ones will be two xr300mg a day. Would this have any effect blood levels because they are xr and the coating melts at different rate. If they weren’t xr I wouldn’t be asking this question. I haven’t swapped them out to see if the headaches will go away because I was thinking I shouldn’t change the way the dosage is delivered. I just think it was odd. I have 3 seizures in one month and levels dropped. I change to newer bottles and levels go back up again. Also when I started the 600mg dose last year my levels were checked once and they were 12. After this long post my question is should I throw the ones out that expire next year? I won’t be able to get my levels checked anytime soon to see if they have dropped. If you’ve made it this far thanks for reading. Edit the bottles were stored in my dresser. And they were in original manufacture bottle from galxosmithklein gsk
101.answer:
It sounds like you have been managing your epilepsy well with the help of Lamictal, but you have experienced some breakthrough seizures recently. It's possible that the decrease in blood levels of Lamictal could be contributing to your seizures, as you mentioned that changing to newer bottles seemed to improve your symptoms.

Based on your experiences, it may be a good idea to follow your neurologist's advice and switch to the newer bottles with a longer expiration date. While it's true that medications can still be effective past their expiration date, there may be slight variations in potency that could impact your treatment.

As for the change in dosage form from 200mg XR to 300mg XR, this should not significantly impact your blood levels as long as you are taking the prescribed dose. The extended-release formulation is designed to release the medication over a longer period of time, so the slight difference in dosage should not cause any issues.

It's important to discuss these concerns with your neurologist, as they can provide personalized advice based on your medical history and current symptoms. They may recommend changes to your medication regimen or suggest other strategies to help manage your epilepsy more effectively.

102.question: My friend's brother just had a baby several days ago. The mom is in her mid 30s, third time mom, healthy. They have 2 completely healthy kids. The pregnancy was good, although the baby was born about a week after due date. The mom was in hospital during that period as she had contractions periodically but they said there wasn't a need to induce her. She delivered a (seemingly) healthy girl on june 27th (due date was june 19th).While she was in hospital, everything seemed great. When my friend and her brother went to pick the mom and baby up from the hospital yesterday, the baby had a mild seizure while the nurses were doing the final check-up. However, it was dismissed and the baby was allowed to go.Just mere hours after the baby got home, she had two more seizures in the span of 3 hours. The first was around 5pm and the second was around 8pm, after which they took the baby to the hospital. They ran some tests and decided to keep her for the night. She had another seizure in the morning, a stronger one, and it was witnessed by a doctor. The doctor was pretty concerned and ordered some other tests. The brain scan and reflexes were good, brain activity was good. They decided to keep her anyway, just to keep an eye on her. The baby was finally seen by a neurologist this afternoon. The neurologist is an older woman, they say she's very experienced in neonatal care. She basically said that it's nothing, that it happens all the time, that the mom was probably hungry, cold and/or scared so she was shaking during delivery which somehow transfered the shakiness to the baby and it manifested as a seizure (3 days later?). Now, I'm absolutely NOT a doctor, much less an experienced neurologist, but this honestly smells like BS. I also don't have kids and have never given birth. Is this possible? My friend and her family are holding onto what this woman said and I definitely don't want to be skeptical, but I really can't help it. It just sounds so impossible to me and the fact that it happened 3 times in the 24 hours the baby was released just makes me believe that the hospital is trying to save itself from a lawsuit.  Can any doctor, nurse, mother, anyone who had or has heard of a similar experience tell me their opinion? Because I truly wish I could believe it, but I simply don't. Even though the test results are good so far.
102.answer:
I understand your concerns and skepticism about the explanation given by the neurologist. It is always important to trust your instincts and seek further opinions or information if needed. 

While it is true that some babies can experience seizures due to various reasons, including lack of oxygen during birth or other medical conditions, it is still important to thoroughly investigate the cause of the seizures in this specific case. It is not common for a baby to experience seizures three days after birth due to the mother being hungry, cold, or scared during delivery. 

I would recommend discussing your concerns with the family and encouraging them to seek a second opinion or further medical evaluation if necessary. It is important to ensure the safety and well-being of the baby, and getting a thorough understanding of the situation is crucial in this case. 

Ultimately, trust your instincts and seek additional information or support if needed. I hope the baby receives the appropriate care and attention she needs to address the seizures.

103.question: So I'm an 18 yr old Caucasian male (62kg,180cm). Since some months ago, I have constant depersonalization/dereaalization and periods of confusion that really bother me. I went to a neurologist and had an MRI scan(which turned out fine, except for some normal anatomical variants) and I was wondering if my confusion and dpdr can be the result of epilepsy ?(non-convulsive seizures). Thanks!
103.answer:
It is possible for confusion and depersonalization/derealization to result from epilepsy, particularly non-convulsive seizures. However, it is important to note that there are many other possible causes for these symptoms as well. It's good that you have already seen a neurologist and had an MRI scan, as these tests can help rule out other potential causes of your symptoms. 

If you are still concerned about the possibility of epilepsy, I would recommend discussing this with your neurologist. They may recommend further testing, such as an EEG (electroencephalogram) to look for abnormal brain activity that could be indicative of seizures. It's also important to continue to communicate openly with your healthcare provider about your symptoms and any concerns you may have. 

In the meantime, try to practice self-care techniques and stress-management strategies to help cope with your symptoms. And remember, seeking help from a healthcare professional is the first step towards finding relief and managing your symptoms effectively.

104.question: What would cause a 31 year old Caucasian female w/east European and french-canadian decent who is 5'3 110lbs to have;-Seizures (family history epilepsy, personal history TBI) w/seizure onset being 26.-Chronic low potassium-Chronic borderline and sometimes full anemia-POS ANA 1:320 that had been POS ANA 1:160 for several year but recently has risen-GFR swings on and off from 90 to 70 to as low as 50 in one year and cycling this patten indefinitely-Difficulty w/low glucose however repeat testing and dr deny Diabetic as an option-upon seizure onset new symptoms of small blood clots and bruising. Significant pain in locations followed by relief and brusing in the location.-female doesn't drink (at all) or smoke had been working out regularly last decade until onset of symptoms came with intense fatigue.-Has had 1 child, only complications was significant post birth hemorrhage.-upon seizure onset development of seeing black lines in vision that come and go.-potential stroke upon onset of all above resulting in drop foot right side, eye palsy right side, neuropathy of right side-chronic borderline high MCH-positive Raynauds-Bouts of unprovoked tachycardia with PVC  -aphasia and dysphagia-swelling of joints but negative RA factorTests negative for- -Sjorgens specific -Lupus has been consider however initial workup showed stable c3 and c4 and was dismissed year of all onset. Hasn't had lupus specific retesting since then.Differental offered was MS but cleared on MRIs.
104.answer: Based on the symptoms described, it is possible that the individual may have a rare autoimmune disorder such as Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS) or Systemic Vasculitis. These conditions can present with a combination of neurological symptoms, low potassium, anemia, positive ANA, GFR fluctuations, blood clotting issues, vision disturbances, joint swelling, and other systemic manifestations. It may be beneficial for the individual to seek a second opinion from a rheumatologist or hematologist specializing in autoimmune disorders for further evaluation and management. Further testing for specific antibodies associated with APS or Systemic Vasculitis may be warranted to confirm a diagnosis.

105.question: My mum (45F, 165cm, 80kg, non drinker, non smoker) moved from India to Australia in 2006. She had her first seizure (tonic-clonic) in 2009 and was diagnosed with Epilepsy which has been reasonably controlled (rarely any tonic-clonic seizures and isolated absent seizures) with Keppara and Trileptal on varying doses over the last 10 years. Her current dose is Trileptal 750mg bd and Keppara 1000mg bd. She also has medications for high blood pressure and high cholesterol. Mum recently went to India for 6 months and after returning, has been dealing with multiple absent seizures a day where she will have a lapse of attention and mental confusion/unable to pay attention. There are also lip smacking and chewing motions also. She has accidentally injured herself during the absent seizures and they seem to occur in periods of stress/anxiety. As a result, the docs are saying there might be a psychological aspect to her epilepsy. She has most of her family overseas so has always dealt with feeling isolated and may be feeling more so since coming back from India. We are getting her in with a pyschologist in the New Year but really want to know if anyone on here can offer any advice on why the medications are no longer controlling the absent seizures and if there might be something we are missing. It has impacted her lifestyle/QoL immensely over the last decade and it is getting worse so if anyone has advice on different ways we can manage this, we would be grateful. Whether it is seeing a different medical specialist, allied health practitioners or things we can implement to ensure her safety. Thank you.
105.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your mum's recent struggles with absent seizures. It's important to remember that epilepsy management can be a complex process and sometimes adjustments to medication or additional treatments may be necessary. Here are some suggestions that may help improve your mum's situation:

1. Consult with a neurologist specializing in epilepsy: It might be beneficial for your mum to see a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy to get a second opinion on her current treatment plan and explore other possible medication options.

2. Keep a seizure diary: Keeping a detailed record of when the absent seizures occur, any triggers, and their duration can help identify patterns and potential triggers. This information can be valuable for healthcare providers when evaluating treatment options.

3. Explore alternative treatments: In addition to medication, there are other treatments such as dietary changes, relaxation techniques, and neurofeedback therapy that may help with seizure control. It's essential to discuss these options with healthcare professionals before implementing them.

4. Create a safe environment: Given that your mum has been accidentally injuring herself during absent seizures, it's important to ensure her safety at all times. Removing sharp objects, installing padding on furniture, and ensuring someone is always around to supervise her can help prevent injuries.

5. Seek support: Dealing with epilepsy can be challenging, both for the individual and their loved ones. Joining support groups or connecting with others who have experience with epilepsy can provide valuable emotional support and coping strategies.

It's great that your mum will be seeing a psychologist in the New Year as her mental health and emotional well-being are essential components of overall epilepsy management. Remember to stay patient and persistent in finding the right treatment approach for your mum. Wishing you and your mum all the best in finding solutions to improve her quality of life.

106.question: Ever since I was a little kid, every few months I get hit with absolutely insatiable vinegar cravings. I will straight up drink it from the bottle and still want more. I also get cravings like this for things that are quite acidic in nature, such as lemons, hot sauce, or tomatoes. As a kid my parents would have to literally cut me off because I would eat so much my lips would turn white, and I’d still want more. I’ll sit down and eat an entire head of lettuce, bundle of celery, full size cucumber, etc with vinegar on it. (Idk if this is important, but I hate apple cider vinegar. My go to is red wine vinegar, but white vinegar or balsamic will also do the trick.) I do imbibe on occasion and have noticed that the last two days after I did get these vinegar cravings, but other than that, I can’t pinpoint any specific triggers.I’m a healthy weight and eat a fairly varied diet, and the only oddities in my bloodwork are low white blood cell counts.I’ve heard that sometimes intense cravings can signal some sort of biological clue for a nutrient that is missing. Could that be something that is going on? I was just curious! This doesn’t really negatively impact my life, it just causes me to get some weird looks sometimes.Details: 23F, 5 ft 3 inches, 130 lbs, Caucasian, acid cravings, existing medical issues (Migraines, IST, mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation), medications (verapamil and singulair), no drugs, sparingly drink, no smoking.
106.answer:
It’s interesting that you have these intense vinegar cravings every few months. It’s possible that these cravings could be related to a nutrient deficiency, but it’s hard to say for sure without further information. Some research suggests that cravings for certain foods, like vinegar or other acidic foods, could be related to a need for specific nutrients like magnesium, potassium, or vitamin C. However, it’s always best to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and advice.

Given your existing medical issues and medications, it’s important to discuss these cravings with your healthcare provider to rule out any potential underlying health concerns. They may be able to offer insight or suggest further testing to determine if there’s a specific nutrient deficiency or other reason behind your cravings.

In the meantime, if these cravings are not negatively impacting your health or daily life, it may be okay to indulge in moderation. Just be mindful of your overall dietary balance and make sure you’re getting a variety of nutrients from your meals and snacks. And if you find yourself experiencing these intense cravings more frequently or if they start to impact your health, definitely reach out to your healthcare provider for further guidance.

107.question: I’m 19F about 5’3” not sure about my weight but quite small from the UK.So, in the past, I’ve had what I believe to be 3 tonic-clonic seizures. I never actually got medical advice for these because 2 happened after smoking weed and one when my (untrained) friend pierced my nose and I didn’t want my parents to find out about any of these with a trip to the doctors (when they did ever find out they just thought I fainted because it was a hot day etc) These were years ago so I haven’t thought about them much. An hour or so ago my boyfriend was having a normal conversation with me and I started panicking for no reason at all and from past experience felt like I was going to have or had just had a seizure. I got really hot, dizzy, panicky, shaky and just didn’t feel right overall. I felt kind of disconnected if that makes any sense. I thought this might be a focal seizure. A while afterwards though I still didn’t feel normal, I’ve been staring at my room for about 20 minutes just looking around and closed my eyes for 10 minutes with my knees to my chest rocking side to side. I just don’t feel quite normal at the moment and I’m not sure if I could have epilepsy or it could just be my mental health (I have depression, anxiety and occasionally worry I have schizophrenia) but I thought I was doing alright mentally at the moment.Sorry for the long post, as I say it’s my first ever post on Reddit and I’m just very confused about what’s going on at the moment.Any ideas or advice would be great!
107.answer:
First of all, I want to reassure you that seeking medical advice is crucial in situations like this. It's important to get a proper diagnosis and treatment plan from a healthcare professional.

Given your history of seizures and the symptoms you experienced recently, it's possible that you may have epilepsy. It's also important to consider other factors such as your mental health conditions and how they may be affecting your symptoms.

I would strongly encourage you to make an appointment with a doctor or a neurologist to discuss your symptoms and concerns. They will be able to conduct a thorough evaluation and provide you with the necessary support and guidance moving forward.

In the meantime, try to take care of yourself by getting enough rest, managing stress, and avoiding triggers that may worsen your symptoms. Keep a journal of your symptoms and any potential triggers to share with your healthcare provider.

Remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, and you deserve to receive the necessary support and care to help you feel better. Take care and reach out for help when needed.

108.question: Age 33 Sex M Height 5’ 9” Weight 170 Race Caucasian Duration of complaint 3 Weeks Location Distal Tibia/Ankle Any existing relevant medical issues Epilepsy Current medications KeppraI’m about 3 weeks post skateboarding injury and I have this lump on my distal tibia. Seems like it’s off the bone on the medial side. As a skateboarder it’s common to take repetitive shots to the ankle, so I’m not overly concerned. The lump happened to appear after the injury. It wasn’t super painful so I kept on skating after a few more incidents to the same area I decided to take a break. I’m about a week removed from skating and haven’t seen a noticeable improvement. No pain. Just sensitive to the touch. Thanks in advance
108.answer:
It is concerning that you have developed a lump on your distal tibia after a skateboarding injury. Even though there is no pain, it is important to have it evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out any fractures or other serious issues. It is possible that the lump could be a result of a soft tissue injury or inflammation.

Given your history of epilepsy, it is important to ensure that the injury is properly addressed to prevent any complications or exacerbation of your condition. I recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible to have the lump evaluated and determine the appropriate treatment plan. In the meantime, it would be best to avoid any activities that may aggravate the injury further. Take care and I hope you have a speedy recovery.

109.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female
109.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your relative's health struggles. It sounds like she has been through a lot with the fainting spells and potential MS diagnosis. It is important for her to have a comprehensive evaluation by a neurologist specializing in epilepsy and MS to get a clear understanding of her condition. In addition to medications, there are other treatments and lifestyle changes that may help manage her symptoms. It is also important for her to have a supportive network of family and friends to help her through this difficult time. If she hasn't already, she may want to consider seeking a second opinion from a different healthcare provider to ensure she is receiving the best care possible.

110.question: 25F white JME keppra 1gMy epilepsy seems very well controlled with keppra. No complaints.Lately I've been feeling really tired, but I'm getting good sleep. I don't have any signs of seizures when I wake up. It's always been hard to wake up in the mornings, but lately it's been awful. It feels like I didn't sleep at all.I was working today. I closed my eyes to blink, and everything was kinda dizzy, but it went away quick. It's hard to describe, it's kinda like dizziness, but also like everything's... dropping? Melting?It feels like my brain is tripping up just like with a myoclonic jerks, but there's no myclonic jerk. Weird right?I've just been trying to shake it off. I been on keppra for 3 or 4 years. Can it wear off?
110.answer:
It's possible that the tiredness and dizziness you're experiencing could be side effects of the medication. While Keppra is generally a well-tolerated medication, some people may experience certain side effects over time. It's important to speak with your doctor about any new symptoms you're experiencing, as they may need to adjust your dosage or switch you to a different medication.

It's also important to consider other factors that could be contributing to your symptoms, such as stress, poor sleep quality, or other health conditions. Keeping a journal of your symptoms and discussing them with your doctor can help determine the underlying cause and develop a plan to address them.

Overall, it's not likely that Keppra would suddenly stop working after 3-4 years of use, but it's always best to consult with your healthcare provider to rule out any potential concerns. Be sure to mention any changes in your symptoms, as well as your concerns about the medication's effectiveness.

111.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female 5,5 Ft, 160 Lbs Non smoker
111.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but it sounds like your relative is experiencing some serious health issues that require prompt and comprehensive medical attention. It is concerning that she has been given conflicting diagnoses and treatments for her condition.

I would recommend seeking a second opinion from a different neurologist or specialist to get a clearer understanding of her condition and the best course of treatment. It may also be helpful to keep a detailed record of her symptoms, triggers, and any patterns that you notice to share with her healthcare providers.

In the meantime, it is important for her to prioritize her safety and well-being by avoiding situations where she is at risk of falling or injury. Encouraging her to maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise, a balanced diet, and proper sleep can also help support her overall health.

I hope this information is helpful, and I wish you and your relative all the best in finding a resolution to her health issues.

112.question: 28F 5’6” 225lbs non smokerA little less than a month ago, I had two seizures in the span of 24 hours due to postpartum eclampsia. I have never had a seizure before, and from what I understand, I shouldn’t have one again because it was due to the high blood pressure caused by the eclampsia.The neurologist at the hospital put me on Keppra for a month just to be safe and prevent more seizures while my body recovered from the eclampsia. 1000mg twice a day.Well, I am off all blood pressure medications and have stabilized from the eclampsia, and now it’s getting to be time to come off the Keppra and I am worried about what it will be like coming off.I’ve read things about Keppra causing a lot of side effects when you come off it, which is very scary to me seeing as a lot of the day I am alone with my newborn and I cannot be in an unfit state during that time.I don’t think I’m at risk for going off the Keppra triggering a seizure, right? Because it was a one time thing caused by high blood pressure? And my blood pressure is now under control? That’s what scares me the most. Being alone with my newborn and having another seizure because I got off the meds. Should I ween off the meds or have I been in them a short enough time and the fact that I’m not epileptic makes it safe to come off them without risking serious side effects?I am talking with the neurologist I saw at the hospital who prescribed me the Keppra, but he’s been very nonchalant, not really getting back to me, and doesn’t seem to understand my really big concerns because I am alone with a newborn for a lot of the day and I need to be 100% certain that coming off Keppra will not interfere with my ability to care for him.
112.answer:
First and foremost, it's important to follow the guidance of your healthcare provider when it comes to weaning off Keppra. It sounds like you are already in communication with the neurologist who prescribed the medication, which is a good first step.

In general, it is recommended to gradually taper off Keppra rather than stopping it abruptly. This can help reduce the risk of experiencing withdrawal symptoms or a return of seizures. Your neurologist should be able to provide you with a specific tapering schedule based on your individual circumstances.

Regarding the risk of having another seizure after coming off Keppra, it's important to remember that your previous seizures were likely triggered by the eclampsia and high blood pressure, rather than being related to epilepsy. Since your blood pressure is now under control and the eclampsia has stabilized, it is less likely that you are at risk for a repeat seizure.

However, it's always best to err on the side of caution and continue to follow the advice of your healthcare provider. If you have concerns about caring for your newborn while coming off Keppra, be sure to express these to your neurologist so they can provide you with the necessary support and guidance.

It's understandable to feel anxious about coming off medication, especially when caring for a newborn. Remember to prioritize your own health and well-being, and don't hesitate to seek support from healthcare professionals, family, or friends during this transition period.

113.question: Prefacing with comorbidities: obese, diabetic, hypertension 75 inches, 300lbs Early March, I had an episode where I felt what was almost like an electric shock in my right hand, followed by a similar sensation on the left side of my head. I fell unconscious, and the next thing I know, the EMTs are at my house. My wife states that I was convulsing, and, at one point, not breathing during the attack. After standard workups, they found a 8mm lesion on my brain. televisit Neurologist told me that it didn't look like cancer and that 'no neurosurgeon is going to operate on this.' Either way, I was scared. Went to a well-reputed hospital, and saw a neuro-oncologist. He felt this was serious, and ordered a functional MRI as well as a Stealth MRI. I was really happy to receive the results that this was not brain cancer, and was in fact vascular in nature (literally, anything but brain cancer, right?). I was referred to a neurosurgeon who deals with things more vascular in nature. He's ordered a diagnostic cerebral angiogram, which I'm getting tomorrow. CTA showed a narrowing of my carotid artery, and he suspects it was a dissection. Either way, I'm simultaneously being treated by a neurologist at the same hospital as the aforementioned neurosurgeons in case this was a seizure (my initial diagnosis). I did not tolerate keppra well (rage), and am now on Vimpat. Almost every night, I have these episodes where I have this 'pit of my stomach' that I recognize as how I felt right before I had my initial attack. Questions: Are these seizures, or could this issue completely vascular in nature? Can a dissection/TIA cause seizures? What about the initial attack? Looking up TIA online, I'm not seeing it presenting in this manner. Will I be on these seizure meds forever (They make me feel awful, with brain fog, etc.)? Did I develop Epilepsy at age 35?
113.answer:
It sounds like you have been through a lot with your health concerns and I'm sorry you are having to deal with all of these issues. It is understandable that you are feeling scared and overwhelmed.

To address your questions:

1. It is possible that your symptoms could be due to a vascular issue such as a dissection or TIA, rather than seizures. Both dissections and TIAs can sometimes cause symptoms that mimic seizures, such as the electric shock sensation you described. It is important for your medical team to continue investigating to determine the underlying cause of your symptoms.

2. Seizures can sometimes be a complication of a dissection or TIA, but it is not the most common presentation. It is important for your doctors to carefully evaluate your symptoms to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.

3. It is not uncommon for seizure medications to have side effects such as brain fog and other issues. It is important to communicate with your healthcare team about how you are feeling on the medication so they can adjust as needed. It is also possible that you may not need to be on seizure medications long-term, depending on the underlying cause of your symptoms.

4. It is possible to develop epilepsy at any age, so it is important for your doctors to continue monitoring and evaluating your symptoms to determine the best course of treatment for you.

I hope this information is helpful and I wish you all the best in your journey to better health.

114.question: Why does my head feel like it’s slightly shaking when I put my hands on my forehead and press them down into my pillow ? I am 21M, I am 21 and a male, 5’9 roughly in height, I weight roughly 60 KG, I take epilepsy medication called Epilim 6 tablets per day in the morning and the evening, I’m a non smoker, I am white/ Caucasian, I don’t use drugs, my issue is twitching problems, this issue started on the 27th of September and has lasted till this day, it has happened in Leeds the United Kingdom. I have only had absence seizures before which nobody ever noticed, the neurologist that I saw in Poland this summer said it’s very likely that I will only have absence seizures my whole life. 5 days ago I noticed that my leg started slightly twitching, I noticed this physically and I don’t feel it unless I see it, 2-3 days ago I felt my left arm slightly twitching. When I put my head into my pillow in a certain position or against my bed I feel like it’s slightly shaking, other wise I get no other feeling from my head. 5 days ago I started getting small weird twitches in my left upper arm and right leg nowhere else in my body, the doctors that I saw today and yesterday said that Yesterday when I was sleeping I felt that a weird shaking feeling in my body at night but honestly unlike the other feelings this might have not even happened, I’m not sure that it did happen. I saw two doctors about this yesterday and both said it’s probably from stress and the doctor yesterday said it’s the fasciculation of muscle from stress. They booked me in with a neurologist but it might take 3 week. What’s wrong with me ?
114.answer: It is important to follow up with the neurologist as scheduled to get a proper diagnosis. The twitching and shaking sensations you are experiencing could be related to your epilepsy medication, stress, or possibly some other underlying neurological issue. It is also possible that these symptoms could be related to anxiety or panic attacks. It is best to discuss your concerns with the neurologist and follow their recommendations for further evaluation and treatment. In the meantime, try to manage stress through relaxation techniques, exercise, and healthy lifestyle choices.

115.question: About a month ago i smoked a little weed with my friends at a pool and when i got out i started feeling extremely light headed so i went to go sit down on a lounge chair next thing i knew i was on the ground everything was completely black and i couldn't see or hear anything all i could feel was my body flopping around uncontrollably and i couldn't stop it. The whole experience only lasted about 15 seconds but it felt like 15 minutes then out of nowhere i was able to stand up and my vision cleared and i was fine if anyone has any experience with or knows why this happened please help me im scared there could be underlying health issues i never knew about (i smoke fairly frequently and it never happened prior to this incident or after any help would be greatly appreciated)Edit: mods removed my first post for not adding this so age and gender 16m weight 132lbs height 6'3 no medical issues aside from psychological and im on no medications
115.answer: I'm not a medical professional, but it sounds like you may have experienced a brief episode of syncope, which is a temporary loss of consciousness caused by a drop in blood pressure. It's possible that the combination of smoking weed, being in a hot environment, and possibly not hydrating enough could have contributed to this episode. It's always a good idea to talk to a doctor if you have concerns about your health, especially if you experience similar episodes in the future. Take care of yourself and stay safe.

116.question: Today the mathematics docent in my university, who is approximately 60 years old, froze for some 20 sec leaning on his desk, then his face's right half made something like a smile, and he turned his head slightly rightwards, for some 15 sec, and as we were just realizing something's wrong, he burst out in short unnatural laughter, moving his hands away from the desk, then stiffened and fell back. He hit his head at the board; of course, we called ambulance. I was out to wait for it, but after accounts of my colleagues who stayed with the docent, he was unconscious for 5-7 minutes, foam from his mouth, and as I could myself see, blood had run from within his left ear (the medics who came commented than it could be that he got a skull fracture from the hit in the board rim which is metallic; his skin on the front left of his head where he apparently hit the board was reddish, scratched from the rub; although it appeared to me that he must rather hit the board with the rare of his head). He was desoriented, not sure how much he understood, but he answered negatively when they asked him if he had epilepsy. I read this whole afternoon about strokes and epilepsy but none of the various descriptions seems to match what I witnessed (esp. the disturbing laughter). Some idea?
116.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but based on your description, it is possible that the mathematics docent experienced a seizure. Seizures can sometimes present with unusual behaviors such as laughter or disorientation. The fact that he was unconscious, had foam coming from his mouth, and blood from his ear indicates that there may have been a more serious underlying issue.

It would be best to wait for a medical professional to provide a proper diagnosis and treatment plan for the docent. In the meantime, make sure he receives the necessary medical attention and support.

117.question: So I am a 26 y/o male and I was just diagnosed with epilepsy about a year ago.  went to my current neurologist and he prescribed me Lamotrigine tablets for the seizures. He only prescribed them in 6 month increments and will not renew the prescription until I come in for another appointment. Currently I am on my last month of the prescription and had not scheduled an appointment yet. I tried to renew the prescription through my pharmacy, but the Dr declined the renewal request. I was able to make a last minute appointment for tomorrow but that seems a little wrong of him to do that. What if I was unable to schedule an appointment before my prescription ran out? I know it’s on me to reschedule the appointments but this is potentially life saving medication for me. These are not opiates or amphetamines. I just didn’t know if this was the norm or if the Dr is being unnecessarily difficult. Thank you for any clarification on this.
117.answer:
It is important to follow up regularly with your neurologist to monitor the effectiveness of your medication and ensure that you are on the right dosage. It is possible that your doctor has specific reasons for wanting to see you in person before renewing your prescription, such as discussing any potential side effects or adjusting your dosage. However, it is definitely concerning that your doctor declined the renewal request without giving you a clear explanation or alternative solution.

It is always a good idea to communicate openly with your healthcare provider about any concerns or difficulties you may have in accessing your medication. In the future, you may want to discuss with your doctor a plan for scheduling appointments and obtaining prescription refills in a timely manner to prevent any interruptions in your medication regimen.

If you are unable to schedule an appointment before your prescription runs out, it is important to contact your doctor’s office to discuss the situation and see if there is a way to expedite the process. You may also want to ask your pharmacist if there are any options for obtaining a temporary supply of medication while you wait for your appointment.

Overall, it is essential to advocate for your own health and well-being in situations like this. If you continue to experience difficulties in obtaining your medication, you may want to consider seeking a second opinion or discussing your concerns with a patient advocate or healthcare administrator.

118.question: I was recently diagnosed by a neurologist with partial epilepsy. the symptoms I had were burning sensation in the back of my head and neck and my back, memory and concentration problems and tightness inside of my head, I felt it in the beginning in the top of my head back in 2017, and starting from 2018 it transferred to the bottom inside of my head. I got prescribed Zeptol 200mg (Carbamazepine) and one for memory and concentration and another for something else (I'll update this with the other prescriptions, I'm writing this from work because I'm on the verge of quitting). I previously thought that I had a problem with my neck or something that has to do with my spine. I have gone to several neurologists and this is the only one that mentioned partial epilepsy. The previous ones all said it was nothing to worry about. I, today have dementia. I have trouble following courses or job meetings or anything. Sometimes I forget the name of people around me. I should mention as well that I feel something really tight in the bottom back of my head. After some research I found that a part of the brain called hippocampus is the one responsible for short term memory processing. It's been a week and a half using Zeptol (200mg). I started with one a day for a week. Now the second week I increased it to two, just as my neurologist said. I still don't feel the benefit that I wanted, to gain back my short term memory. Is the damage done to my short term memory reversible, or am I gonna be like this for the rest of my life?eventually having Alzheimer in my 30s?
118.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your recent diagnosis and the challenges you are facing with your memory and concentration. It's important to follow the treatment plan prescribed by your neurologist and give it some time to see if there are any improvements in your symptoms.

It's difficult to predict whether the damage to your short-term memory is reversible or not. Everyone's condition is unique and may respond differently to treatment. It's important to continue working with your healthcare team to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment as needed.

Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that is different from epilepsy. It's important to discuss any concerns you have about future potential complications with your healthcare provider.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to explore memory enhancement techniques and strategies to help cope with memory and concentration difficulties. This could include things like creating lists, using reminder apps, and practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques to help reduce stress and improve focus.

Remember to take care of yourself and seek support from loved ones or a counselor if needed. Stay in communication with your healthcare team and don't hesitate to ask any questions or voice any concerns you may have. Stay positive and keep working towards better health and well-being.

119.question: Yet another EDIT: I fainted today on my way to the store and was brought into the hospital. They did a bunch of tests, and realized I was having from 6-10 "silent" seizures a day. I probably had them when I was younger too and they just went away, and came back due to my lack of sleep in the past couple of weeks and anxiety. I honestly didn't even know that was a thing until yesterday, so thank you all. They also did a GI and said that I might have gastroparesis, which would explain pretty much all my symptoms when it comes to weight-loss, and I have an appointment for a gastric emptying study in 2 weeks from now. Thank you all!EDIT: I've called them brain zaps my whole life, but I didn't know that was an actual medical term for something completely different. Its not the withdrawal kinda zaps, it's like a loss of consciousness that I get, but still stay standing up.EDIT 2: No, I don't have an eating disorder. Doctors have no idea why I lost my appetite and can't keep food downSo I really don't know how to explain this without sounding absolutely insane.
119.answer: I apologize for the confusion. It seems like I may have misinterpreted my symptoms. I have been experiencing fainting episodes, seizures, and possible gastroparesis, but I do not have an eating disorder. The term "brain zaps" that I used previously may have been misleading, as it actually refers to something different. I appreciate all the support and information provided by everyone. Thank you for understanding.

120.question: Age:18 Sex:F Weight:46 kg Height:1.61 cm So i have had histories of deja vu, it usually doesn’t last long. I don’t have them a lot, sometimes more sometime less. I have a huge fear of brain tumor/epilepsy so i am always looking out for symptoms. I also randomly get dream flashbacks. Sometimes at night, doesn’t happen that often, i get like weird head/body vibrations/buzzing and then i try to go to sleep, i start having nonsense thoughts and i can’t sleep. My ears are buzzing right now and so is my head. My heart sometimes gets on a higher rate and i wake up from this mildly depersonalized. I fear that this mighr turn into a grand mal seizure. I have had no history of seizures before. I am so scared to sleep right now fearing that something might happen. It’s probably about a year that this situation while i am trying to sleep happens. Wold really love to have an EEG bit when i went to the neurologist a year ago he only diagnosed me with anxiety combined with elements of OCD. He did some reflex/eyesight tests and all came back with no neurological deficit. I’d get an EEG but i am literally such a hypochondriac that my parents are concerned and i just went through blood tests and i don’t want to worry them again! If anyone has any idea i’d be so glad :)
120.answer:
It sounds like you are experiencing symptoms of anxiety and possibly panic attacks. Deja vu, dream flashbacks, body vibrations, buzzing sensations, and racing heart are all common symptoms of anxiety. It is also common for anxiety to manifest itself as a fear of serious medical conditions such as brain tumors or epilepsy.

It is important to remember that anxiety can cause physical symptoms that mimic serious medical conditions, but that does not mean you actually have those conditions. It is also common for anxiety to worsen when trying to sleep, leading to difficulties falling asleep and intrusive thoughts.

It is recommended that you seek help from a mental health professional, such as a therapist or psychiatrist, to help you manage your anxiety. They can provide you with coping mechanisms, such as relaxation techniques and cognitive behavioral therapy, to help you manage your symptoms. It may also be helpful to talk to your parents about your concerns and seek their support in seeking treatment.

While an EEG may provide reassurance, it is important to address the underlying anxiety that is causing your symptoms. Remember that you are not alone in experiencing anxiety and there is help available to support you through this difficult time.

121.question: 23 AFAB in Canada, 500mg keppra 2x daily, 50mg lamotrigine daily, recently given Tylenol 3’s, Zofran, and torodol to take. Hi all! I’m 23, have endo, PCOS, gastroparesis, and epilepsy. I had my first excision laparoscopy at 17, was on birth control until it gave me a stroke, did the whole Lupron then Orillissa thing for two years until it stopped working, had an IUD until it got embedded into my uterus, and now I’m lucky to be the patient of an excision specialist willing to do a hysterectomy and excision surgery within the next 6-9 months. I’ve done pelvic physiotherapy too, and eat gluten free since it significantly reduces my pain (might be celiac, haven’t been tested). I’m currently having pain way worse than usual and I’m convinced it’s my left ovary (sharp left lower quadrant pain but it radiates to the back, across my abdomen, with some rebound pain but not significant). I went to the ER and they could see some of the ovary, could see that both ovaries had “multiple follicles” (I presume this is my PCOS, unsure how many they mean by multiple) but couldn’t tell if it was torsion or not, gave me IV morphine in a 1L bolus, sent me home with the T3’s and zofran with instructions to come back if it didn’t get better for another U/S and a CT. (Urinalysis and US ruled out urinary concerns, idea behind the CT was to rule out diverticulitis I believe). No pregnancy or STI risk. Ijust went back and saw a doctor who ridiculed me, suggested birth control, wouldn’t let me speak, and said “I guess we can give you morphine, this is the problem with you pain patients”. He also suggested prescribing more narcotics which I repeatedly said I want to rule out torsion instead of being given even more narcotics. He said torsion would make me vomit, but I’m on zofran. My family doctor is off until September, my pelvic physiotherapist is booked until September, I’ll try calling my surgeon tomorrow. But what the hell do I do in the meantime? I’m in excruciating pain and I don’t want to be chewing on codeine. I’m just so frustrated. I’m an active 23 year old grad student, I’m so close to getting rid of these useless organs, but I’m sitting here passing out from pain. My main concern is that my seizure risk increases as I’m in more pain, my second concern is developing a drug dependency. Any advice is welcome.
121.answer:
I'm so sorry to hear about all the difficulties you are facing. It sounds incredibly frustrating to be in so much pain and not be getting the proper support and care from your healthcare provider. It's important to keep advocating for yourself and seeking out medical help until you get the relief and answers you need.

In the meantime, you can try using heat therapy (like a heating pad) to help with the pain, as well as practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness to help manage the discomfort. Make sure to stay hydrated and try to rest as much as possible.

If the pain continues to worsen or if you experience any new symptoms, it's important to go back to the ER or seek out another healthcare provider for further evaluation. Trust your instincts and don't be afraid to speak up for yourself and your needs.

I hope you are able to find some relief soon and get the care and support you deserve. Remember that you are not alone and there are people out there who are willing to help you. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to reach out for help when needed.

122.question: Here’s my info: 21F, 160lbs, 5’2”, White; preexisting conditions include Major Depressive Disorder, General Anxiety Disorder, and Asthma; non drinker, but I do vape and smoke weed Current medications: Zoloft 100mg 1x/day AM, Adderall 10mg as needed for school/work, Fluticasone inhaler (Advair) 2x/day, Singulair 10mg 1x/day PM, Xyzal 5mg 1x/day PM, Ventolin inhaler as needed, Keppra 500mg 2x/day I made a post about this a few months ago. I went through a few details about these weird “episodes” I’d been having that I later found out were partial seizures. You can read my first post here Anyway, on 10/7 I suffered my first grand mal seizure. I went to the ER and had a CT and bloodwork- both were unremarkable. I was also given Keppra IV, as well as a Keppra prescription 500mg 2x/day. I also had an MRI and an EEG- both unremarkable as well. Since then I’ve had a few more of these partial seizures. They come at completely random times and the doctors were stumped as to why this suddenly popped up. I have no family history of epilepsy, and never had seizures prior to these starting around mid/late 2019. Never had any crazy fevers as a kid, and have not introduced any new drugs etc. since they started. I’m really just making a post to gather more insight and experiences from doctors and other people as well. If anyone has any insight as to what could be causing this, it would be much appreciated. This diagnosis has kinda knocked me on my ass, as I can’t drive for 6 months after my last seizure. While I’m glad my scans/tests were unremarkable, I wish I had gotten some sort of answer.
122.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your recent diagnosis of epilepsy and the impact it has had on your daily life. It can definitely be frustrating not having a clear answer as to what may be causing your seizures. It sounds like you've already undergone a lot of testing and evaluations to try and identify a potential cause, which is a good start.

Epilepsy can have various causes, including genetics, head injuries, brain infections, brain tumors, and other neurological conditions. In some cases, the cause of epilepsy may not be clear, which is referred to as idiopathic epilepsy.

Given your complex medical history and medication regimen, it's possible that one of your preexisting conditions or medications could be a contributing factor to your seizures. It's important to continue working closely with your healthcare providers, including neurologists, to monitor your symptoms and adjust your treatment plan as needed.

In addition, lifestyle factors such as stress, lack of sleep, and substance use (including vaping and smoking weed) can also potentially trigger seizures in some individuals with epilepsy. It may be helpful to discuss these factors with your healthcare providers and explore ways to manage them effectively.

Overall, managing epilepsy requires a comprehensive approach that may include medication management, lifestyle modifications, and regular follow-up appointments with your healthcare team. It's important to stay proactive in managing your condition and seeking support from healthcare professionals and loved ones.

I hope this information is helpful, and I wish you all the best in managing your epilepsy and overall health. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare providers for guidance and support. Take care.

123.question: Basic Information Age: 71 Gender: Male Height: 5’7” Weight: ~70kg Smoking status: Non-smoker for 2 years (smoked for 40 years previously) Medical issues: Advanced liver disease, cirrhosis Duration: Approximately 6-7 years Hi all, My father (71M, about 70kg), was diagnosed with cirrhosis back in 2014 as a result of alcohol abuse. Over the years since, he's had three bouts of esophageal varices (the most recent in January 2020) and four seizures: May 2019, Sept 2019, Jan 19 2021, Feb 23 2021. Things have felt pretty stable since he recovered from his last bout of esophageal varices in 2020, and it was a relatively relaxing year in terms of worrying about his health. While it can be heartbreaking, he has only been drinking a few beers every night and I've had to accept a few years back I can't stop him drinking. During Christmas, he told me he has gone off Xifaxan - which I believe he's been on since January 2020- as he hates going to the bathroom every hour and informed his doctor. He's aware it's for hepatic encephalopathy, however outlines he doesn't need it due to his cognitive functions still relatively in tact: he does the cryptic crossword every day, a sudoku, and can still play a vast range of songs on piano. Moreover, his long term memory of events and trivia seems unchanged. Though, from my observations over the years, there's a decreased lack of insight into the situation, increased short term memory loss, and less fluid intelligence. Following yesterday's seizure, he was prescribed Keppra. I guess what I'm asking is that: is it possible that going off Xifaxan is causing the seizures to return? Can seizures be a symptom of hepatic encephalopathy? Google says it's a rare side effect, but possible. Dad sometimes postulates it's a result of his motorbike accident in 1971 and was recently taking salt tablets due to low salt levels, however I advised him to speak with his GP about this and the GP advised him to stop. So far no doctor has made this connection - or, more accurately, what Dad has told me what the doctor's are saying. He's being sent to a district hospital later this month for an fMRI scan. This is worrying. Usually whenever there's a return to hospital - esophageal varices or seizures - there's a sigh of relief that he survived once again and one doesn't have to worry for while, but now with two seizures a month apart, I'm concerned they'll be more frequent and end up causing a coma and/or death. Ultimately, I asked him today if he would rather have seizures or go to the bathroom every hour. He said he'd rather have seizures as he hated how he felt going to the bathroom. Even if this is the cause, I guess, just like I can't make him quit drinking, I can't force him to go on any medications. Other medication as at November 2020 Propranolol 40 mg antoprazole 40 mg andesartan 16 mg Spiractin 25 mg Mirtazapine 15 mg Thanks in advance.
123.answer:
I am not a doctor, but I can provide some general information based on the details you have shared. 

Seizures can be a symptom of hepatic encephalopathy, which is a condition that occurs due to liver dysfunction. The build-up of toxins in the blood can affect brain function and lead to seizures. Going off Xifaxan, which is commonly used to treat hepatic encephalopathy, could potentially contribute to the return of seizures in your father. It is important to discuss this with his healthcare provider to determine the best course of action.

It is also concerning that your father is experiencing frequent seizures and other symptoms related to his liver disease. It is crucial for him to follow his doctor's recommendations and stay on top of his medical care to manage his condition effectively. The fMRI scan scheduled for later this month will hopefully provide more information on his current health status.

It is understandable that you are worried about your father's health, especially with the increased frequency of seizures. Encouraging him to prioritize his medical treatment and adhere to his prescribed medications is essential for his well-being. It may be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with him about the potential risks and benefits of his treatment options.

Ultimately, it is up to your father to make decisions about his health, but offering your support and guidance can make a positive difference. I recommend continuing to communicate with his healthcare providers and explore all available options to ensure he receives the best care possible.

124.question: 19F 167cm 59kg chinese in UK // "passing out" under certain conditions, suspected focal epilepsy?? duration: 3+ years?? (no existing medical conditions, no smoking/drugs etc)  Hi, I'm in a bit of a pinch and desperate for some kind of second opinion /advice on this since I'm travelling back home from uni and can't see a GP until I return in October (personal/family reasons).I've been "passing out" unexpectedly for short periods of time maybe a few times a month for at least 3 years now but only recently cared enough to dig deeper. It seems that it happens when I'm focusing on a bright light/screen in a dimly lit environment (e.g. it's happened every time I went to a concert in the past half year, 7 times, also in the car at night when looking at bright lights, and watching a presentation on a projector in a dark-ish room). Each time it happens I feel a bit dizzy/nauseous and slow, then my eyes roll and refuse to focus, and eventually my head drops and I'm unconscious for a few seconds to a few minutes. When I regain consciousness I feel quite disoriented and often "pass out" again very quickly for several times in succession until removed from the environment. It seems to also take at least several minutes of being exposed to the stimulus before anything happens, in general. I can't really remember accurately since it feels very hazy.
124.answer:
I'm not a medical professional, but based on the information you provided it does sound like a possible case of focal epilepsy, specifically photosensitive epilepsy. Photosensitive epilepsy is a type of epilepsy that is triggered by visual stimuli such as flickering lights or certain patterns.

It's important that you see a doctor as soon as possible to get a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. In the meantime, try to avoid situations that trigger your episodes, such as concerts or looking at bright screens in dimly lit environments. Make sure to also inform your family and friends about your condition and what to do in case you have an episode.

If you experience any other symptoms or if your episodes become more frequent or severe, seek immediate medical attention. Remember, it's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to your health.

125.question: Male 6months old no medical conditions, no medicine being taken. Approx 20lbs healthy baby boyMy son was sleeping and woke up screaming I went to soothe him and he couldn’t be consoled for what seemed like forever. I tried waking him up from what seemed like a nightmare but he wouldn’t wake finally he woke up and stopped screaming. He became unresponsive but with eyes open. He looked lethargic and wouldn’t respond to stimulation. Then shook a little bit 3 times and went back to normal. Was this a seizure? Should I take him to the hospital or have his doctor look into it at his physical?Thank you for any responseUpdate: baby went to the doctor today they will be doing an EEG to be on the safe side.
125.answer: It's always best to err on the side of caution when it comes to your child's health. It's possible that what you described could have been a seizure, so it's important to have a medical professional evaluate your son. The doctor's decision to perform an EEG is a good step in determining if there are any underlying issues that need to be addressed. It's important to continue to monitor your son and consult with his doctor if you notice any further symptoms or changes in behavior. Wishing you and your son all the best.

126.question: Hi docs, I'm at a loss as to what my best course of action is next. Would love to hear your advice. It's a long, detailed post, but I still left out some stuff to keep it a reasonable read. Let me know if there's anything you'd like me to add or clarify.When I was a teenager I got these weird feelings in my body, and it caused me to basically jerk my hands/arms. The feelings also gave me this weird sensation to fall to the ground. I've never had a full blown seizure, but my neurologist diagnosed me with epilepsy. I was prescribed oxcarbezapine (trileptal) and I took it for many many years. It worked perfectly. Those feelings were completely gone.About two years ago I stopped taking the medication. My life was completely normal up to that point and I've never had any of those feelings basically since I started taking the medication. Also many of the side effects of the medication had subsided completely. It was as if I wasn't taking anything at all. I thought I'd give it a shot at stopping. Worst case scenario I can just get back on it again.It was a great year or so of no issues at all. I thought I was cured.  Then I had a bout of H pylori and I took two rounds of antibiotics + prilosec. Almost as soon as I started taking the antibiotics + prilosec combo, the feelings returned with a vengeance. My arms violently jerked on a couple of occasions. And here's the kicker - the oxcarbezapine I had been taking no longer worked when I went back on it. Worse, the antibiotics gave me recurring acid reflux, which always trigger those epileptic feelings.I immediately changed my diet to keto to help manage the situation, and it mostly worked. I still had the occasional feeling, but it was minor and didn't cause any issues. I spoke to my neurologist around this time and he said it's probably best to just continue managing it with diet and exercise, as he didn't want to put more toxins in my body. I still couldn't really do many normal life stuff like date, travel or go to friends' gatherings, because I was fearful of the feelings rearing up again at a bad time. But at least I had a healthy diet and I was exercising reguarly. I'm pretty healthy otherwise.Fast forward to about two weeks ago. I basically ate a meal with a lotta sugar/carbs in it, and it kicked me out of the low carb ketosis. Immediately the feelings returned again with a vengeance. This time it was even worse. I felt like I had to hold on to something whenever I walked. I might as well be in a wheel chair. The feelings roared inside me.I knew I had to get back into ketosis ASAP. So I fasted immediately, stayed home for a few days, and ate zero carbs. Now I'm feeling a bit better after getting back into ketosis. But the problem is this time, there are still a ton of those feelings remaining. Sometimes I have to stop walking and just stand there, just to wait for the feeling to go away. Other times I've even had to walk weirdly to manage the feelings. Needless to say it is extremely weird in public.  Right now I'm not sure what my best course of action is. Will this go away? If I just keep up the keto and exercise? Should I try a different drug? I feel like whatever side effects any new drug might have will still be worth it. Right now, I basically can only get away with doing stuff by myself. I wouldn't be able to do stuff with others. I would seize up or be afraid of seizing up. I can't really function like this. I'm self employed but if I have to get a regular job (which I have been considering), this could never work.I'm happy to clarify or add any details as needed.Thank you so much in advance
126.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about the challenges you're facing with your epilepsy symptoms returning. It's important to work closely with your healthcare provider to find the best course of action for managing your condition.

One option to explore could be trying a different antiepileptic medication to see if it can help control your symptoms. Your neurologist may have insights into other medications that could be effective for you and discuss the potential side effects and benefits of each option.

Additionally, continuing with a healthy diet, such as keto, and regular exercise can be beneficial in managing epilepsy symptoms. It's great to hear that you are already incorporating these lifestyle factors into your routine.

It's also important to consider any triggers that may be exacerbating your symptoms, such as consuming foods high in sugar and carbs. Avoiding these triggers and maintaining a stable diet can help in managing your symptoms.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize self-care and seek support from friends, family, and healthcare professionals during this time. Managing epilepsy can be challenging, but with the right treatment plan and support system in place, it is possible to improve your quality of life.

I would recommend reaching out to your healthcare provider for further guidance on managing your symptoms and exploring potential treatment options. Stay proactive in your care and don't hesitate to seek help when needed. Best of luck on your journey to managing your epilepsy symptoms.

127.question: I took my epilepsy meds about 1.5h ago, Divalproex Sodium 250mg. I want to take a regular Gravol (not nighttime) so I can get to sleep earlier. I know it's not the best sleep aid but I don't have anything else at home currently and I want to fix my awful schedule.I read something about diphenhydramine triggering seizures but I'm not sure how similar it is to dimenhydrinate which is in Gravol so I'm a little worried as I haven't had one in years.
127.answer:
It's always best to consult with your doctor or pharmacist before taking any new medications, especially if you have a history of seizures. While diphenhydramine and dimenhydrinate are similar in structure, they do have slightly different effects on the body. 

If you are concerned about the potential risk of triggering a seizure, it may be best to avoid taking the Gravol and try other methods to improve your sleep schedule. This could include establishing a bedtime routine, avoiding caffeine and electronics before bed, and creating a comfortable sleep environment.

If you do decide to take the Gravol, it's important to monitor how your body reacts and if you experience any unusual symptoms, contact your healthcare provider immediately. Your health and safety should always be a top priority.

128.question: Background info: Hi I’m at 36 year old male, I have epilepsy and take medication for it. I received a micro discectomy at the start of the month and a second surgery to due to increased pain 5 day ago. I’m also currently taking gabapentin, celecoxib, and cyclobenzaprine. Five days ago, in the hospital, I was in a lot of pain and was receiving pain medication through an IV. The nurses were having a lot of difficulty placing the IVs in me, and my IV was changed about four times. I’ve been home for about five days and yesterday two of the areas where the IVs where placed developed a small rash.Right where the needle entered. The first one is located on my posterior palm below the digits 1 and 2 The other is located on my posterior forearm on the ulnar just distal my elbow. The rashes are red, slightly elevated and very itchy.Should I be worried? Is this an allergic reaction to something? Is there any home/over-the-counter remedy I can try before before making a doctor’s appointment. Thank you in advance
128.answer:
It is possible that the rash is a result of an allergic reaction to something used during the IV placement process, such as adhesive tape or the IV catheter material. It could also be related to an irritation from the repeated needle insertions.

In order to determine the cause of the rash, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional, such as your primary care physician or a dermatologist. They can provide a proper evaluation and recommend the appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, you can try over-the-counter antihistamine creams or oral antihistamines to help with the itching. You can also apply cold compresses to the affected areas to reduce swelling and discomfort. Additionally, keeping the area clean and avoiding scratching can help prevent further irritation.

If the rash worsens, spreads, or does not improve with at-home remedies, it is important to seek medical advice promptly. In the meantime, make sure to avoid any known triggers or irritants that may have caused the reaction.

129.question: My mother (age <60yo, no familial history of dementia) had a mild cognitive impairment since the surgery 12 years ago, but a year ago she was diagnosed with a depressive disorder and presented some amnesic complaints that were attributed to her past medical history (she is currently being followed in psychiatry). A few months ago I started observing a difficulty in transmitting any kind of information to others (comprehension is maintained) and sense of overwhelming when she has different tasks to do in the same day, but she keep being independent at her domestic daily activities.I don't know if this is my med student clinical reasoning or my overthinking, but (and as a future doctor), is it possible to make a differential diagnosis between demential syndromes or other diseases (excluding obvious imaging or analytical findings)? Which is the role of the classical mini-mental examination test + clock test at screening patients for dementia?
129.answer:
As a future doctor, it is important to consider differential diagnoses when evaluating cognitive impairment in a patient. In the case of your mother, it is important to rule out other potential medical or psychiatric conditions that could mimic symptoms of dementia. 

The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) and clock drawing test are commonly used screening tools for dementia. The MMSE assesses various cognitive functions such as orientation, memory, attention, language, and visuospatial abilities. The clock drawing test evaluates executive functioning and visuospatial skills. These tests can help provide a baseline assessment of cognitive function and aid in identifying potential cognitive deficits that may be indicative of dementia. 

However, it is important to note that these screening tests are not diagnostic on their own and should be used in conjunction with a thorough medical history, physical examination, and laboratory testing to rule out other potential causes of cognitive impairment.
