Additionally, consulting with a neurologist or geriatric psychiatrist for further evaluation and assessment may be warranted in cases where a definitive diagnosis is needed. 

Ultimately, it is important to approach the evaluation and management of cognitive impairment in a thoughtful and comprehensive manner to ensure the best possible care for your mother.

130.question: Hi I recently had blood work done (a week ago) and my levels were high. 36yr female, I take 300mg daily of lamictal for epilepsy.Hemoglobin: 16.4 H Red blood cell count: 5.22 H Hematocrit: 47.8 H Some things I've noticed in the last 2-3 months, not sure if they are symptoms, but they have been happening enough and are different enough that I've noticed them. - night sweats, sometimes the shirt I sleep in will be wet, and it wakes me up - itchiness after hot baths or showers - fatigue (I had low vitamin D, so not sure if it's necessarily related to red blood cell count, vitamin D, or just general tiredness, i haven't been sleeping well for the past few months)
130.answer: It sounds like it may be worth discussing these symptoms with your healthcare provider, especially since your red blood cell count and hematocrit levels are high. These symptoms could potentially be related to your medication, underlying medical condition, or other factors. Night sweats, itchiness, and fatigue can sometimes be signs of an underlying issue that needs to be addressed. Your healthcare provider may recommend further testing or adjustments to your medication based on the results of your blood work and your symptoms. It's always best to address any concerns or changes in your health with your healthcare provider.

131.question: 36F 145 pounds 5'8 Started having issues with everything in my early to mid20s I'll list everything just in caseDIAGNOSED: Epilepsy - diagnosed in 2007 Narcolepsy with Cataplexy - diagnosed in 2009 Raynaud's with Erythermalagia - diagnosed 2016Other symptoms: Pins and needles in stomach, face, eyes, extremities, head -not all at once -this can occur at random times -sometimes while I work out, having sex (which can also cause my fingers or lips to stiffen and I have to wait for them to work itself out) sitting on the toilet, or laying down (which only happens to my stomach) Every blue moon, I'll have muscle spasms feeling like they are steming from my spine after I've laid down. It feels more neurological, if that makes sense.My body will feel like it's shaking on the inside, almost like it's vibrating. Usually when I'm tired.I have urge incontinence probably due to years of battling constipation. Must admit, I think it's getting better as it's not as frequently happening as it was.My left nostril will drip or run snot sometimes without me even realizing it (newer symptom) My primary doctor said it's probably just post nasal drip and prescribed me nasal spray twice a day. It does help dry it out but if I miss even one time, my husband will point out it running down.Recently switched neurologist and had a EEG done which I had an episode though it showed on the test and the nurse helped me through it, it registered as not a seizure or he said it didn't convince him that it was though the nurse clearly saw it.  At times when I'm feeling off I'm rushed with rapid heart beat, shakiness, and I can't read (everything looks to be in another language). At this point I feel confused, scared, angry, and rushed. Happens a lot when I have decisions to make. Restaurants, retail store, airport, etc.I get brain fog a lot but as long as I take my nuvigil I do a lot better.Here's why I'm posting... I can hear everything while having an episode, though sometimes when I repeat back what was happening while I have a seizure it's not all the way correct. I can't talk during it. My eyes roll back. The last one I shook some, which doesn't usually happens. I've had times where my hands cripple up (rarely). I usually feel a "drooping" or pulling in my bottom lip when things start and a complete lack of ability to use my muscles. They feel really heavy. I tend to stare right beforehand. The second to last episode I felt a pulling sensation, like someone was turning my head towards the left. When it ended, I head was facing left.My neurologist is putting me on Vimpat. I was taking Xyrem for ten years but last year I switched to ambien because my snoring got really bad.Current medication: Ambien 5mg Nuvigil 250mg I have an IUD I'll be starting Vimpat 100mgWasn't very active in my 20's Started working out in my 30's Past year in a half I have focused on strength training and cardio 5-6 times a week.
131.answer:
It sounds like you have been through a lot with your health issues and I'm sorry to hear that you are dealing with so many symptoms. It's good that you are working with a neurologist to try to manage your epilepsy and narcolepsy with cataplexy. It's also good that you are staying active with your strength training and cardio workouts.

132.question: An MRI with Neuroquant showed these normative percentiles: Hippocampal Occupancy Score – 32 Hippocampi – 72 Superior Lateral Ventricles – 94 Inferior Lateral Ventricles - 74 The hippocampal volume seems normal but the hippocampal occupancy score is very low. 132.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but based on the information provided, a low hippocampal occupancy score can indicate atrophy or damage to the hippocampus, which is a critical brain region for memory and emotional regulation. Given your symptoms of memory loss, depersonalization, reduced consciousness, and depression, it is possible that the changes in your hippocampal occupancy score may be contributing to these issues.

The fact that you have a history of epilepsy, COVID, vaccine reaction, and past use of CBD oil with negative effects could all be contributing factors to the changes in your brain. 133.question: I have epilepsy(taking Keppra/Lamictal)Age: 39M Height: 6’0 Weight: 235 Non smoker/drinker I have epilepsy(controlled by meds) and have typically avoided flu vaccines due to GBS(albeit rare). Has anyone heard of any data related to the Covid vaccine and GBS and/or is there a better choice when choosing between brands.
133.answer:
As of now, there have been very few reported cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) associated with the COVID-19 vaccines, including Pfizer and Moderna. The risk of developing GBS after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine appears to be very low, much lower than the risk of developing GBS after contracting COVID-19 itself.

It is important to note that the benefits of getting vaccinated against COVID-19 outweigh the risks of potential side effects, including GBS. Vaccination is critical in preventing severe illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19, especially for individuals with underlying medical conditions like epilepsy.

If you have concerns about GBS and the COVID-19 vaccine, it is recommended that you speak with your healthcare provider. They can provide you with personalized recommendations based on your medical history, current medications, and individual risk factors.

Ultimately, the decision to get vaccinated should be made in consultation with a healthcare professional who understands your unique circumstances and can help you make an informed choice.

134.question: About June of 22 I suffered an event which felt like a lightning bolt across my chest not soon after starting experiencing numbness in arms and legs, constant bouts of extreme fatigue and muscle spasms/ cramps…neurology ruled out epilepsy and PNES, they are still stumped on ms or lyme possibly…the only confusing part is reoccurring rhabdomyolysis and extreme heat intolerance…the numbness has turned into more of a burning feeling down arms and legs and seems to be spreading used to only start in finger tips and toes…the muscle spasms in legs seems to be getting worse…neuro could only find. Low testosterone symptoms, was referred to endocrinologist and put on test replacement…exercise and diet seem to help temporarily but then I hit the reoccurring course of over heating and then my CK levels spike was at 16000 recently but after aggresive flushing they went back down, we’re kind of at a cross road was wondering if anyone had insight on what to do next? Neurology only wants to repeat an mri once per year to rule out ms
134.answer:

135.question: Hong Kong,18M On 27 August I had my first seizure, it happened at a restaurant which go for lunch nearly every day. The waiter there told me she saw me fell suddenly and seizing on the ground. After I ‘woke up’ I found my self yelling and struggle to leave the restaurant. Then slowly regain consciousness and paramedics asked me to unlock my phone in order to contact my parents. They also me that they called the police for help.I have no idea about what I did during that time... It makes me feel so ashamed.... After one day of hospitalization I was discharged with no medication given. I was also given a discharge slip mentioning the diagnosis was epilepsy Just a few days my second seizure occurred, while I was sleeping. When I woke up, I saw paramedics standing in front of my bed. Then nothing else. Then the next thing I could remember was , I am inside a ambulance. I can feel my brain like a computer lagging. It took me around 20-30s to recall why I was in an ambulance. After one day of hospitalisation, I discharged with Lamictal prescribed. After gradually increasing the dose, now I have to take medication two times per day, 100mg in total. I can start to feel the side effects. It makes me memory decline.. It makes me feel so frustrated. I did not want my friends to know. So I talked about my feelings on other forums anonymously. The reply I got was, are sure you are suffering from epilepsy? (That person)I have the same experience before too! Turns out he was diagnosed vasovagal episode. So now I am doubting if I am suffering from epilepsy or not? I really hate taking that Lamictal and wish to get rid off it..
135.answer:

As for the side effects of your medication, it's important to discuss them with your doctor. They may be able to adjust your dosage or prescribe a different medication that is more tolerable for you.

Remember, it's okay to seek support from friends and loved ones during this time. Talking about your feelings and concerns can help alleviate some of the stress and confusion you may be experiencing. Take care of yourself and prioritize your health.

136.question: 24 F USA Asthma, epilepsy, hypothyroidismI have laryngeal candidiasis (unknown cause but thought to be from Breo and prednisone?) and it isn't responding much to fluconazole. The next step is amphotericin b and I'm kinda nervous. What should I expect realistically?
136.answer:

Realistically, you may experience some side effects while taking amphotericin b. Common side effects include fever, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, and muscle pain. In some cases, more severe side effects such as kidney damage or allergic reactions may occur.

Before starting the medication, your healthcare provider will likely discuss the potential risks and benefits of treatment with you. They will also closely monitor your condition while you are taking amphotericin b to ensure that it is working effectively and to watch for any potential side effects.

It's important to follow your healthcare provider's instructions closely while taking amphotericin b, and to report any concerning symptoms or side effects promptly. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to discuss them with your healthcare provider.

138.question: My boyfriend (82kg, about 176cm tall) has had panic attacks that look like seizures since he was 16. He is now 31. During those attacks, which are primarily triggered by his fear of needles and medicinal procedures, he loses consciousness. He describes it as "the light going further and further away until I'm in a black void and there is a hammering noise in my head". He also told me that sometimes he kicks around and trembles and shakes while he is out of consciousness. He was tested for epilepsy twice, has had several blood tests. His attacks only happen when he is in an anxious situation.He did take drugs like weed and speed as a teenager, he quit smoking in January this year. He has depression and anxiety officially diagnosed as well as panic disorder.A few weeks ago I witnessed such an attack for the first time ever. And I thought I was prepared. But suddenly his face turned purple. So I called an ambulance. He was brought to the hospital and they gave him medicine to calm him down ( I think it was opioids) so they could test his blood and stuff and it all came back normal, there is also still no sign for epilepsy. He is sleeping well, he is eating well, he is drinking well. Therapy and medicine have already been recommended to him many times. He's had CBT, but they never really did any confrontation therapy with him aside from drawing blood from him with a needle, which went well.

It's important for him to continue seeking professional help and support in managing his anxiety and panic attacks. Therapy and medication can be very effective in helping him learn coping strategies and techniques to manage his symptoms. It's concerning that he has experienced these attacks for so many years and has not seen much improvement. It may be helpful for him to seek a second opinion from a different healthcare provider or specialist to ensure he is getting the best possible care.

It's also important for you to take care of yourself during this time. Witnessing someone you care about going through such challenging experiences can be very difficult. Make sure to prioritize your own self-care and reach out for support if needed.

Overall, it's clear that your boyfriend is struggling and it's important for him to continue seeking help and support in managing his mental health. With the right treatment and support, he can work towards managing his anxiety and panic attacks and improving his quality of life.

141.question: The other day I didn't use the dosage cup and just swallowed some Pepto-Bismol Max. I guess it was maybe a mouthful? I don't know how much that is but it felt like a "large swallow". 142.question: My girlfriend and I are at the end of our rope. Age: 24, height: 171 cm, weight: 50 kg She was vaccinated with Biontech for the first time in August. She passed out in the waiting room after 15 minutes, so she fainted. 3 weeks later it happened again. Ambulance was called, but in the hospital no cause could be found.Not thinking much of it at the time, she had a second vaccination in September, again Biontech. Since then - and I am not exaggerating here - she keels over several times a day, uncontrolled and absolutely randomized, and is unconscious between 10 and 30 minutes.During her unconsciousness she hyperventilates, unconsciously of course. In addition, she convulses at times, but very tentatively. For example, within 15 minutes she convulses 3 times for about 3 seconds at a time. The hyperventilating goes on for several minutes. If I keep up the same breathing speed during this, I have the feeling of suffocating.She was already 2 times over more than a week in the hospital, where the heart and the brain were examined (MRI, CT,...). Both times nothing was found. I suppose that an examination during an attack would be useful, but somehow the doctors don't seem to think so.  We have been to neurologists and family doctors besides the hospital. Even a "systematic" family doctor who prescribed some homeopathic thing.No remedy let alone diagnosis has been found yet, neither epilepsy nor narcolepsy. Nothing.Now for other aspects: - She has a headache almost continuously, but before the attacks it gets stronger - Her vision on both eyes gets worse before the attacks - She feels the left side of her body less, including her arms and legs before the attacks. - She gets dizzy before attacksShe can minimally fight it, but not for long. It can happen while lying down or standing up. But especially when she is physically exerting herself. If she lies down one evening, it is less likely to happen. If she fights it during the day, the attacks are longer and more severe in the evening.Sometimes it is right after eating or drinking - she also can no longer drink and eat large amounts at the same time. As a result, she consumes very few calories and continues to lose weight - she is already extremely thin and really should not lose any more weight.She can hardly concentrate on her studies. She can't go out by herself anymore because she could fall over at any time. The whole everyday life is insanely restricted. In principle, the disease currently dominates everything.She reacts extremely badly to medication. She can't take headache pills because they make her fall over. Even things prescribed by doctors make her faint right away. I bought carbohydrate powder - she passes out from that too.She has no mental illnesses. She is not depressed, has no anxiety, and has no mental issues with her weight or anything like that. I really can't imagine that this is psychosomatic based - especially because the connection with vaccination is so clear.  We are both absolutely not anti-vaccination and don't believe that there was anything weird in it. She even wanted to get boostered, but we are too afraid that it would get worse.We had hoped that the attacks would lessen as the vaccine effect wore off. But it seems more likely to get even worse over time.This is psychologically very stressful and also makes me afraid to go out with her because I never know in which situation I have to intervene right away. Partly she has already hit the ground while standing unchecked.We really don't know what to do. Is there anyone with experience reports on this or any kind of clue what else we could do? Any doctor, any diagnosis, any kind of remedy?She and I are both 100% aware that it can't go on like this in the long run. And she would also commit suicide at some point if it doesn't get better. And I can absolutely understand that. A normal life is impossible like that.tldr: Friend keeps keeling over uncontrolled and randomized since vaccination. After 6 months still no doctor knows why and we suffer extremely. Especially for her a normal life is no longer possible
142.answer:
I am truly sorry to hear about the difficult situation you and your girlfriend are going through. It sounds incredibly distressing and frustrating that despite seeking medical help, a diagnosis or effective treatment has not been found yet. 

Given the symptoms you have described, it is crucial that your girlfriend continues to seek medical attention from specialists who may have more experience in dealing with such complex cases. It may be helpful to seek out a neurologist who specializes in seizure disorders or a cardiologist to rule out any potential cardiac issues.

Since the symptoms seemed to have started shortly after vaccination, it could be worth exploring the possibility of post-vaccination complications or vaccine-related adverse effects. You may want to consider reaching out to local health authorities or vaccine adverse event reporting systems to report her experiences and seek guidance.

In the meantime, it may also be helpful for your girlfriend to keep a detailed journal of her symptoms, including triggers, timing, and any accompanying symptoms, to help medical professionals better understand the pattern of her condition.

Additionally, reaching out to support groups for individuals experiencing post-vaccination complications or rare health conditions may provide you both with a sense of community and resources for navigating this challenging situation.

Please know that you are not alone in this, and it is essential to continue advocating for your girlfriend's health and well-being. Stay strong, and I hope that you will find the answers and support you need to improve her quality of life.

143.question: I’m a 23 year old female. 144.question: 25f 110ish lbs Everyday smoker Cannabis use Non drinker 200mg lamotrigine 2x daily 400mg zonsimide 2x daily Refractory epilepsy of unknown origin(possibly localized but won't know until I go in for my EMU)Hello so as you can see I have refractory epilepsy and my specialist and I are talking about me begining the steps towards a surgical approach as I'm still having breakthrough seizures. 145.question: I've been receiving electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in two session, I stopped the first time due to cognitive side effects. However I started it again and I'm perplexed. 146.question: 35 yo female with history of migraines as a child. MRI, ekg totally clear.Fainted a few times which caused a visit to a neurologist who was quick to diagnose with epilepsy. No longer loosing consciousness but symptoms are still present.    Wave of “feeling ill” usually nauseous    Followed by involuntary grimacing (as if I sucked on a lemon)    Slurred or slow speech 80% of the time    Feels like my brain is swollen - but only the part of my forehead    Sometimes itchy scalp    After the episode I feel like I was hit by a truck for the next few hoursDoes this sound like a seizure? 146.answer: Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you are experiencing partial seizures, also known as focal seizures. These seizures are localized to a specific area of the brain and can cause symptoms such as involuntary movements, altered speech, and sensory abnormalities like the feeling of a swollen brain or itchy scalp. It is important to follow up with your neurologist and discuss your concerns about taking anti-seizure medication. They may be able to offer alternative treatment options or further testing to confirm the diagnosis. It is always important to advocate for your own healthcare and make informed decisions about your treatment plan.

147.question: i’m 18 years old, 5’3, i don’t take any medications, i vape and smoke weed. i do cocaine, so i was driving and i felt a weird like strain in my neck on the left side, then the left side of my face went numb. my tongue went numb and my left eye felt weird. my arm went numb too. then i pulled over and my hearing started to fade. my vision started to go black and i passed out. when i was unconscious it felt very euphoric and safe, it felt like i died. and then i woke up suddenly and took a breath and i had pissed myself. my friend with me said it looked like i was having a seizure but i had never had a seizure before. while i was at the doctor my blood sugar was normal but my blood pressure was low, my ekg was normal, the doctors took blood and said nothing was wrong. what do you guys think is wrong with me
147.answer:
It is important to note that I am a language model AI and not a medical professional. However, based on the symptoms you described, such as numbness in your face, tongue, and arm, as well as vision and hearing issues, it is possible that you experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or a mini-stroke. It is important to rule out any underlying medical causes and to ensure you receive appropriate treatment or management. Keeping a detailed journal of your symptoms, triggers, and frequency can also be helpful for your healthcare provider in making an accurate diagnosis.

149.question: My daughter is 7F, in Canada, recently diagnosed ADHD-C but not on meds yet. All vaccines up to date. She is in therapy for ADHD & anxiety management at a local kid's multidisciplinary clinic (occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, counsellors, that sort of thing.)Sleep history: she had night terrors maybe 3-4 times total during her toddler years, nothing else of note.So, after years and years of no sleep issues, my daughter has had 4 very similar "episodes" within the past 4 weeks. Here's what they look like:-episodes start <2 hours after sleep onset and seem to have distinct "phases"-phase 1: she screams for me-phase 2: she gets into a crawling position on the bed and starts violently rocking forward/back and slapping or clawing at the mattress. She'll vocalize 1-2 words or sounds as if she's trying to communicate something to me, then make a tongue clicking sound, then try again, over and over. This lasts about 1-2 minutes. She seems to be aware of my presence but can't express herself. -phase 3: she starts running to her doorway as if she's looking for something, then returning to the bed to rock and click again, though she seems more "in control" of herself than in phase 2. This lasts longer, maybe 3-5 minutes. Again, she's aware of my presence and will even talk to me sometimes.-phase 4: she stops rocking and makes a very urgent, specific, and clearly spoken request. One time, for example, it was that she desperately needed a blue marker, which she used to write "BACKE" on a poster on her wall. Another time she needed to put her blanket in the corner in the shape of a pyramid.-phase 5: once the task is completed, she is very visibly relieved, and speaking normally. She lays down again and is very twitchy/shaky. It takes her about 5 minutes to stop twitching, and then she suddenly drops asleep.-she always remembers these episodes in perfect detail the next morning. She explains it as getting a "weird" feeling in the centre of her forehead, and then she sees something in the room that isn't right, like the door frame being too small or a clone of herself standing in the room.These episodes started suddenly a few days after we returned from a trip across the country to visit family. During that visit, she had a UTI and was on 10 days of cefixime, in case that's relevant. She was always accompanied by at least one parent at all times during the trip and we didn't notice any oddness in her behaviour.Daytime behaviour is mostly normal, though she is sometimes very tired when she wakes up, and that doesn't seem connected to these episodes.We've been treating this like some sort of sleepwalking manifestation of anxiety, but I'm starting to question myself. Does this description raise any flags that suggest we should be looking into other possibilities or getting her in to see a doctor?
149.answer:
It sounds like your daughter's episodes are quite concerning and could potentially be a sign of a more serious underlying issue. While it's always a good idea to consider anxiety and stress as potential triggers for sleep disturbances, the specific nature of these episodes may warrant further investigation.

Given that these episodes started suddenly after a trip and a UTI, it may be worth discussing these symptoms with your daughter's healthcare provider. It's possible that there could be a neurological or sleep disorder at play, especially if these episodes continue to occur.

Some possible conditions to consider could include sleep disorders such as parasomnias (e.g., sleepwalking, night terrors) or even seizure disorders. A thorough evaluation by a healthcare provider, possibly a pediatric neurologist, may be helpful in determining the underlying cause of these episodes.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to keep a detailed log of your daughter's episodes, including any potential triggers, frequency, and any other relevant information. This information can be valuable in helping healthcare providers better understand the nature of these episodes and come up with an appropriate treatment plan.

Overall, if you have any concerns about your daughter's sleep disturbances, it's always best to consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation and guidance.

150.question: 26F I'm currently talking 30mg citalopram for depression and anxiety, it definitely helps with anxiety but my depression is just getting worse. At first I thought it was due to my other health issues but I think it's from increasing dose of citalopram?? Can SSRIs make you more depressed? I've been taking it for around 4-6 months.I've been trying to get a GP appointment for a week but they're always booked up (I'm in the UK) so I'm tempted to just stop taking it until I can get one and change meds but not sure if this is safe? Maybe more safe than slowly becoming suicidalAlso I'm not sure what antidepressants to try next, I'm currently taking topirimate 50mg bidaily (hoping to increase this or might be swapping to another epilepsy med for my myoclonic jerks) so any med that has twitching as a possible side effect is a no. Also want to avoid anything that will make me tired, I have fatigue.I've tried Sertraline and fluoxetine in the past, I tried mirtazapine. Would amitripyline be a bad combo with topirimate cause I know they're both used for migraines too?
150.answer:
I'm sorry to hear that you're struggling with your depression despite taking citalopram. It is possible for SSRIs like citalopram to initially worsen symptoms of depression before improvements are seen. It's important to talk to your GP before making any changes to your medication, as abruptly stopping citalopram can lead to withdrawal symptoms and potentially worsen your symptoms.

When you do speak with your GP, you can discuss your concerns about citalopram and explore other possible antidepressant options. Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that is sometimes used for depression and migraines, but it may not be the best option for you given your current medications and symptoms.

Your GP can give you guidance on which antidepressant might be a good fit for you, taking into consideration your current medications and medical history. They may also be able to provide support and additional resources to help manage your depression.

In the meantime, it's important to reach out for support if you're feeling suicidal or overwhelmed. You can contact a mental health helpline or seek help from a therapist or counselor. Take care of yourself and prioritize your mental health during this time.

151.question: Age 5 Sex male Height 40” Weight40lb Racewhite Duration of complaint 20 months Location Colorado, USA Any existing relevant medical issues CP, epilepsy Current medications Generic keppra 2.5mg/ml 2x daily My 5 yo son with CP and epilepsy My kid is amazing and funny and smart. We learned of a perinatal stroke he had between 28-32 weeks. He was born at 33 weeks, 3 days (twin A). He has left hemiplegia, is legally blind, ambulatory, talks, etc.On 4/30/19, he had a blow out focal seizure that generalized. He was stabilized by EMS with Versed and is now on a daily generic Keppra dose that is controlling seizure activity and is doing great. He’s wonderful. I’m so proud of him. He’s such an incredible human being. The thing is, I can’t seem to get over this looming threat of another generalized seizure. I have rescue meds, I’m with he and his his twin sister all the time, but I’ve lost all sense of calm since this event. I can’t sleep through the night without checking on him repeatedly (he’s actually sleeping in our room since it happened). I have motion and sound activated cameras all over my home, as he isn’t a great fit for most seizure detecting devices. I am so worried I’m ruining his life by being so caught up in this FEAR of another big seizure. I am scared all the time. I want him to be happy. I don’t want him to stop speaking to me when he turns 18 because I am such an annoying, overbearing mom. I want him to have privacy. With COVID, I’ve gotten even more protective. We really don’t go anywhere anymore. We’ve ceased all in person therapies and remotely attend school, as I’m so scared of a fever triggering a seizure. We were hiking a lot this summer, but all the trails in my area are very busy, and we just couldn’t continue risking it. Any ped neuros/epileptologists out here, please give me some feedback. What is the likelihood of him having a breakthrough seizure out of nowhere? How can I get past this and let him just be a kid? If the seizure occurred because of his brain injury from the stroke, will it always remain controlled with the Keppra, or can that change, too? FWIW, his twin sister is also incredible and hilarious, kind and wondrous.
151.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about the challenges you are facing with your son's health. It is completely understandable that you are feeling anxious and worried about the possibility of another seizure. It is important to remember that epilepsy can be unpredictable, but with the right medication and management, many individuals are able to live fulfilling lives with minimal seizures.

The likelihood of your son having a breakthrough seizure can vary depending on his individual case and medical history. It is important to work closely with his pediatric neurologist and epilepsy specialist to monitor his condition and adjust his medication as needed. They will be able to provide more specific information about the likelihood of future seizures and the best ways to manage them.

It is also important to prioritize your own mental health and well-being. It is natural to feel overwhelmed and stressed when caring for a child with complex medical needs, but it is important to find ways to manage your anxiety and find support. Consider reaching out to a therapist or support group for parents of children with epilepsy.

In terms of letting your son be a kid and allowing him to have privacy, it is important to find a balance between keeping him safe and allowing him to explore and experience the world. It is okay to take precautions, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, but try to find ways to gradually reintroduce activities and experiences that are important for his development and happiness.

Overall, communication with your son's medical team, prioritizing your own mental health, and finding a balance between safety and independence are key in navigating the challenges of caring for a child with epilepsy. Remember that you are doing the best you can for your son, and it is okay to ask for help and support when needed.

152.question: I’m an 18 year-old male senior in high school (155 lbs, 6’0”) that has been dealing with a life-altering medical condition for what I presume to be most of my life.I’m not sure exactly when it started, but the best way I thought I could explain what I have endured and my journey through it would be starting with my symptoms. Every couple of seconds, I presume in conjunction with blood flow to my head, I get a sensation of “blanking out” almost like the entirety of my brain shuts down for a split second. If I were to look at an object for an extended period of time, every couple of seconds I would slightly lose focus of it and have to reorient myself to it, which when applied in a broader sense makes everything from my perspective seem less grounded and real. I’ve had people watch my eyes and tell me that they don’t move, so I don’t know exactly where this is coming from. Additionally, it’s almost like I cant keep track of too much at the same time because I feel like I am constantly losing focus. This affliction has affected nearly every aspect of my life, from academics, socializing, and self-acceptance in ways that you can’t imagine. It feels as if I am a fragmented version of my true self, which is just awful.I’m an effort to resolve this issue, I’ve tried nearly everything that I could think of. First I tried changing my diet. Nothing. Then my sleep and exercise habits. Nothing. Then ensuring I get every single possible vitamin or mineral that I could possibly be deficient in. Nothing. Then I went to a chiropractor for speculation that it could be an issue related to my neck. Nothing. My parents put me on anti depressants and ADD medications because as a result of my issue I exhibit some symptoms of ADD. They made me feel a little funky, but didn’t fix or change the issue at all. I went to a psychiatrist who just dismissed what I had was all in my head, and a therapist who was helpful for other aspects of life but could not offer any advice for my affliction. I convinced my parents to let me go see another chiropractor that specialized in upper cervical adjustments, as that’s what I thought could be the underlying key after all this time. After half a year of doing that, the best that it could offer was inconsistent slight alleviation of my symptoms. From this I thought that maybe I could get at least some relief from self massage and muscle release of my upper neck and head area, so I attempted probably hundreds of different stretches and exercises from every corner of the web to release any possible muscle tension or tightness that could be leading to this. Nothing. That is until about a week ago, when I noticed something peculiar when messing around with my tmj joint. If I open my jaw wide, go behind the joint right on the front of my left ear, move up to where I feel two bones connect, and push in to try to separate them for about a minute, I get a moderate amount of temporary relief. When I do this, I also get a strange warm and liquidy sensation in that joint, as well as being able to feel the blood flow from some blood vessel connected there to the inside of my head near the left far end of my mouth. The relief only lasts around 15-45 minutes, and sometimes if I push too hard my cheeks feel worse and my mental state becomes even weirder, but for some reason out of every single thing that I’ve tried this is the only maneuver that works consistently.Throughout the years I have gotten an MRI of my head, an MRA of my head, and an MRI of my cervical spine that have all supposedly come back normal, which makes no sense to me because my symptoms and sensations are reality.I’m wondering if I could possibly have an issue with a subdued artery that runs near my tmj joint that could be doing weird things to blood flow to my brain, because honestly that’s what it feels like is happening. The constant change and fluctuation in my mental status and capabilities has nearly driven me to the edge, and that coupled with what I know I could be capable of if I didn’t have such an affliction makes me horribly depressed and dare I say slightly suicidal.I know this is quite a handful and seems outright crazy and confusing from an outside perspective, but I am going again to a doctor this week to describe in detail my symptoms and how I can partially remedy them, so any insight or advice from a doctor on here on what could possibly be the cause of this or what to bring up with her would be highly appreciated. EDIT: Thank you guys for all your responses, I’ll make sure to bring up a lot of the possibilities with my physician. Even though I still don’t know the exact root cause it is incredibly relieving to know that other people are willing to offer their ideas and help after it feeling like me against the world for so long.
152.answer:
It sounds like you have been through a lot trying to figure out the cause of your symptoms. I am not a doctor, but it is important to keep advocating for yourself and seeking out medical professionals who are willing to listen to your experiences and try to help you find a solution.

It is possible that your symptoms could be related to a vascular issue, such as a problem with blood flow to the brain. It may be worth discussing this possibility with your doctor and asking if any further tests or evaluations could be done to investigate this.

In the meantime, continuing to explore self-management techniques that provide temporary relief, such as the jaw manipulation you discovered, can be helpful in managing your symptoms. It is also important to continue to seek support for your mental health and well-being, as dealing with a chronic and debilitating condition can take a toll on your emotions.

Remember that you are not alone in this journey, and there are people who are willing to support you and help you find answers. Keep advocating for yourself and seeking out medical professionals who are willing to listen and work with you to find a solution.

153.question: Female, 40, has a history of seizures but not since 2011, after surgery,  Can you feel a seizure in your head? Google says it goes from your head to other parts of your body, but could someone feel it happen inside their head? Why don't all seizures show up on eeg? Is it possible to not notice or feel having a seizure but suddenly have the feeling like you had one? If there is an article that explains all this, I would love to read it. Thanks in advance!
153.answer:
It is possible for someone to feel a seizure happening inside their head, as seizures can manifest in various ways depending on the individual and the type of seizure. Some people may experience sensations such as tingling, pressure, or a sense of disorientation in their head before a seizure spreads to other parts of the body. 

Not all seizures show up on an EEG because the brain activity during a seizure can be localized and may not always be detected by the electrodes on the scalp. Additionally, some types of seizures, such as absence seizures, may not produce significant changes in brain activity that are detectable on an EEG.

It is also possible for someone to not notice or feel a seizure happening but later experience symptoms or sensations that could be related to a seizure. This could be due to various factors such as the type of seizure, the individual's awareness or consciousness during the seizure, and other underlying medical conditions.

I recommend consulting with a healthcare provider or neurologist for further information and guidance on seizures and their effects. Additionally, you may find helpful information in articles or publications from reputable sources such as medical journals or epilepsy foundations.

154.question: Hey all, I am a 30 yo white male. I am currently 270 pounds and 5'9. Active and fairly healthy. Meds: Keppra (1000mg x2 daily, Prozac 40mg 1x Daily, Clonazepam .5mg x2 daily, Meloxicam 15mg 1x daily, Fish Oil, Vitamin D, Vitamin C Supplements) I had mono when i was 17 that developed into GBS. I had weakness, druken gate, and slurred speech and my main symptoms. Symptoms resolved in approx. 6 months and i was going back to normal. Shortly there after i started with seizures, one in November 2009, again in February 2010. I have been on Keppra since and been seizure free. I also have auto immune disease. One diagnosed, Hidradenitis Supperativa (doing well), and one undiagnosed. The undiagnosed one is more recently been bothering me.. i have Episcleritis and joint pain.. High ESR and CRP in the blood. I am worried about covid and want the vax but am afraid because i had a neurological reaction to the flu shot after my GBS. My Neurologist is insisting i get the vax and im talking to my Rheumi tomorrow. Is there anybody who can give me insight on what i should consider? Thank you!
154.answer:
It's understandable that you have concerns about getting the COVID-19 vaccine given your history of neurological reactions to the flu shot after GBS. It's important to discuss your concerns with your healthcare providers, including your neurologist and rheumatologist.

It's possible that they may recommend a particular vaccine based on your medical history and current health status. They may also suggest taking precautions before and after receiving the vaccine to monitor for any potential adverse reactions.

Ultimately, the decision to get the COVID-19 vaccine is a personal one and should be based on the advice of your healthcare providers and your own risk assessment. It's important to weigh the risks and benefits of getting vaccinated in your specific situation.

Remember that the COVID-19 vaccine has been shown to be safe and effective for the majority of people, but it's important to have a conversation with your healthcare team to determine the best course of action for you.

155.question: Medical professionals are calling my bf's symptoms panic attacks, but I'm convinced he needs a neurologist. I'm a research scientist in mental health (i.e. not a doctor), and my gut keeps telling me something is very wrong. What do you think?Bf is currently experiencing “panic attacks” that he barely remembers after they finish. They last 3-6 hours, occur on more than half of the days in a week, and are characterized by extreme anxiety and neurological symptoms such as loss of balance, slurred and slowed speech, mental confusion, memory loss, rapid eye saccades side to side, fainting, and vomiting.Background: He has a history of childhood abuse and neglect and in general hasn't seen doctors in his lifetime. Before this started, he had no known conditions but did have a history of anxios and depressive symptoms since adolescence. He's of south asian descent, 5'10, aprox 150lbs, is on 100mg of lyrica, smokes nicotine (~10 cigarettes a day), 4-7 drinks a week, no other drug use. Early 2021 - Symptoms begin: He started losing his balance and slurring his speech in the last year, usually either after something extremely stressful (covid and unemployment really got to him) combined with having a beer or two. I thought it was his alcohol tolerance changing with age, so I wasn't too worried. He had several bad falls because of this, broke his glasses twice, needed stitches, etc... stressful but not concerning.  June 2021 - Symptoms worsen: He finally got a job in April, he was super happy. It was a bit stressful and outside his field and had a huge learning curve, but he loved it. But he started losing his balance and slurring his speech more often, even when he hadn't had a drop of alcohol. He also started having full blown panic attacks, where he couldn't breathe, would vomit repeatedly, thought he was dying... I used grounding and breathing techniques to help him through July 2021 - Psychiatric emergency room: In early July, he couldn't keep food down for 6 days straight and alternated crying and panic attacks. The slurred speech and loss of balance continued. I took him to psychiatric emergency in my city where he was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder and put on a low dose (25mg) of seroquel/quetiapine. He was put on sick leave from his job. He was matched with a local psychiatrist, so switched him from seroquel to 50 mg lyrica (gabapentin pregabalin~~)~~ that eventually increased to 150mg. August 2021 - Regular emergency room: Worst night. After feeling suicidal for the first time in years, he suddenly crashed face first into our shoe rack. Busted his nose open, black eye, full shebang. He was on his back and semi conscious, and couldn't speak. No asymmetry in smile etc but 911 operator and ambulance both suspected a stroke. He got carried out on a stretcher, down the stairs, rushed to ER, and kept for 2 days. He doesn't remember any of this except waking up in the hospital (but he was conscious and speaking/attempting to speak). MRI negative for stroke, EEG negative for seizure, bloodwork normal. Given one dose of ativan, discharged, told it was "bad anxiety", and to keep seeing his psychiatrist. Sept 2021-present: medical incompetence??? : He saw his psychiatrist 3 days after he was released from the ER. Doc kept him on Lyrica 150 and said ER wasn't concerning since all tests were normal. Asks why bf doesn't want to go back to work yet/is reluctant to extend sick note. Doc refuses to put him on waitlists for therapy, other modalities at the psychiatric hospital, etc... because it's "not that bad". My bf quit his job last week, since he faints at least weekly, vomits 2-3 times a week, and gets these "panic attacks" every other day at least (we're currently on day 4 of a long storm). Second appointment was Tuesday. Doc decided to lower lyrica to 100mg (???) and prescribed Silexan, a lavender oil extract(?!?!?!) available from natural food stores. Not available to buy in my country. No pharmacist near us has heard of it. Doc still refuses to do anything else and outright refused ativan when my bf asked for it because it's "not serious enough". Next appointment is in over a month. Bf was on the floor half an hour ago and unable to get up. Where I'm stuck: We're stuck in a loop of "well, he has a doctor, so go see him" whenever we consult a nurse, ER, clinic, etc... and a doctor that isn't taking this seriously. We're in Canada (Quebec) with no family doctor and current doc and er won't refer to a neurologist. We've tried putting in a doctor change request but in a strained system it's not going through. I've reached out to work colleagues within mental health research and they can't help/shuttle him in anywhere. Bf is struggling with feeling suicidal/like a burden and I'm scared all the time
155.answer:
It is understandable that you are feeling frustrated and concerned about your boyfriend's symptoms. Given the severity and complexity of his symptoms, it may be beneficial to seek a second opinion from a different medical professional, such as a neurologist or a different psychiatrist. It is important to advocate for your boyfriend's health and well-being, as his current symptoms are impacting his daily life and causing significant distress.

If possible, try reaching out to other healthcare providers or hospitals in your area to see if they can provide a different perspective or referral to a specialist. Additionally, you may want to consider seeking help from a patient advocacy organization or mental health support group that can offer guidance on navigating the healthcare system and obtaining the care your boyfriend needs.

It is also crucial to ensure that your boyfriend has a support system in place, whether it be through therapy, counseling, or community resources. Encouraging open communication and seeking help from mental health professionals can also help address any underlying issues that may be contributing to his symptoms.

Overall, it is important to prioritize your boyfriend's health and well-being, and not hesitate to seek alternative opinions or support if you feel that his current treatment plan is not addressing his needs adequately.

156.question: My son- 2.5 year old M, 3 feet tall, 35 lbs, takes 1.5ml Keppra 2x/day- diagnosed with generalized epilepsy in December and taking keppra since then- had mri under sedation in Feb and found a significant Chiari malformation (normal cerebellar tonsils are 3-5 mm, his are 15)- they say the chiari and epilepsy are not related though it seems like quite a coincidence to me. Thoughts??
156.answer:
I'm not a medical professional, but I can try to provide some information based on what you have shared. 

Chiari malformations are structural defects in the cerebellum, which is the part of the brain that controls balance. While it is possible for someone to have both epilepsy and a Chiari malformation, it is important to note that they are considered separate conditions with different causes. 

In some cases, Chiari malformations can cause symptoms such as headaches, neck pain, and balance problems. However, not all individuals with Chiari malformations will have symptoms or require treatment. 

It is possible that the Chiari malformation was present before your son was diagnosed with epilepsy, and it was only discovered during the MRI in February. It may be worth discussing your concerns about the potential relationship between the Chiari malformation and epilepsy with your son's healthcare provider. They will be able to provide more information and guidance based on your son's specific medical history and needs. 

It is important to continue working closely with your son's healthcare team to monitor his epilepsy and Chiari malformation and to ensure he is receiving appropriate treatment and support.

157.question: This is going to be a long post, I also copy pasted it from my previous post on a different forum which I used because I thought this forum was taken down. Im not sure if that's ok.I (m24) have had episodes of sudden double vision which lasts approximately 40 minutes each time for 5 years. I am responsive and coherent during episodes. They are usually a few grouped together within 2 weeks of each other and no more than 10 'episodes' a year.This is something I have seen many doctors, including neurologists, for ever since it began and have never gotten solid answers.Things ruled out by medical professionals and lab tests are: epilepsy  migraines   vertigo    brain masses  scar tissue in brain  eye diseases  blood sugar problems  blood pressure   medication levels Through my own observations by recording and testing things during episodes I have also found that it has no correlation with dehydration  eye appearance (pupil size, placement and no involuntary eye movement)  blood sugar  temperatures  foods or caffeine time of day   medications  body position (standing, sitting, laying down, walking)    eye fatigue smoking (happened both before I started smoking and after) finally realized I will start feeling slightly disoriented about 5-10 minutes before it starts. When the double vision starts, moving around promotes more dizziness but only because my eyes can't focus. If I am sitting down or keeping my head level there will still be feeling of mild disorientation and double vision but no dizziness. These episodes last almost exactly 40 minutes every time (I set a stopwatch when they start.) with the longest edging closer to an hour.  I started having peripheral neuropathy involving both arms and both legs early this year but after blood tests we found out I had severe vitamin D deficiency. After high doses of Vitamin D this completely went away and I was hoping the double vision would also go away (because most of the episodes happen between september and april, lower light months). But unfortunately it's still happening.Again I am left anxious and concerned because the episodes just came back. A notable episode happened recently when the double vision was significantly worse than ever before and went away when I used only one eye (it used to happen no matter which eye I looked through or if I used both.). It made the double vision go from a noticeable but slight 'distance' between the two versions I see, to double vision that showed stuff separate up to 3 inches apart. I don't drive so it's no danger to myself or others but when I'm walking it makes it hard to make out things like stoplights or to be able to look side to side to check for cars without feeling like I will fall. Just knowing it might start at any moment is so terrible.I have looked this up and talked to doctors about it so much over the past 5 years and I just want to know if there are any other reasons these might be happening or advice about what to do.I forgot to mention I did have a few minor concussions as a kid. 3 notable ones were when i broke my nose falling directly on my face with some confusion, the back of my head going through drywall and a hit against the back of my head where i may have blacked out for a second. No puking or memory loss after any and no need to see a doctor. and A benzo overdose a year before first episode with no short memory for 3 days (i was medically cleared afterwards and it caused no other issues) Thats why they were looking for possible scar tissue in my brain.The peripheral neuropathy mentioned came back. My vitamin D levels came back normal and my doctor checked my parathyroid hormone levels because of it and those also came back normal. She's suggesting neuro again but I probably won't schedule unless something gets worse or something new happens bc specialty appointments are expensive.
157.answer:
It sounds like you have been through a lot with trying to figure out the cause of your double vision episodes. It's frustrating when you have seen multiple doctors and still don't have a clear answer. 

Given your history of minor concussions and the fact that the double vision episodes started after a benzo overdose, it may be worth considering seeing a neurologist again. They may be able to conduct more specialized tests or imaging to further investigate any possible brain injury or neurological issues that could be causing your symptoms. 

In the meantime, keeping track of your symptoms, triggers, and any changes in your vision can be helpful for the doctor to have a more complete picture of what you are experiencing. It's also important to continue following up with your primary care doctor and any specialists to monitor your overall health and address any new symptoms that may arise. 

Overall, it's important to advocate for yourself and seek out the care and support you need to address your concerns and find answers. Don't hesitate to seek out medical help if your symptoms worsen or if you have any new symptoms that concern you. I hope you are able to find some answers and relief soon.

158.question: My little brother has random faint spells (or mini epileptic attacks, we are not sure). We want to help him lose weight as that alone would improve his quality of life by itself but the biggest issue we have is that he falls very frequently and he is very heavy. Up until now every fall he has had has not resulted in a major injury thankfull but its bound to happen. I was wondering. Is there a cage/walker product that allows us to take him on walks and would catch him via a harness should he fall? This walker/cage bungee cord contraption would have to be able to hold the sudden shock of 250 lbs of deadweight when he has his faint spells. Please let me know if you know of such a device or what the name is.
158.answer:
I recommend consulting with a medical professional or physical therapist to discuss your brother's specific needs and find the best solution for his situation. They may be able to recommend a type of walker or mobility aid that can help support him and prevent falls, or provide guidance on possible adjustments to existing equipment to make it more secure.

In terms of specific products, there are a variety of mobility aids available on the market that can provide added support and stability during walks. These can include rollators with built-in seats or harness systems for added security. You may also want to look into products specifically designed for individuals with conditions such as epilepsy or balance issues.

Ultimately, safety should be the top priority, so it's essential to find a solution that can effectively support your brother's weight and provide the necessary protection in case of a fall.

159.question: 26f. 122lbs, 5'2". Never smoker, rare drinker. On medication (trokendi, fycompa, Yaz, pristiq, creon, Cymbalta, b12 injections, pepsid, abilify). History of epilepsy, migraines, chronic pancreatitis status post tp/ait.Went to ED for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that was unremitting for weeks. Had abdominal CT that found incidental liver lesions. Followed up with an MRI with contrast. The below are the findings in my liver. Hpw should I interpret? Is it something to worry about?"There are multiple (at least 7) arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, which are hyperintense on T2 and without internal fat. The dominant lesion measures 1.8 cm and seen in segment 6 of the right lobe (29:67). A few other prominent lesions include 6 mm segment 6 (29:47), 8 mm segment 5 (29:40), and 3 mm segment 2 (29:30). No definite washout however the lesions appear to enhance less then background vessels on delayed phases, arguing against hemangioma.Multiple arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, largest measuring up to 1.8 cm in segment 6 of the right lobe. Imaging features suggest adenoma with the differential including focal nodular hyperplasia."
159.answer:
I am not a doctor, but based on the findings of your MRI, it appears that you have multiple arterially enhancing lesions in your liver. The largest lesion is measuring 1.8 cm and is in segment 6 of the right lobe. The imaging features suggest that these lesions could be adenomas, with focal nodular hyperplasia also being a possibility.

It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss these findings and determine the best course of action. They may recommend further testing or monitoring to better understand the nature of these lesions and decide on the appropriate treatment plan. It is always best to consult with a medical professional for a proper interpretation and personalized guidance.

160.question: Hello. This is about my wife who is 19F. Non smoker. Non vaper. No medical issues. No history of epilepsy in her family. I would like to highlight main parts of this inquiry. Not going into too much detail unless required by someone.My wife (19) first time pregnant had an emergency C section at 36 weeks due to breech. Baby passed away. She was fine. Had some headaches and after 6 days at home she felt blurry vision and after about 20 mins got her first seizure ever. Got 2nd one in the ambulance and after reaching hospital had 3 more.In the hospital they performed another spinal tap for her CSF (Lumbar puncture) and MRI. All tests etc were good. MRI suggested some activity in the front part of her brain. But doctors couldn't pinpoint anything. They concluded that it must have happened due to her previous spinal anesthesia for c section which is rare but not impossible.She was discharged 12 days later with Phenytoin medicine for epilepsy. 300mg per day (3 tablets all together) for 3 months. It has been a month and half (or less) and she had no seizure but some strange observations I had about her: Very sensitive to light especially when very sleepy or waking up.She had blurry vision again but partially and in one eye. One day she had in both eyes.e become a deep sleeper and it becomes really hard to wake her up. She would sleep for about 7 to 9 hours and wake up only if we woke her up. When I discussed these observations with the doctor he told me to decrease dosage to 200mg per day. Almost 2 weeks now since lowering her dosage. She has developed this strange itching all over her body that prevents her from sleeping since 3 to 5 days. She also felt her hand vibrate or shake for 2 to 3 secs while sleeping. oday she said that she felt her whole right side of the body vibrate a little and after that her right arm. She seems normal for the most part. No slurred speech, just that she forgot some of the things before seizures and also her journey from home to hospital. So is she at risk of getting seizures again? I am too damn afraid. Even when she itches the whole bed vibrates the same way it did when she had her seizure and this thing keeps me on my toes at all times. I also read that the itching can be due to some neurological issues and I think it might be Multiple sclerosis??
160.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your wife's difficult situation. It's understandable that you're feeling worried and concerned about her health. It sounds like her doctors have been proactive in investigating her symptoms and adjusting her medication accordingly.

It's important to continue to communicate with her healthcare providers about any new or unusual symptoms she may be experiencing. It's possible that the itching and other symptoms she's experiencing could be related to her medication or could be a sign of another underlying issue. Multiple sclerosis is a possibility, but it would be best to discuss this with her doctors and possibly consider further testing or evaluation if necessary.

In terms of her risk of having seizures again, it's difficult to predict with certainty. Seizure disorders can be complex and vary from person to person. It's important for her to continue taking her medication as prescribed and to follow up with her healthcare providers regularly to monitor her condition.

In the meantime, try to support your wife and encourage her to rest and take care of herself as best as she can. Remember to take care of yourself as well, as caring for a loved one during a challenging time can be emotionally taxing. Don't hesitate to reach out for support or additional guidance if needed.

161.question: Every so often I get these really weird sensations that feel somewhat neurological that I haven't a clue what they are since they seem so different from anything else I know of. I've been getting them occasionally for over a year now. 25F. I just had one now and it leaves me in such a weird state of mind afterwards.I feel somewhat floaty and dizzy currently, so please forgive me if this isn't constructed well.It begins as a tingling sensation? Like a shiver. That flushes through me. And I feel some kind of emotion that I can't describe, like dread or deja vu or some kind of combination of the two. I become hyperaware of my sorroundings, like reality has become more real? It's very abstract and weird, I know. I usually forget the specifics of these sensations; but I've written them down previously while experiencing them so I can repeat these now. Afterwards, accompanied by a light headache that goes away fairly quickly.(Very, very rarely I get migraines with a visual aura, but this experience is completely different.)I'm really dizzy/floaty this time around and I'm not sure why. It has been a while since it happened; I thought it had stopped happening. It passes after some time and doesn't seem to negatively affect me, though it's very difficult to maintain a conversation or writing while it's happening. I don't think I've ever been this dizzy thoughNo other diagnoses, no medication, or anything else. I don't know how long the shivering phase lasts, but I think its under a minute. The dizziness is fading a little now, and I think its been about 10 minutes, though I have a light headache.
161.answer:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a type of neurological phenomenon called an aura. Auras are sensory disturbances that can occur before a migraine or as a standalone experience. They can include symptoms such as tingling sensations, visual disturbances, and changes in perception. It's important to note that auras can vary widely from person to person and may not always be recognized as related to migraines.

If you continue to experience these sensations, it may be a good idea to speak with a healthcare provider to rule out any underlying medical conditions and to explore potential treatment options. Keep track of when these episodes occur and any possible triggers that may be associated with them. This information can be helpful in identifying patterns and potential causes.

In the meantime, try to stay calm and rest if needed during these episodes. Stay hydrated and try to maintain a healthy lifestyle to help manage any potential triggers. Take care of yourself and reach out for support if needed.

162.question: I’m 22F. So in 2017 I was diagnosed with epilepsy after a full-tonic (like a stereotypical?) seizure having had myoclonic seizures constantly for like 2 years before then. No one took me seriously until the major one. During the diagnosis and since, I was constantly asked to describe what I NOW know are myoclonic seizures, but no one ever said they were. I was on Lamotrigine (around 100mg morning and night) until 2020, then was on Keppra (500mg morning and night). In 2021 I was told that since i hadn’t had a seizure in over 3 years I could stop medication (which wasn’t actually true- I hadn’t had a full on seizure in over 3 years but I still had myoclonic ones when having sleeping problems but no neurologist seemed to understand that they were seizures?). The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. From May 2022 I was absolutely fine with zero issues at all. Then one night in September, I was only able to sleep 2 hours and had dozens of myoclonic seizures until I had a full on seizure. Completely out of the blue. I was then put on 250mg Keppra morning and night but the new neurologist prescribed Lamotrigine…but only 25mg every morning. I was fine on 500mg Keppra/day but then ran out in October and hadn’t been told how to make the switch, so I just replaced the meds. In the days right after, I’d have a small myoclonic seizure while trying to fall asleep but I thought I was just trying to adjust. A few days later though, I woke up (after minimum 6 hours of sleep) and had dozens of myoclonic seizures only seconds apart and I spent hours trying to fight off a major seizure. After a few hours break we went to A&E because I was begging for meds I wasn’t prescribed. They just said to take 25mg Lamotrigine at night so I immediately did. When I went to bed the constant myoclonic seizures resumed from midnight until 5-6am. All day/night I thought I’d have to end my life rather than go more days like this. The next few days got gradually better and the pharmacists were horrified I was prescribed so badly. But ever since then, I have been on 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra morning then 1g Keppra at night and regularly have myoclonic seizures while trying to fall asleep so have to take Clobazam. Sorry for the novel, but why has everything gone so downhill?? If it makes a difference, I have a history of quite intense mental health issues though never formally diagnosed (not my fault lol). 100% have depression and anxiety (don't know if it borders on panic), think I had BPD, have had major eating problems (binge/restricting), used to think I had ADD, suspect I could be vaguely on the autism spectrum. Not sure which suspicions have been correct lmao. EEG RESULTS - I wasn't sent the literal results, only the documents. They're in French which isn't my first language so I'll TRY to translate but will include the original French (unless it's obvious) to be safer. Thank you!! Base rhythm/rythme de base : alpha, distribué de façon symétrique. stable fuselé 9 Hz /alpha, symmetrical distribution, stable taper (?) 9 Hz Alpha activity: normal Activité delta : irrégulière fronto-temporale bilatérale occasionnelle / Delta activity: irregular fronto-temporal bilateral occasionally Theta activity/Activité thêta: absent Stop reaction/Réaction d’arrêt : normal Fast rhythms/rhythmes rapides: bi-frontal, non reactive Paroxysm (?? no clue)/Paroxysme: absent Photostimulation reaction: normal (no reaction) Hyperventilation reaction: normal (no reaction) Conclusion: foyer de ralentissement localisé fronto-temporal bilatéral intermittent. Absence d'anomalies épileptiformes franches. / no clue how to translate foyer in this context but intermittent slowness localised in the bilateral fronto-temporal. Absence of epiletiform(??) anomalies. PRIL 2022 (when I stopped meds, also most recent EEG since before the chaos): Base rhythm: alpha, symmetrically distributed. Stable taper(?). Alpha activity: 9 Hz Delta activity: absent Theta activity: absent Stop reaction: normal Fast rhythms: bifrontaux, non reactifs/bi-frontal, non reactive Paroxysm/paroxysme: absent Reaction to photostimulation: normal (no reaction) Reaction to hyperventilation: not tested Conclusion: normal exam
162.answer: It sounds like you have been through a lot with your epilepsy diagnosis and medication changes. It is concerning that you have experienced a decline in your seizure control despite being off medication for some time. It may be worth discussing with your neurologist about potentially increasing your medication dosage or trying different medications to better control your seizures. Additionally, it is important to address your mental health issues and seek support from a healthcare professional to ensure you are getting the appropriate treatment and management for your depression, anxiety, and other concerns. The EEG results you provided seem to indicate some intermittent slowing in the fronto-temporal regions, but no clear epileptiform anomalies were detected, which is reassuring. It's important to continue working closely with your healthcare team to manage your epilepsy and overall well-being.

163.question: I, 16(AFAB)(Diagnosed with ASD, GAD, MMD, and ADHD, no physical conditions known, I don't take any medication or supplements whatsoever), have been consistently baffled by what keeps occuring. I have no idea where to look anymore, and this is honestly a last ditch effort to at least point me in the right direction.Starting when I was around 11 years old, periodically, I'd go through a "episode" of sorts where exactly half my body would become completely numb and it became difficult to communicate. When I was 12, this happened during school, and it was so bad I ended up being sent to the hospital. I believe I received an MRI among a few other tests, but ultimately, the episode was over by the time I had arrived. The doctors said I was fine and I was sent home, but since then I have had about 8 more of these episodes.When this occurs, it starts by my entire arm slowly going numb, which spreads through one side of my body, almost as if there's a line going all the way down. The weirdest part is that it's exactly half, and that includes all of that half (no joke, half my tounge and nose too) will go completely numb. Sometimes I will get an extraordinary horrible headache during this that lasts about 5 hours, which makes me incredibly sensitive to any form of light or sound. As mentioned previously, I lose the ability to communicate, but not the ability to think. I am able to recognize what my body is going through the entire time, but all that I am able to do is I suppose cry and wail. I lose the ability to speak English. Sometimes I am able to delay these episodes by doing breathing exercises, but ultimately it's only a delay, and I end up losing vision entirely for at least 15 minutes during this.I have no idea why this happens, as the circumstances are different every time. It seems to be entirely random and completely cripples me for at least 2 hours. I want to know what it is so I can research it and hopefully focus on preventing it, or at least lessening the effects.Any ideas?
163.answer:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through these episodes, they must be very distressing for you. It's difficult to say what could be causing these symptoms without more information or a full medical workup. It sounds like you have already seen a doctor about this, but it may be worth seeking a second opinion or consulting with a specialist such as a neurologist. They may be able to provide more insight and potentially offer a diagnosis or treatment plan.

In the meantime, keeping a detailed journal of when these episodes occur, what you were doing before they started, any triggers you may have noticed, and how long they last could be helpful for healthcare professionals in determining a potential cause. It's also important to prioritize self-care and stress management techniques to help reduce the frequency or severity of these episodes.

I hope you are able to find some answers and relief soon. It's important to advocate for yourself and continue seeking medical help until you find a resolution. Take care.

164.question: Age, sex: 23M Height: 5'7" Weight 80kgs Current medications: Glyciphaige SR500 for pre-diabetes, LN Bloc 20 and Moxovas 0.3 for High BP, Thyrox 62.5 for Hypothyroid.Okay so recently i was at a neuro to check if i have Myoclonic Epilepsy. I used to have these shoulder jerks that would last one second, then my whole body started moving in all directions like few months later. For some time it was fine and recently my head started jerking so i finally went to a neuro. The EEG was fine. Looking at my posture and the way i was standing the doc said I've motor tics and AD/HD. So I've been given Tetrabenazine for these movements, Clonidine for ADHD and also Clonazepam 0.25 for emergency when I'm having too many jerks. A quick look at google told me that Clonazepam is used to treat Myoclonic Epilepsy. Should i be worried about these jerks situation because apparently doc Haven't ruled out epilepsy
164.answer: It is understandable that you may be concerned about the possibility of epilepsy given your symptoms and the medication you have been prescribed. It is important to follow up with your neurologist and discuss any concerns you have about your diagnosis and treatment plan. It may be beneficial to have further discussions with your doctor about the possibility of epilepsy and how it is being managed with the current medications you are taking. Remember to communicate openly with your healthcare provider to ensure that your concerns are addressed and that you are receiving the appropriate care for your condition.

165.question: 20 y/o USA white female, 5'5" 145 lbs, currently taking Zoloft, Lamictal (as a mood stabilizer, I'm not epileptic), and have an IUD if that counts as a current med?My psychiatrist and therapist both think I might have atypical ADHD and we're trying out different meds to see if they help. My psychiatrist put me on low-dose Concerta for about 2 weeks and told me to work my way up to 3 pills as a single dose, spending a few days on 1 pill and then a few days on 2 pills and that if it felt like it was working well at a dosage below 3 pills, to just stick with that. I was having some air hunger then but not as much as I currently am. The Concerta was giving me mood swings at the dose where it started to feel like it was working (3 pills) so she decided to have me try Vyvanse instead.It's only my second day on Vyvanse and I'm no stranger to waiting out initial side effects or even to dealing with long-term side effects that suck but suck less than not being medicated for the condition but the air hunger is really getting to me.I'm a classical singer so I do know how to take legitimately full breaths and have been going through the motions of taking full breaths but still never feel like I've got a full breath. I'm not panting or something like that, I'm breathing normally, it just doesn't feel like I'm getting all the air I need. Yawning helps me feel like I got a full breath but only until the next breath and I can't just try to yawn for every breath because while the Vyvanse isn't making me constantly nauseous, it makes it way easier for me to be nauseated and if I yawn too hard too much, I get nauseous.Is there anything I can do? Like I said, I'm hoping that the air hunger will go away once my system gets more used to the Vyvanse but in the meantime I'd really love not to feel this way.
165.answer:
It's important to talk to your psychiatrist about any side effects you are experiencing with the Vyvanse. They may be able to adjust your dosage or suggest a different medication that might work better for you. In the meantime, you can try some things to help alleviate the air hunger feeling. 

One thing you can try is practicing deep breathing exercises. This can help you feel like you are getting more air with each breath. You can also try taking slow, deep breaths through your nose and exhaling slowly through your mouth. 

Another thing that might help is staying hydrated. Drinking water regularly throughout the day can help with respiratory function and may alleviate the air hunger feeling.

It's also important to make sure you are getting enough sleep and taking care of your overall health. Eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and practicing stress-reducing activities like meditation or yoga can all help improve your overall well-being.

Remember, it's important to communicate openly with your healthcare providers about any side effects you are experiencing. They are there to help you find the best treatment plan for you.

166.question: Hi. I just wanna have some guidance in advance if someone can help me :(This hadn't happened to me since March 2020. It happened again last week and sometimes I do feel a bit drowsy or weird but haven't had a full on focal seizure again.What I experienced was:Nausea I saw an aura, or like static? on my right eye that then turned into colors.   My limbs went cold I had a deja vu sensation, like I started to think things I hadn't thought of in two years?
