I don't know how to explain it I lost all peripheral vision on my right eye for a good while.Speaking was difficult Almost lost consciousness (in 2020 I did lose consciousness and moved my eyes from side to side very rapidly and my face went droopy last time). Back then I went to the ER and they couldn't find anything. Since it never happened again I didn't go see a neurologist but the other day it happened twice so I immediately booked an appointment.
166.answer:
I'm sorry to hear that you are going through this. It sounds like you may be experiencing some focal seizures. It's great that you have already booked an appointment with a neurologist. They will be able to conduct some tests and provide you with a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to keep a journal of your symptoms and any triggers you notice, as this can provide valuable information for your neurologist. It's also important to make sure you are getting enough rest, managing stress, and practicing relaxation techniques to help reduce the frequency of these episodes.

If you experience another seizure, it's important to stay safe by moving to a safe location, lying down, and turning onto your side to prevent choking. It's also a good idea to have someone with you who can help monitor your symptoms and provide assistance if needed.

I hope you get the support and guidance you need from your neurologist. Take care and best of luck on your journey to understanding and managing your condition.

167.question: I’m male, age 19, BMI currently 18.5, location: USA, my issues began at age 12 right after puberty, however, I would get moments of AIWS and vomiting in the middle of the night prior around age 7, I eat fine and have no family history of stroke or blood clot disorders, I have a healthy BMI, and my blood and heart have been tested at 12 and were fine. I think I also have non-epileptic seizures from anxiety due to the different characteristics of PNES vs ES. However, when I was 12 right after puberty, I would wake up in the middle of the night unable to understand speech and I had depersonalization, trembling, ptosis (one eyebrow or eyelid drooping usually in the morning after sleep) and sometimes blurry vision, usually accompanied by AIWS and panic attack, however, at random days I would get blurry vision easily, all these problems were usually accompanied by a food intolerance and would significantly improve a few minutes after passing stool, yet require a day or two to fully subside. Now at 19 I still get these symptoms but much more mild, after eating a food I’m intolerant to, I get slightly blurry vision and panic, then when I slept I woke up in the middle of the night with panic/depersonalization/trembling and restricted circulation and my hearing sounded a little foggy and I had slight trouble understanding words and whenever someone looks at or talks to me I panic and have to hide in my room to block out the sensory, my mouth is also numb and eating food feels weird and gives me a panic attack and then I have to go to the bathroom, after passing stool of the irritating food, the symptoms elevate significantly, I get back the feeling sensation in my mouth and body but just feel very subtly numb for the rest of the day.
167.answer:
It sounds like you have been dealing with a range of symptoms for several years, potentially related to food intolerances and anxiety. It may be helpful to keep a food diary to track which foods seem to trigger your symptoms, and consider discussing this with a healthcare provider or a registered dietitian to explore potential food sensitivities or allergies. 

Additionally, given your history of AIWS, depersonalization, and panic attacks, it may be beneficial to speak with a mental health professional to address any underlying anxiety or stress that could be contributing to your symptoms. They can help you develop coping mechanisms and strategies to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being. 

It's also important to continue monitoring your symptoms and discussing them with your healthcare provider, as they can help rule out any potential underlying medical conditions and provide appropriate treatment and support. Take care of yourself and prioritize your health and well-being.

168.question: So I was diagnosed with Epilepsy last August and put on Keppra 1000mg twice a day. I did not like how it made me feel, so they moved it to once a day. Still, at times I feel foggy....seeming almost drunk. I was wondering if this is normal or maybe I was taking it at the wrong time of day. Should I take with food? Should I take before bed? I am not on any other meds except Motrin 800 for fake hip. Please let me know what you would recommend. Thank you in advance. I am a 41 year old male, 190 pounds and not a smoker.
168.answer:
It is common for people to experience side effects from anti-seizure medications, including feeling foggy or drunk-like. It is important to talk to your doctor about any side effects you are experiencing. They may be able to adjust your dosage or try a different medication that works better for you.

In terms of when to take your medication, it is recommended to take Keppra at the same time each day to help maintain a consistent level of the drug in your system. It is generally ok to take Keppra with or without food, but if you find that taking it with food helps lessen the side effects, then that is fine to do. 

As for taking it before bed, some people find that taking anti-seizure medications at night helps them better tolerate the side effects as they sleep through them. However, it is important to consult with your doctor before making any changes to your medication regimen.

Overall, it is important to communicate openly with your healthcare provider about any side effects you are experiencing so they can help find the best treatment plan for you.

169.question: Age - 30   Sex - male    Height - 5'8"-174 cm    Weight - 60 kgs.    Duration of complaint - 3 years    Location - Soft palate    Any existing relevant medical issues - Subjective Tinnitus caused by olanzapine and an MRI scan   Current medications - Cinolazepam for sleep, Mysoline for the myoclonus. Is palatal myoclonus treatable?
169.answer:
Palatal myoclonus is a rare condition characterized by rhythmic contractions of the muscles of the soft palate. It can be quite bothersome and affect speech and swallowing. Treatment options for palatal myoclonus may include medications such as muscle relaxants, botulinum toxin injections, or surgical intervention in some cases.

Given your existing medical issues and medications, it would be best to consult with a neurologist or an otolaryngologist who specialize in movement disorders to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for your specific case. They can provide a comprehensive evaluation and discuss the potential options for managing your palatal myoclonus. Treatment may vary depending on the underlying cause of the myoclonus and individual factors.

170.question: Hi there. I was hoping someone could give me some input on an MRI view. I have access to the MRI so if anyone wants another image, I can view it. This is my most recent MRI, Jan 2021. I also have a disk with the MRI/MRA/MRV I had in 2019 History: 32F. I have a CVST in 2019 on the right side of my brain. This included my superior sagittal sinus, part of my transverse sinus, my sigmoid sinus, and then went down into my jugular. I’m heterozygous Factor V Leiden. Other than that I didn’t get any real information on the cause. I had a DVT in 2012. My eye doctor says my peripheral vision in my right eye isn’t great. I recently was diagnosed with epilepsy, being complex partial seizures that originate in my right temporal lobe. I get de ja vu, kinda black out, zone out. Sometimes I can tell when this happens, other times I have been driving and suddenly not known where I was. Apparently I clench my teeth often, and I also sometimes stutter randomly, like I’ll say “and” a bunch of times in a row for no reason. Around the time the CVST happened, I developed some symptoms that I don’t know if they’re related (but I blame stress). These include temperature regulation issues, mostly when I sleep. Sleep paralysis/some hallucinations/terrors. And insomnia, which I think is just from fear of sleep paralysis. My psychiatrist did say I was having something called exploding head syndrome, which again, I think is just me mentally being terrified to sleep and I jolt myself out of sleeping. The temperature thing includes randomly burning up or freezing, sometimes sweating. Blanket amount and house temp don’t seem to vary this. My boyfriend will either cover me in blankets or ice packs. I have passed out from the heat part if I try to get up. The cold part, I just shake and chatter. These are all ongoing. I currently take Eliquis, propranolol, Keppra, and have taken Vyvanse, Xanax, prazosin, and Ambien, all as prescribed. I stopped taking the Vyvanse about six months ago. The Xanax is occasionally, and the Ambien is rarely. I take vitamin D and a B complex. I drank occasionally but since the epilepsy diagnosis, have cut back. I don’t do any other drugs. Warfarin made me bleed insanely and Zonisamide made me extremely sick. My neurologist wants to send me to Cornell or similar and I guess I’m just trying to avoid everything with Covid going on if I can. Sorry if this post is a little wonky, I’m going on about two days of no sleep. I will try to clarify any questions. Edit: oh I’m 5’4, white, and 180lbs. I put on weight since the CVST. I was originally around 140-150lbs. I used to get severe migraines, since I was a child. I would lose vision, not be able to speak, and it felt like someone beat my head in. Since seeing my new neurologist in 2019 and being diagnosed with the CVST and medicated with Eliquis, I have rarely had migraines.
170.answer: I'm sorry to hear about all the health issues you have been dealing with. It sounds like you have been through a lot. Since you have access to your MRI images, I recommend consulting with your doctor to take a look at them and provide you with insights based on the current situation and your medical history. It would be helpful to have a medical professional analyze the images and give you the best course of action moving forward. Additionally, staying in touch with your neurologist and potentially following through with a referral to Cornell or a similar institution could provide you with more specialized care and possibly more answers to your ongoing symptoms. Take care and I wish you the best in your health journey.

171.question: This last year at the ripe age of 32 I developed a myriad of health complications. Primarily nuerological comlications such as myoclonus, seizures, and a serious case of insomnia. Thankfully I am improving now. I was in excellent former health and this came on like wildfire. For 6 months I was in and out of hospitals. I had 6 MRIs done, 4 lumbar punctures, and 7 CT scans in the span of 6 months. The majority of the diagnostics were of low clinical yield and I was empirically treated for autoimmune conditions & epilepsy. I often feel that the excessive imaging(CT) only added insult to injury. I know this is already said and done and there's nothing I can do about it now, but im hoping maybe someone with a bit of knowledge and insight on the subject could ease my nerves about cancer risk etc. Below are the scans preformed and parameters that were made available to me. Where do I stand I'm comparison to radiation workers, patients treated with radiation therapy or gamma procedures, pilots, surviovors of eratic radiation exposure etc. I want to put these worries to rest and move forward with my life. Yes it's a simple as nothing I can do now but move forward and enjoy life. I'm just hoping to hear some people who may have gone through it and shared these worries that your all ok, or for someone with a background and focus in radiation(be it medicine, physics, engineering, etc)to tell me my worries are irrational. CT scans August 16th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 1005.29 September 22nd - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 799 September 23rd - Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis Total Exam DLP: 652 September 25th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 763 November 15th - Chest/abdomen/pelvis W contrast Total Exam DLP: 1291.11 CONTRAST: 80 mL of Iohexol Inj 80 mL November 18th - Full body PET scan Total Exam DLP: A fuck load December 15th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 881.17
171.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but I can provide some general information about radiation exposure from CT scans. CT scans do expose patients to ionizing radiation, which can increase the risk of cancer in the long term. The actual risk depends on a variety of factors including the amount of radiation received, the age of the patient, and the specific body part being scanned. 

It's difficult to directly compare your radiation exposure to other groups such as radiation workers, patients receiving radiation therapy, pilots, or survivors of erratic radiation exposure. Each of these groups has different levels of exposure and radiation sensitivity. In general, the risk of cancer from a few CT scans is considered low, especially if the scans were medically necessary for your diagnosis and treatment.

It's important to discuss any concerns you have about radiation exposure with your healthcare provider. They can help assess your individual risk and provide guidance on next steps. It's also important to focus on your recovery and health moving forward. Try to stay positive and take care of yourself. Remember, worrying about the past won't change anything – focus on the present and your future wellness.

172.question: Suddenly, everywhere I look, people are touting the benefits of stimulating the vagus nerve. What is the vagus nerve, and what does it actually do? Does stimulating it actually have all these positive effects people claim? (Stimulating digestion, lowering blood pressure, helping anxiety, etc.) 35/F/white/115 pounds/sertraline/Canada. Is stimulating the vagus nerve bullshit?
172.answer:
The vagus nerve is the longest cranial nerve in the body and plays a crucial role in the functioning of many organs in the body. It is responsible for controlling the parasympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for rest and digest functions in the body. Stimulation of the vagus nerve has been shown to have various positive effects on health, including improving digestion, lowering blood pressure, reducing anxiety, and promoting overall well-being.

There is evidence to suggest that stimulating the vagus nerve can indeed have these positive effects. Methods of stimulating the vagus nerve include deep breathing, meditation, yoga, acupuncture, and devices that deliver electrical stimulation to the nerve.

While the benefits of vagus nerve stimulation are supported by research, it is important to note that it may not work for everyone and should not be considered a cure-all for all health issues. It is always best to consult with a healthcare professional before trying any new treatment or therapy.

In conclusion, while some may view the benefits of stimulating the vagus nerve as exaggerated or "bullshit," there is scientific evidence to support its positive effects on health. It may be worth exploring as a complementary therapy for various health conditions, but it is important to approach it with caution and consult with a healthcare provider.

173.question: i was diagnosed when i was young with a seizure thing that goes away when youre 13, which impairs my ability to concentrate and gave me seizures while im sleeping about once every blood moon and my mom told me it was epilepsy, but see the thing is that shes not very good with english, and i have never had any trouble with seeing flashing lights. is it possible to have epilepsy but no trouble with seeing flashing colors?
173.answer: Yes, it is possible to have epilepsy without experiencing seizures triggered by flashing lights, also known as photosensitive epilepsy. There are many different types of epilepsy and not all individuals with epilepsy are sensitive to flashing lights. It is important to seek a proper evaluation and diagnosis from a medical professional to determine the specific type of epilepsy you may have.

174.question: Does radiation necrosis heal? 31 female 155 lbs Diagnosed w/ Brain AVM & 2 aneurysms 2009. - 3 gamma knife treatments in 2019. edications: Topamax, Trileptal, Zoloft, Wellbutrin, Clonidine, Vyvanse, Vitamin D, Folic Acid & had Kyleena IUD replaced February 16th. - important because vision symptoms started could be coincidence. Shortly after I had my new iud put in I started having issues with my left eye, vision became blurry”ish” on and off. For the next 3 weeks I Had slow thought processing during the time & some confusion. - Hard time finding words. I also had some “left neglect” symptoms but that’s normal for me when I get migraines because my left side goes numb so I related all of this to stress & the migraines until I started having muscle twitching in my left hand & wrist. - I started to improve end of March but My vision is still off sometimes & I’m not as sharp as I used to be. I Had an eeg in April which showed slowing, which I feel like is normal.. but I just had a follow up MRI & this is the report.. is someone able to explain it to me? No one has ever told me I had radiation necrosis. I guess I was always under the assumption my brain would heal itself after my radiation… but 4 years later it just seems to be getting worse. Does radiation necrosis heal/is it dangerous? Could this just be swelling? Did is progress fast from January 2022-April 2023? 4.. Since I’m not getting blood flow there is it basically the same thing as a ischemic stroke? What is FLAIR hyperintensity? Those are just questions off the top of my head. I don’t see a dr until June and google is not my friend.
174.answer:
Radiation necrosis is a potential complication of radiation therapy for brain AVM and aneurysms. It occurs when healthy brain tissue is damaged by radiation treatment. While some cases of radiation necrosis can heal or improve over time, it is also possible for the condition to progress and cause ongoing symptoms.

The MRI report you received likely shows findings consistent with radiation necrosis, including FLAIR hyperintensity, which indicates areas of abnormal signal intensity in the brain. This can be a sign of inflammation or tissue damage.

It is important to follow up with your doctor in June to discuss these findings and determine the best course of action. They may recommend further imaging studies, medication adjustments, or other treatment options to help manage your symptoms and monitor for any progression of the condition.

Given your history of brain AVM and aneurysms, it is important to take any changes in symptoms seriously and seek medical attention promptly if you notice any new or worsening symptoms. Be sure to communicate your concerns and questions with your healthcare provider so they can provide you with appropriate guidance and support.

175.question: Sex: M Age 48 Weight 235lbs Height: 6ft 2" non smoker, non drinker epilepsy since birth, had his hemispheres separated about 15 years ago. Takes anti-depressant (can't remember the name) and Tegertol for seizures. I have been with my husband for 11 years, married for 10 years, so I haven't been a part of his entire journey, but I am here for the rest of it! He has been having increasing seizures in the last 7 years, and the neurologist just ups his meds. December of last year he had a big one. I had to call an ambulance because his active seizure was over 15 minutes. He stayed in a postectal state for over 5 hours. They did a CT scan, and it shows an area of calcification, and his neurologist said that is normal and unchanged.What I have noticed is that before his more major seizures, he will have a bad headache that advil or tylenol will not touch. Then a few hours later, he will have a seizure that will last between 3-5 minutes, with a postectal state ranging from 10 minutes to an hour.Is this something that can even be fixed or managed better? Is it just part of living with someone with epilepsy?
175.answer:
Living with someone with epilepsy can certainly be challenging, but there are steps that can be taken to help manage the condition and potentially reduce the frequency and severity of seizures. Here are some suggestions:

1. Ensure that your husband is taking his medication as prescribed by his neurologist. It's important to follow the treatment plan provided by his doctor, as missing doses or not taking medication as directed can increase the risk of seizures.

2. Keep a seizure diary to track when seizures occur, how long they last, and any potential triggers or warning signs. This information can be helpful in identifying patterns and working with your husband's healthcare team to adjust his treatment plan as needed.

3. Make sure your husband is getting enough rest, eating a healthy diet, and managing stress levels. These lifestyle factors can all play a role in seizure control.

4. Consider exploring alternative treatment options, such as ketogenic diet therapy, vagus nerve stimulation, or epilepsy surgery. These interventions may be recommended by your husband's neurologist if medication alone is not providing adequate seizure control.

It's important to have open and ongoing communication with your husband's healthcare team to ensure that his epilepsy is being properly managed. While epilepsy may not be "fixed," there are certainly ways to better manage the condition and improve quality of life for your husband.

176.question: i'm a caucasian 23 year old female, 5'6" 115 lbs, taking oral BC, trintellix, vyvanse, keppra, and ranitidine (yeah, i kno). things like this have been going on for as long as i can remember. other than the fact that i'm epileptic, i really don't have any other underlying physical conditions that, to my knowledge, would cause this issue. i'm not really active unless you count standing around at work all day. i don't drink, smoke, or do any illicit drugs. i vape though...shhhh.so basically, i'm having what the title says. and when i mean constant, multiple times per day, anywhere on the body, with physical exertion or without.for example, today, i reached behind me to close a damn sliding cabinet door and got a wicked charley horse in my tricep. it throbbed for a few hours after. i'll lean my body to one side, maybe to reach for something further away and i'll get horrible contractions around my neck, upper back, shoulders, you name it. from seemingly normal and not excessively exerting actions.other times, i'll be sitting cross legged in bed, looking at reddit, and out of nowhere, my foot will flip out and the muscle that runs along the tendon on the bottom of the foot will tense like crazy and i'll have to stop what i'm doing to try to relax it, because as i'm sure a lot of people know, charley horses kinda continue to contract unless you move the body part in the opposite way or whatnot.i will get painful muscle contractions ANYWHERE. i get them in my throat muscles if i swallow something funny. i'll get them in my uterus (indiscriminate to my cycle and it feels way different than menstrual cramps). i'll get them in my BUTTHOLE MUSCLES. those are absolutely horrendous because i'll be in excruciating pain for 10-30 seconds and kind of have to position myself around and hold my breath until they relax. i get them in my fingers, wrists, calves, thighs, upper and lower abdomen, pretty much anywhere there's muscle.feel free to ask any other relative questions. i'm really just looking for insight and if anyone else is familiar with something like this.
176.answer:
It sounds like you are experiencing muscle spasms and cramps throughout your body. While occasional muscle cramps are common and usually harmless, experiencing them multiple times per day all over your body may indicate an underlying issue.

Some possible causes for frequent muscle spasms and cramps can include dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, nutritional deficiencies (such as magnesium or potassium), medication side effects, or neurologic conditions.

Given that you have a history of epilepsy and are taking multiple medications, it's important to discuss your symptoms with your healthcare provider. They may want to evaluate your medications to see if any could be contributing to your muscle spasms, as well as investigate other potential causes.

In the meantime, staying hydrated, eating a balanced diet rich in essential nutrients, and gentle stretching exercises may help alleviate some of your symptoms. Keep track of when and where you experience muscle spasms to provide your healthcare provider with more information.

177.question: Age:20F Had been epileptic for 6 years but last seizure I had was 2 years ago.I have been getting this weird episodes for years now. I suddenly get a weird feeling of an attack/episode is going to happen, and then, I get this strong deja vu feeling about the situation I'm in has already happened, it sort of repeating? I suddenly get overwhelmed with fear and it comes along with panic attack. Heart palpitations, breathing problems(hyperventilation perhaps?), and then I don't really remember what happens. I'm confused after the episode about what really happened or triggered it. It last for an hour or so. It happens in sleep as well sometimes. Usually I end up sleeping after the episode since I get tired everytime it happens. Though, It affects me badly that I'm in fear all day, cause there seems to be lingering of that episode, like it's about to happen again.Yesterday I got about 5 or more episodes like that. 2 while sleeping I'm wondering if it's just because of anxiety issues(simply panic attacks) or is it related to Epilepsy? I have been taking medication once regularly- I take Levetiracetam-750
177.answer: It's possible that these episodes could be related to your epilepsy or they could be a separate issue like anxiety or panic attacks. It's important to discuss these symptoms with your doctor so they can evaluate your situation and provide you with appropriate treatment. It's possible that your medication may need to be adjusted or that you may need additional support for anxiety or panic attacks. It's always better to be proactive in addressing these concerns with your healthcare provider.

178.question: Age: 18 ex: Female Height: 150 Weight: 51kg Race: Arab Duration of complaint: a week ny existing relevant medical issues: anemia Current medications: iron pills, beef liver pills, blood building pills. original complaint  When I inhale I feel like my brain is full and nourished and healthy, but when I exhale it gradually worsens and I become very lightheaded and dizzy, I’m talking about normal breathing rates, not meditation breathing or fast rapid breathing, normal breaths.. I can’t sleep because of it, it makes my brain feel like it’s about to fall, like it’s falling, and sometimes I feel my brain vibrating, sometimes I feel an electrical feel going through my brain and moving, it feels like something is gonna happen like a seizure cause it feels like theres too much, like a sudden gush or surge of chemicals or something rushing into my brain and it’s gonna make me have a seizure or something, im not epileptic but there are times when I wake up my body is completely jerking non stop and uncontrollable, my jaw my hands, all of it, it lasts for seconds, and I can’t speak or make a voice, it’s like non stop jerking and twitching and shaking and my jaw constantly jerks along with my body, idk if this is related to what I’m feeling in my brain but iv had these “jerks” since a long time
178.answer: It's important to note that the symptoms you are experiencing are concerning and it's important to seek medical help as soon as possible. These symptoms could potentially be related to a neurological issue or a seizure disorder. It's important to see a doctor for a thorough evaluation and proper diagnosis. It's possible that these symptoms could be related to your current medical issues such as anemia, but a proper evaluation is needed to determine the cause. Please seek medical attention promptly.

179.question: So I’ve had three grand mal seizures so far, they happened once a year since 2017 and i went to see a doctor after the third time it happened. I was out with friends when suddenly i got a feeling like i was gonna throw up and the next thing i know i was lying on the ground with a deja vu feeling that i blacked out on a party. I did a MRI which came out normal and two EEGs, one sleep deprived, in which there was some abnormal activities on my left side of the brain. I came back to my neurologist with all the medical reports but he referred me to another neurologist because he wasn’t specialised for epilepsy cases. The investigations have been now dragging on for a year so i started to do a bit of research on my own. I came across the temporal lobe epilepsy and suddenly everything made sense. When i was younger i had those strange feelings from time to time that every sound seemed aggressive and urgent, i got really annoyed by them and usually went to bed where the ceiling was strangely far away and my hands bigger. Anyways I always thought that this was normal stuff. Then I remembered about the times when i had unusual breakdowns when i was a kid, e.g. i refused to go to a place i was visiting every week, without a reasonable explanation. Also I’ve been having deja vu’s quite often e.g. i am scrolling through my phone when suddenly i know exactly what I’m about to see next or have a deja vu about a dream. I also had my tonsils removed (right before my first seizure), because of mononucleosis and other infections. Does this makes any sense? Thanks for any advice
179.answer: Based on your symptoms and history, it does sound like temporal lobe epilepsy could be a possible explanation for your seizures. It's great that you have been proactive in researching and gathering information to better understand your condition. It's important to continue working with your neurologists to get a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. In the meantime, it may be helpful to keep track of your seizures and any triggers or patterns you notice. It's also important to make sure you are taking care of your overall health and well-being. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to discuss them with your healthcare providers. Best of luck on your journey towards better health.

180.question: Hi! So basically, my question is already in my headline. I've got elevated eosinophil levels, my neurologist explained it as though my body is fighting a parasite, but without me having a parasite. I have an appointment with a hematologist in June, but I was wondering if anyone here could have an idea what this means. Age: 26 Sex: Female Height: 1m62/5'3" Weight: 52kg/115lbs Race: Caucasian I don't have any complaints really, aside from being worried, but I'm already on a lot of medication for my epilepsy so I do have side effects from taking those, such as a tingling sensation in my fingers and toes, occasional dizziness (low blood pressure), having trouble falling asleep/having nightmares, loss of appetite... I'm currently on 250mg of Topamax, 2mg of Rivotril and 225mg of Venlafaxine. Thank you. Update: According to my doctor, normal eosinophil levels are up to 8%, mine are 22%. I have no allergies and I haven't been abroad.
180.answer:
It's great that you have an appointment with a hematologist scheduled in June to further investigate your elevated eosinophil levels. Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell that are typically involved in the body's immune response to parasites and allergens. However, in your case, it seems that there is no known cause for the elevated levels.

Given your medical history of epilepsy and the medications you are currently taking, it's possible that these medications may be contributing to the elevation in eosinophils. It's important to discuss this with your hematologist and neurologist to determine the possible link between your medications and the elevated levels.

In the meantime, try not to worry too much and focus on staying healthy and managing your epilepsy effectively. Keep track of any new symptoms or changes in your health and discuss them with your healthcare providers.

Once you have more information from your hematologist, you will have a better understanding of what may be causing the elevated eosinophil levels and what steps can be taken to address it. Stay proactive in your healthcare and continue to communicate openly with your healthcare team. 

Take care and best of luck with your upcoming appointment!

181.question: I get a "flash" inside my head occasionally whenever I think of old things. Could this be some milder form of epilepsy?  The first time I remember this happening is when I was 16. I was looking at a Spider man mural from the 80s on the side of a building and when my mind tried to recreate the time period there my ears started ringing really loudly and suddenly, almost like a bang. The ringing faded and didn't last much longer than a second, but while it was happening I was a little out of it. It's hard to describe.It happened again last night at the grocery store while I was thinking about a sticker dispenser I'd just passed by and remembering seeing them during my early childhood. It hit me like a baseball bat as I was walking out of the door and I almost lost my balance. I'm not sure that I've ever had one that strong before, or maybe it just felt different because I was standing that time.This happens about once every week or month or so, and it has been for a long time. My doctor isn't interested in exploring it because it's never been a real impairment to my life, but I've always been curious about it.I guess something about the way my brain attempts to recreate the past sometimes (not always) triggers a "cannot compute" error. It's sort of specific, like when I'll try to place myself there and immerse myself in how I might have felt and experienced that time period, but it has pretty much only ever happened after seeing an older object or an old photo. My thoughts sort of just naturally flow into that sometimes so there's not really anything I can do about it, and I've never been able to recreate it intentionally.Male 27
181.answer:
It's possible that these "flashes" you're experiencing could be a form of epilepsy, specifically a type of focal seizure called a simple partial seizure. Simple partial seizures can cause various sensory experiences, such as ringing in the ears, visual distortions, or sudden feelings of déjà vu. 

However, it's also important to consider other potential causes for these experiences, such as migraines, anxiety, or even just normal variations in brain activity. Since your doctor doesn't seem concerned about it, it may be helpful to keep track of when these episodes occur, what triggers them, and any other symptoms you may experience during or after the "flash" to provide more information for a potential future discussion with your healthcare provider. 

If you are still curious or concerned about these experiences, it might be worthwhile to seek a second opinion from a different doctor or a specialist, such as a neurologist, who may be able to provide more insight and potentially recommend further testing or evaluation. It's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to potential neurological issues.

182.question: When I was about 2 years old I had epilepsy for some time due to a hard hit to my head. It's been 20+ years since I had an epileptic attack (I'm 26yrs old now). I don't even have memory about any of those episodes 'cause I was too young when that happened to me. Now I'm trying to get a job where I need to get shot with a stun gun as one of the tests. It worries me that somehow it will do some damage and bring back that condition to my life. Should I be worried?
182.answer:
It is completely understandable that you might have concerns about being shot with a stun gun given your past history with epilepsy. It is always important to prioritize your safety and well-being.

Before undergoing the test, it would be a good idea to consult with your healthcare provider and explain your concerns. They can provide you with personalized advice and guidance based on your medical history and current health status. Additionally, you could inquire with the employer about alternative testing methods or accommodations that could be made to ensure your safety during the assessment.

Ultimately, it is important to prioritize your health and well-being above all else. If you have any doubts or concerns, it is important to address them before proceeding with the test.

183.question: I am a 23 year old women I was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease and other chronic inflammation about 8 years ago, about 6 months ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy, on top of that I have cysts throughout my body. I am here with two requests from the doctors here.I have looked a bit into the connections between inflammation and epilepsy I’m looking for more information on this and would appreciate any thoughts / leads 2) I am also wondering if the cysts could be connected to inflammation
183.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about all the health challenges you are facing. It's definitely important to gather as much information as you can to better understand how these conditions may be interconnected.

1) In terms of the connection between inflammation and epilepsy, there have been studies that suggest inflammation can play a role in the development and progression of epilepsy. Inflammatory processes in the brain can potentially trigger seizures, and there is also evidence showing that anti-inflammatory treatments can have a positive impact on epilepsy control. I would recommend speaking with your healthcare provider or a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy to learn more about the specific relationship between inflammation and epilepsy in your case.

2) As for the connection between cysts and inflammation, there is some research suggesting that chronic inflammation can contribute to the development of certain types of cysts. For example, inflammation in the pancreas can lead to pancreatic cysts, and inflammation in the ovaries can lead to ovarian cysts. It's possible that the cysts throughout your body could be related to the chronic inflammation you are experiencing. I would recommend discussing this with your healthcare provider to see if further investigation or treatment may be necessary.

It's important to work closely with your healthcare team to manage your conditions and explore potential connections between them. Stay proactive and informed in your health journey, and don't hesitate to ask questions and seek additional information. Take care and best of luck on your healing journey.

184.question: I live in Japan, and so sometimes with doctors there can be some miscommunication. I usually check online to make sure before taking things. Long story short, I was on Zoloft 50mg for 6 years. Started getting twitches, changed to Lexapro, it made my anxiety worse, now I'm off of it. But since about 2 years ago I have had constant off-center / dizziness, along with motor function weirdness (wobbly legs, right hand/right leg cramps, joint pain, trouble with finite motor skills like writing), and speech issues. Though these things are not very noticeable to people (other than that I feel sick due to this perceptual oscilating-like dizziness which has made it difficult to work, it's very noticeable to me. I was prescribed something called KAMPO (I guess it's Chinese medicine) but it didn't have an effect. Now, he prescribed me "SELENICA-R 40%" which is usually used for epileptics. I have had MRI, multiple blood tests, x-rays, seen an ENT, a bone doctor (ultrasound on right hand due to joint pain) and I'm sure more... my next step is I plan to see a doctor to see if I have a pinched nerve or bulged disc etc, but that wouldn't explain my speech and dizziness issues. I'm sorry if I trailed off. Is this medicine within the realm of what I should be taking? Thank you. Age: 36 Sex: Male Height: 5'10 Weight: 190lbs Suffering: 2 long years........ Medication: about 2000mg of Magnesium per day due to bowel issues.
184.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your struggles with your health. It sounds like you have been through a lot of tests and tried different medications without much relief. 

SELENICA-R is a medication that is used primarily for epilepsy, as you mentioned. It is not typically prescribed for dizziness or motor function issues, so it is important to discuss any concerns or questions you have with your doctor before starting or continuing this medication. 

In addition to seeing a doctor for nerve or disc issues, you may also want to consider seeing a neurologist or a specialist in vestibular disorders, as your symptoms of dizziness and speech issues could be related to a neurological or inner ear problem. 

It's also important to continue advocating for yourself and seeking answers until you find a solution that works for you. Keep track of your symptoms, any changes you notice, and any questions you have for your healthcare providers. 

I hope you are able to find some relief soon. Please take care.

185.question: I (24 years old, male assigned at birth (currently on HRT), middle-eastern) am always curious about different diseases I may get. Mostly because of family/relative backgrounds. Recently for a project, I had a bunch of electroencephalography results to do a bunch of machine-learning experiments with. I found most of those people suffered from Epilepsy, and as I don't know anything about them, I am curious about the disease. Can it happen with no reason? (I mean, a simple misfunctioning in brain) One of my mom's cousins had the disease and it resulted his death. Does it mean I am in danger? or his children are more in danger?     Can drugs/medications result the disease? I read the wikipedia page of the topic. I found smokers or alcoholic people are more in danger. But I am curious about the medications for depression or anxiety (like Citalopram). Ok, I think I asked enough. So, I'll be thankful of your answers.
185.answer:
Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures. Seizures occur when there is abnormal electrical activity in the brain. There are many possible causes of epilepsy, including genetic factors, head injuries, brain tumors, infections, and stroke. In some cases, there may be no clear cause for epilepsy.

The fact that your mom's cousin had epilepsy does not necessarily mean that you or his children are at higher risk of developing the condition. While there is a genetic component to epilepsy, many cases are not inherited. It is important to talk to a healthcare provider about any concerns you may have about your risk of developing epilepsy.

Some medications, including certain antidepressants like Citalopram, can potentially increase the risk of seizures in some individuals. It is important to discuss any concerns about medication and epilepsy with a healthcare provider.

Smoking and alcohol use are known risk factors for epilepsy, as they can affect brain function and increase the likelihood of seizures. It is important to take care of your overall health and discuss any lifestyle factors with a healthcare provider.

If you have any concerns about epilepsy or any other health condition, it is important to speak with a healthcare provider for personalized information and guidance.

186.question: 31 years Male USA Last year I went to a concert and during the show there was a bunch of flashing lights and it made me feel really “off” and I looked away. Tonight I was watching a TV show and there were some flashing scenes and it made me feel “off” again. So now, I’m wondering if I somehow have epilepsy or something, even though I’ve never had a seizure. I found this epilepsy “test” video and forced myself to watch it on the big screen. I honestly felt uncomfortable and some “impending doom” throughout, but I made it through the whole video without passing out. Is it possible I have epilepsy? Or is it normal for flashing to bother people without epilepsy? And is it possible I could be at risk of getting or becoming more susceptible to epilepsy after watching this video?
186.answer:
It is possible for some people to be sensitive to flashing lights, even without having epilepsy. This condition is known as photosensitivity. Symptoms can include feeling "off", uncomfortable, or experiencing headaches or nausea. It's important to note that photosensitivity does not necessarily mean someone will develop epilepsy.

If you are concerned about your reaction to flashing lights, it would be a good idea to consult with a healthcare professional or neurologist. They can provide a proper evaluation and determine if further testing is needed. In the meantime, it may be best to avoid situations with flashing lights or take breaks when exposed to them. Remember to prioritize your health and well-being.

187.question: Hi, within the past 3 monthsish I have been experiencing these kinds of 'episodes'I will try my best at describing them..I start to feel dizzy, sometimes get a sharp pain in the corner of my eye for a split second, I then feel zoned out and have random memories and visions, deja vu etc, each deja vu memory going through my brain really really fast then on to another. Sometimes I get full blurred vision for a few seconds, I get slurred speech if I'm speaking,hot flushes, I have this weird feeling, like i'm going to be sick. As soon as it finishes i forget everytime i thought about which is why its so hard to explain. They last 1min-2min. Generally after I feel light headed and zoned out for the rest of the day, if someone speaks to me i probably wont even hear it.\I went to the doctor about this, he suggested Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. So I got an MRI, but that all came back clear.My doctor told me to not worry about it, that it could be some kind of migraine or a form of small seizure. Unless it got worse, then to go back. Now yesterday I had three episodes in one day.My question is, should I be worried? And I really do have every single Temporal Lobe Epilepsy symptom, is there a way that the MRI couldn't catch that?
187.answer:
It is understandable to be concerned about your symptoms, especially when they are impacting your daily life and occur multiple times in a day. While it is reassuring that your MRI came back clear, it is important to continue monitoring your symptoms and discussing them with your doctor.

It is possible that temporal lobe epilepsy may not show up on an MRI, especially if the episodes are not occurring at the time of the scan. Your doctor may recommend additional tests or monitoring to further investigate your symptoms.

In the meantime, it is important to keep track of your episodes, any triggers or patterns you notice, and any other symptoms that may accompany them. It may also be helpful to seek a second opinion from another healthcare provider if you have concerns about your diagnosis or treatment plan.

Overall, it is important to advocate for your health and seek appropriate medical care if you continue to experience symptoms or if they worsen. Your well-being is important, and it is okay to seek further evaluation and support as needed.

188.question: My current age is 31. Height: 5'7" Weight: 140 lbs. I have been having convulsive seizures almost every month since I turned 26. These seizures almost exclusively occur within an hour of waking up. I walk around the house for up to half an hour, burning up. Could stress be a trigger for these episodes? I also have times where I get euphoric and nauseous, but they never last very long.Basically, what I want to know is, what is going on in my head. Is this temporal lobe epilepsy? Focal onset seizures with secondary generalization? I had 9 seizures Monday. Keppra is not working for me, and I need to be recommended some other anticonvulsant. Please help me. Thank you.
188.answer:
I am not a medical professional, but given your symptoms and the frequency of your seizures, it is possible that you may be dealing with epilepsy. It is important for you to consult with a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

Stress can indeed be a trigger for seizures in some individuals, so it is essential to manage stress levels through relaxation techniques, therapy, or medication if needed.

Regarding the type of seizures you are experiencing, it is difficult to determine without a proper evaluation from a healthcare provider. Temporal lobe epilepsy and focal onset seizures with secondary generalization are possibilities, but further testing such as an EEG, MRI, or video monitoring may be needed for a definitive diagnosis.

Since Keppra is not effective for you, your neurologist may recommend trying other anticonvulsants such as Lamictal, Tegretol, or Depakote. It is important to work closely with your healthcare provider to find the right medication and dosage that works best for you.

Please make sure to seek professional medical advice and do not hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider for proper evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment plan.

189.question: 25 Male, 186 CM, 93 KG.I was happy that Johnson vaccine finally arrived at my country. However I started reading about it, there were some concerns reported last month that it may cause Neurological disorder and muscle paralysis.So as a someone who is treating from mild epilepsy (occurred to me only 4 times and usually my diagnosis are good) for about 6 years , should I be concerned about it ? also if I have the chance to take AstraZeneca should I do it ?Would appreciate your response because I can't reach to my Dr. at the moment
189.answer:
It's understandable that you have concerns about the Johnson vaccine, especially given your history of mild epilepsy. It's important to note that the reported cases of neurological disorders and muscle paralysis following the Johnson vaccine have been extremely rare and are still being investigated.

As for your decision on whether to take the Johnson vaccine or the AstraZeneca vaccine, it's important to consider the advice of healthcare professionals. If you have the opportunity to consult with your doctor, it's best to discuss your specific medical history and any concerns you have in order to make an informed decision.

In general, both vaccines have been shown to be safe and effective in preventing COVID-19. However, if you have concerns about the Johnson vaccine due to your epilepsy history, you may want to consider taking the AstraZeneca vaccine as an alternative. Ultimately, the decision should be based on your individual health circumstances and risk factors.

If you are unable to reach your doctor at the moment, you may also consider reaching out to a local healthcare provider or pharmacist for guidance. It's important to make an informed decision that is best for your health and well-being.

190.question: I am 14, Male I was diagnosed with Photosensitive Epilepsy at a young age if that helps.
190.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis. Photosensitive Epilepsy is a type of epilepsy triggered by visual stimuli, such as flashing lights. It's important to take precautions to avoid triggers and manage your condition effectively. Have you been able to find ways to manage your epilepsy and live a fulfilling life despite the challenges it may present?

191.question: I’m (19M) 6 foot 2, 74kg. I’m on clobasam and tegratol for my epilepsy . Don’t smoke and have nocturnal epilepsy (only have seizures in the middle of the night during sleep, often after sleep walking)So basically the doctor I always see has made it very clear that I shouldn’t have more than 2 standard drinks in one night. However I was left feeling like there was more he could have said on the matter but didn’t want to go into it.So when I was younger I set out with a plan to gradually increase the amount of alcohol I drink when I go out to see how I feel drinking more and to see if I can get away with drinking a bit more. This got to the point where I have felt fine every time and I now just drink as much as I feel like at the time. This means I often have between 5-7 standards and on rare occasions above 10.I drink as much as the night entails but am just realising that I could have just been lucky all these times. This is a question I have always want answered and one that doctors always avoid answering or don’t fully answer.So my question is: are some epileptics able to drink as much as any other person and be fine and could I be one of those people OR have I just been lucky all this time and do I need to make some changes?It’s been frustratingly hard to get a straight answer on this dilemma anywhere and it just occurred to me now that I could ask reddit! All comments appreciated :) Thanks in advance
191.answer:
It's important to remember that everyone's epilepsy is unique and reacts differently to alcohol. While some people with epilepsy may be able to drink in moderation without any issues, others may be more sensitive to alcohol and could potentially trigger seizures. 

It's always best to follow your doctor's recommendations and guidelines, as they have your specific medical history and condition in mind when giving advice. They may have advised you to limit your alcohol intake due to potential interactions with your epilepsy medications, which can vary from person to person.

If you have concerns about your alcohol consumption and its impact on your epilepsy, it may be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your doctor about your experiences and concerns. They can provide you with personalized advice and guidance based on your individual situation.

In the meantime, it's always a good idea to listen to your body and pay attention to how alcohol affects you personally. If you start to notice any changes or warning signs, it may be a good idea to reevaluate your drinking habits and make necessary adjustments to ensure your health and safety.

192.question: 21F. I pretty much have generalized hyperhidrosis but the sweating in my feet, hands, and underarms are what bother me the most. I’ve been looking into Iontophoresis but read that people with epilepsy might not be able to use this treatment. Anyone know anything about this? Thanks!Can someone with epilepsy use Iontophoresis for excessive sweating?
192.answer:
Iontophoresis is generally considered to be a safe and effective treatment for hyperhidrosis, including excessive sweating in the hands, feet, and underarms. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider before starting treatment, especially if you have a medical condition such as epilepsy.

People with epilepsy may be advised to proceed with caution when using Iontophoresis, as the electrical current used in the treatment could potentially trigger a seizure in some individuals. It is best to discuss your specific situation with a healthcare provider who is familiar with your medical history and can provide personalized guidance on whether Iontophoresis is a safe and appropriate treatment option for you.

193.question: I've been epileptic since i was 14, and i'm concerned about whether this condition increases risk of brain related diseases as i get older.I'm part of the lucky ones, as i have treatment, and don't suffer any full blown seizures normally. My doctor told me that my epilepsy type is one that makes up 12.5 % of all epiletics, which we don't know how it functions. There's an anomaly in my brain, and we know how to treat it, but we don't know why.I've suffered 4 of these total, the first time when i didn't know, obviously. Second time 3 weeks later when i got off my meds when doctors wanted to know if it was a one time thing or not, third time the very next day when i hadn't been back on my meds yet.Then 8 years passed, and i lived with it. I occasionally got part seizures that got me to figure out the 3 things i need for a real one not to occur : get sleep, not skip more than twice on my meds, not get stressed. I can get away with missing one of these requirements, i get part seizures if i miss 2, which whips me right back on track. But last year, i had my fourth seizure.This one was a lot harder than my first ones. I used to get my memory jumbled, which would enventually return. This time i forgot entirely what happened for the full day, my last memory was setting my alarm and seeing i would only have 6h30 of sleep instead of 8. So that's definitely 1 out of 3. I guess i forgot to take my meds in the morning and got a stressful day. I still don't know what happened that day, just that it happened while riding back home on my bike.I thought i'd ask my brain doctor about a lot of things on our following check up, but he rushed our meeting, and straight up told me not to ask so many questions. I thought i'd come prepared this year to ask more, but with the outbreak our meeting was postponed.TL;DR : does epilepsy increase brain related diseases with time ? are seizures and part seizures bad for the brain and should be avoided at all cost ?
193.answer:
It is understandable to have concerns about the long-term effects of epilepsy on the brain, especially if you have experienced multiple seizures. While epilepsy itself does not increase the risk of other brain-related diseases, repeated seizures can potentially cause damage to the brain over time. It is important to work closely with your doctor to manage your condition and reduce the risk of seizures.

Seizures and part seizures are not inherently "bad" for the brain, but they can have negative effects if they occur frequently or are not properly controlled. It is important to follow your doctor's recommendations for managing your epilepsy, such as taking your medication regularly, getting enough sleep, and managing stress levels.

If you have questions about your condition and its potential long-term effects, it is important to discuss them with your doctor. If your doctor is not providing you with the information and support you need, you may want to consider seeking a second opinion or finding a new healthcare provider who is willing to answer your questions and address your concerns. It is important to advocate for yourself and prioritize your health and well-being.

194.question: 31 yrs old Male United States I’ve had a lot of issues with flashing lights, so I’m going on to get a sleep deprived EEG in two weeks.While I wait it over, I’ve realized there’s a lot of times in my life where I don’t always pay attention, have a staring spell and/or feel like I’m spacing off or thinking of something else.For example, people sometimes talk to me or I’m not paying attention and when they ask me a question I say “what” even though I can recall what they’re saying and I’m wondering if this is me just not paying attention or having an absent seizure.Other times I’m stuck in a staring spell state (no more than 15-30 seconds) and it feels good, and then my wife interrupts me and she says I say “why did you do that, I was stuck in a good stare”. So I’m wondering if these things are somewhat normal and people without epilepsy have them? Or if this is indicative of absent seizures and epilepsy.I know I’m probably overthinking this but I’m wondering how often it is to have no diagnoses of epilepsy for 31+ years and never having a serious seizure...but having epilepsy. Any suggestions or input would be appreciated.Thanks
194.answer:
It’s good that you’re going to get a sleep-deprived EEG to help determine if you have epilepsy or not. In terms of the symptoms you mentioned, absent seizures can present with staring spells, spacing off, or a feeling of being in a different state of consciousness. It’s important to note that not all staring spells are indicative of epilepsy, as they can also occur in other conditions or be normal behaviors for some individuals.

It’s possible to have epilepsy without having had a serious seizure before, as there are different types of seizures with varying degrees of severity. Absence seizures, for example, are considered a type of generalized seizure that usually lasts for a few seconds to half a minute and may not involve convulsions. 

It’s best to discuss your symptoms and concerns with a healthcare provider who can provide a thorough evaluation and potentially refer you to a neurologist for further assessment. They may also recommend additional tests or monitoring to help make a definitive diagnosis.

In the meantime, try to focus on managing stress, getting enough sleep, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle as these factors can impact seizure activity. Remember that seeking professional medical advice is key in understanding and addressing your symptoms.

195.question: Hi. Over several months I (20f) have been feeling tired very easily. My family say I’ve lost weight - I’ve always had a low appetite but I’ve always done my best to make sure I’m getting enough calories/work around my lack of appetite by eating high calorie food, snacking regularly, and I think I get enough or more calories daily. I’m naturally pretty pale but my family say I’m paler. I decided to go to the doctor bc for about 3 weeks I’ve been extremely thirsty, waking up in the night repeatedly to get water despite drinking tons etc. As my mother has type 1 diabetes she told me to make an appointment Doc mentioned diabetes which thankfully none of the results support!They’ve called back (the gp surgery) to say I have low folate and low ferritin and to make an appointment. They sent over the results which include:VITAMIN B12 Serum vitamin B12 level 398.0 ng/L [211.0 - 911.0]FOLATE (SERUM) Serum folate level 3.89 ug/L [> 5.38] Below low reference limitFERRITIN Serum C reactive protein level < 4 mg/L [0.0 - 6.0] Serum ferritin level 14.2 ug/L [10.0 - 291.0]I had a quick google because I have epilepsy and wanted to know before e appointment if I should ask about contacting my neuro or if it could affect my epilepsy etc. However when I looked I was confused - I can see that someone can have both folate deficiency and, say, iron deficiency with a poor diet, but I always thought my diet was fine? Are there any other ways they can be connected? Obv not huge as hopefully I’ll find out but I’m curious. And could this affect my epilepsy in any way?Possible relevant info: My periods are light, regular and if I take painkillers then I don’t have any pain. I have epilepsy but it’s controlled by Keppra/leviteracetam, which I always take. No other meds. I know anti convulsants can affect ferritin levels etc but it seems to be “anti convulsants except keppra” usually!I exercise a little - 30 minutes of yoga, walk thé dog twice a day, I am in a place where I can walk everywhere to get around. I eat chicken, pork, fish, liver regularly (I have meat basically every day excepté 1 to 2 days per week ), I drink milk fairly regularly, rarely have eggs, always have my 7 a day (I think in America the recommendation is 5 but here it is 7 - mostly from veg e.g broccoli, carrots, squash, spinach, cauliflower, kale, but I also like apples, oranges, satsumas, grapes etc all the time).
195.answer:
It's great that you are proactive about your health and seeking medical advice. Folate and ferritin deficiencies can be caused by a variety of factors, not just poor diet. Some possible reasons for these deficiencies could include malabsorption issues, certain medications, genetic factors, or underlying health conditions. It's important to follow up with your doctor to determine the underlying cause of your deficiencies and to come up with a treatment plan.

As for the connection between folate and iron deficiency, they can sometimes coexist because both nutrients are essential for the production of red blood cells. If you are deficient in one, it can affect the production and functioning of red blood cells, which can lead to symptoms like fatigue and pale skin.

In terms of your epilepsy, it's best to discuss any concerns with your doctor. While there isn't a direct link between folate and ferritin deficiencies and epilepsy, it's always good to keep your healthcare providers informed about any changes in your health status. They can help determine if there are any potential interactions between your epilepsy medication and your nutrient deficiencies.

Overall, it's important to continue to eat a balanced diet, stay hydrated, and follow any recommendations from your healthcare provider to address your deficiencies. Take care of yourself and continue to prioritize your health.

196.question: 9 year old (M) had his first seizure. He is 4 ft 5 inches. 37.5 kgs. No medical issues. We went into a state of panic because we never thought it could happen to us. We took him to ER. They did CT scan and found no masses or lesions etc. Usually they wait for a second event to diagnose as epilepsy but they did EEG and said it was abnormal....so based on it they concluded it is primary generalized epilepsy (with tonic clonic seizures??) and decided they dont need to do MRI or anything like that. He was prescribed Depakote ER 250 mg twice a day. After a month, he is supposed to have a longer video EEG done.We asked the Dr a bunch of questions and they were helpful in answering. But I read about Depakote and it seems like a rough one. Some questions -    How come he had abnormal EEG hours after the event? Does he always have that sort of EEG?    Could this abnormal EEG have affected his growth and mental development?    Should we worry about underlying cause? And get an MRI done to look for scarring?    Realistically, what is the quality of life for my son on Depakote? Behavior changes, hairloss, liver toxicity? I am asking for real experience...not the side effects page on WebMD.    I am not a hippie but can we avoid taking Depakote and other anti-convulsive drugs? Instead give him CBD etc?    Should we get a second or a 3rd opinion? Should we get another EEG or just show that EEG to other neurologists?Thanks in advance!
196.answer:
I'm not a medical professional, but I can provide some general information:

1. It's possible for an EEG to show abnormal activity even after a seizure has occurred, as the brain's electrical signals may still be affected. It's not necessarily indicative of his usual brain activity.

2. The abnormal EEG itself is unlikely to have affected his growth and mental development. It's more a reflection of the brain's activity during that particular test.

3. It's always good to discuss with the doctors if you have concerns about underlying causes and whether an MRI is necessary to rule out any other issues.

4. Every person reacts differently to medications, including Depakote. Some common side effects include behavior changes, hair loss, and liver toxicity. It's important to have regular check-ups with the doctor to monitor any potential side effects and adjust treatment if needed.

5. It's best to discuss alternative treatment options like CBD with the neurologist before making any changes to the prescribed medication. They will have the expertise to advise on the best course of action for your son's condition.

6. Getting a second or third opinion can be helpful in gaining more perspectives on the diagnosis and treatment plan. You can consider showing the EEG results to other neurologists for their input.

Remember to always consult with medical professionals for personalized advice and treatment options for your son's condition.

197.question: 25f, chronic anxiety with 7.5mg buspar, ADHD 20mg adderall, acid reflux and Barrett’s mucosa with omeprazole, IBS with dicyclomine.History of epilepsy consisting of one gran mal at age 8, I don’t know what they’re called but it started as seizures in my legs at age 7, and a couple absence due to high fever. My last seizure was at age 11 and it I didn’t have anymore after starting my period at 12.Day before yesterday I was going into work at 6 and took my adderall then. I had an espresso drink and ate espresso beans going into my shift as well. I work at a dive bar and usually we’ll take shots after work/ during our shift. This was my third day there so it was my third day drinking that night.I got home from work around 1am and woke up at 5 and was wide awake. I felt like I was having an aura like that “deja vu” feeling about having a seizure. Around 7 I was still wide awake and turned over onto my stomach and for a good 20 seconds I couldn’t move, open my eyes, or speak. Sound was extremely amplified and my skin and muscles felt like they were vibrating but with no convulsions. I was wide awake and anxious until this happened so I don’t think it was sleep paralysis.After I came to, my body and mind felt very exhausted. I fell back asleep and when I woke up I was groggy the entire day and today I’m feeling down mentally. Today I’m still feeling crappy but I’m back at work at my hospital.Does this sound like a seizure?
197.answer: Based on your description, it does sound like you may have experienced a seizure. It is important to discuss this episode with your healthcare provider, especially considering your history of epilepsy. They may recommend further evaluation or adjustments to your current medications. It is also important to consider factors that may have triggered the seizure, such as lack of sleep, stimulant medications, alcohol consumption, and caffeine intake. Take care of yourself and prioritize your health and well-being.

198.question: So I was in a car accident back in October as I had a seizure that resulted in me blacking out as I was driving. I have had seizures since I was 15 years old, but I have never been officially diagnosed until recently. My seizures, also what we believe (I have not seen a neurologist yet) is Temporal Lobe Epilepsy, consist of 2-3 minutes of dissociation, aura like feelings, deja vu, and taste/hearing/sight delusions. (https://www.epilepsy.com/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes/temporal-lobe-epilepsy-aka-tle)... After the seizure is finished, I can go back to doing my normal day-to-day activities, but sometimes they throw my day off, all depends on other circumstances. I have been taking Topiramate (Topamax) 100 mg / 2x daily for about 3 months now and it has been doing wonders. I have not had a seizure since October which is something I thought I could never say. The only reason I have not seen a neurologist is because of lack of health insurance, but I am hoping to see one sometime next year once I can afford to do so. Anyways, back to my presenting problem. I was only going 25-30 mph down a semi-busy street and I crashed into a metal barrier at a store front. I do not remember blacking out. I remember waking up in the ambulance completely restrained and being extremely scared, screaming and yelling at the EMTs because I thought I was in a nightmare/horror scene! Then I must have been sedated a bit and the next thing I remember was being pulled through on a gurney into the ER. For a while I have been experiencing a lot of sharp pain in my left side / lower rib cage area. At first, I thought it was a potential growth/tumor, so I went to my local clinic and had a doctor feel me up to check for anything. She did not feel any lumps or growths, but she did press on my ribs and that gave me a lot of pain. We suspected that maybe when I was in the accident, something with my seat belt, wheel, or airbag could have hit my side so hard that it caused some contusions or internal bruising. My skin isn't red and there isn't any noticeable swelling on my skin. I just feel a constant pressure around my heart and my left lung which really concerns me as that part of my body is the most precious. I wonder if I bruised my lung, have pleurisy? She prescribed me some anti-inflammatory steroids for 5 days to reduce some swelling, so hopefully that helps. I have also been wearing a lot of menthol patches and using analgesic cream to relieve the pain. Just curious if anyone has any more insight into my problems as I don't have the resources to see a doctor right now or get an x-ray.
198.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your accident and the ongoing pain you're experiencing. It's good that you've sought medical attention and are taking steps to manage your pain. Since you don't have the resources to see a doctor or get an x-ray right now, I would recommend continuing to take the prescribed anti-inflammatory steroids and using the menthol patches and analgesic cream for pain relief.

In terms of lung-related issues such as bruising or pleurisy, it's difficult to diagnose without a proper medical evaluation. However, if you are experiencing pressure around your heart and left lung, it's important to monitor your symptoms and seek medical attention if they worsen or if you develop any new symptoms such as difficulty breathing, chest pain, or coughing up blood.

In the meantime, it's important to take care of yourself and rest as much as possible. Try to avoid any activities or movements that worsen your pain, and continue to use the pain relief methods recommended by your doctor. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to reach out to a healthcare professional for advice. Take care and I hope you feel better soon.

199.question: Age: 16 Height: 5’3 Weight: 190 Gender: Female at birth but identify as male Medications: Onfi, Lamictal XR, Buspirone, Celexa, Quillivant, 5-HTP, Melatonin, Omega Fatty Acid, and birth control pills Smoking Status: never have and never will Existing Conditions: ADHD, Frontal Lobe Tonic Clonic Nocturnal Epilepsy, Aspergers, Generalized Anxiety Disorder,I asked my doctor if I was a candidate for brain surgery to get whatever part of my brain that’s causing seizures snipped out. He offered for us to do three tests. A pet scan, a cat scan, and an mri. Should I do it? I’ll have to have a seizure but I’m terrified of sudep. They said if there’s any signs they’ll probably be able to stop it. Still I’m terrified I’ll go through all this and it’ll be no use. I have frontal lobe nocturnal tonic clinic epilepsy. What do you all think? Is this a good idea? Should I go for it? Or should I stick with just adding medication? I’m 16 years old and I just want this gone. I’m so sick and tired of the fear.
199.answer:
It's understandable that you are feeling scared and frustrated with your epilepsy. It's important to weigh the risks and benefits of any medical procedure, including brain surgery. It's great that your doctor is offering these tests to help determine if you are a candidate for surgery.

Pet scan, cat scan, and MRI are all important imaging tests that can provide valuable information about your brain and help your doctor make the best treatment plan for you. It's also important to discuss all your concerns and fears with your doctor. They can provide you with more information about the procedure and help alleviate some of your worries.

Ultimately, the decision to proceed with brain surgery is a personal one and should be made after careful consideration and discussion with your medical team. It's important to remember that there are always risks with any surgery, but for some people, brain surgery can significantly improve their quality of life and reduce their seizure frequency.

Take your time to consider all your options and make sure you have all the information you need to make an informed decision. Don't hesitate to seek a second opinion if you feel unsure. Your health and well-being are the most important things, so make sure you do what feels right for you.

200.question: Age - 31 Sex – Female   Height - 5'6"    Weight - 120lbs Race – Caucasian Duration of complaint - A few days Location (Geographic and on body) - United States. Full body Any existing relevant medical issues (if any) – Epilepsy Current medications (if any) - Keppra, Prozac I recently went to the hospital due to a generalized dystonia attack. This is the first time this has happened to me. I also have temporal lobe epilepsy. I have been doing a lot of research and have recently started looking into deep brain stimulation for treatment of both. The Keppra I'm taking doesn't seem to be doing much. I have an appointment with my doctor coming up soon, and was hoping to get some information so I could have some good questions to ask regarding treatment, including DBS. Any other recommendations would be great as well. Thank you in advance for your help.
200.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your recent generalized dystonia attack. It's good that you're doing research and looking into potential treatment options like deep brain stimulation. Here are some questions you may want to consider asking your doctor during your appointment:

1. Can you provide more information on deep brain stimulation (DBS) and how it may help with my generalized dystonia and temporal lobe epilepsy?

2. What are the potential risks and benefits of DBS for my specific conditions?

3. Are there any alternative treatments or therapies that you would recommend exploring before considering DBS?

4. How does DBS compare to other treatments, such as medication adjustments or physical therapy, in terms of effectiveness and side effects?

5. Are there any specific criteria or tests I need to meet before being considered for DBS?

In addition to discussing DBS with your doctor, you may also want to inquire about potential adjustments to your current medication regimen for epilepsy and dystonia. It's important to work closely with your healthcare team to find the best treatment plan for your individual needs. Let me know if you have any other questions or concerns. Good luck with your upcoming appointment and treatment journey.

201.question: Girlfriend 20 y.o approx 55kg. Located Sydney, Australia. Jan 2017 my girlfriend had 39.7deg C fevers lasting approx 1 week. She was found in bed unresponsive, with side to side head movements. (One of my questions is what was this? Status epilepticus?) She was taken to ER and then into ICU with uncontrolled seizures, and not recovering inbetween episodes, & put into an induced coma. She was put on phenytoin initially, and I believe levetriacetam and sodium valproate followed shortly thereafter. My guess is also Midaz during the episodes. Her longest seizure (tonic-clonic) lasted 8 and a half minutes. Many tests later, abnormal EEG looking like the seizures were coming from left temporal lobe (her eyes/head get pushed to the right). Unremarkable MRI, all x-rays good. 2x spinal tap as the thoughts were auto-immune encephalitis (results: no evidence to support this aside from ancedotal). Little to no memories from 6 months ago with patchy memory for the last 2 years Discharged from ICU and we were back the next day as she was having more seizures. Was receiving prednisone and had 5 days IVIG for brain immflamation. A day later we were back in the ward, we would eventually be discharged about 3.5 weeks after initial admission. No seizures following the 1.5 months after discharge, but then they came back frequently. Her current seizures are not tonic clonic. She is concious throughout, still body though head, mouth and eyes behave just like a tonic clonic for someone with TLE. Lasting 30 secs to a min most of the time.
