227.answer:
Given your symptoms and medical history, there are a few red flags that you should watch out for:

1. Increasing lightheadedness and fatigue: If these symptoms persist or worsen, it could be a sign of anemia or other underlying health issues, such as thyroid problems.

2. Darker urine: This could indicate dehydration or liver issues. If your urine remains consistently dark despite increased water intake, it could be a sign of a more serious problem.

3. Changes in menstrual cycle: Lighter periods and spotting could be a sign of hormonal imbalances or other gynecological issues, especially given your history of endometriosis and ovarian cysts.

4. Increasing ovarian pain: If the pain in your ovary is getting worse and is accompanied by other symptoms like nausea and increased hunger, it's important to have it checked out by a healthcare provider to rule out any complications from the cyst.

5. Recurrent flu-like symptoms: Constantly feeling like you are catching a flu, along with frequent cold symptoms, could be a sign of a weakened immune system or underlying infection.

Given your family history of cancer and the fact that several of your symptoms are concerning, it would be best to schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider to discuss your concerns and undergo further evaluation. It's important to listen to your body and seek medical attention when needed, especially when dealing with ongoing health issues like epilepsy, endometriosis, and migraines. Take care of yourself and prioritize your health.

228.question: I’m (40F) 5ft 8, 164lbs, caucasian. Medications: Lamotrigine and Sertraline Health conditions: ADHD, Tourette’s, epilepsy and severe degenerative disc disease. I don’t have a current issue but every time I’ve had surgery I wake up completely full of beans, even when I’ve just woken up in recovery. I will stay hyper for hours afterwards and not feel surgical pain for the same amount of time. It can be quite funny, I talk at 100mph and can’t stop giggling. I don’t feel sick at all and always want water and food immediately. Drs/nurses etc have commented it’s like I didn’t even have surgery, but I’ve never asked if there’s a reason why. I’m not sure if it’s related but codeine does absolutely nothing for me and I always need extra anaesthetic at the dentist. I’ve never been told I’m difficult to put under GA. Thank you in advance, I’ve been wondering for years.
228.answer:
It sounds like you may have a unique response to anesthesia and pain medications, which could be related to your underlying health conditions and medications you are taking. Some individuals may have a genetic predisposition to metabolize drugs differently, resulting in varying responses to anesthesia and pain medications.

Your heightened energy and lack of pain sensitivity after surgery could possibly be due to the effects of the anesthesia or pain medications on your neurotransmitter levels. It's also possible that your body processes these medications differently, leading to a faster recovery and reduced pain sensation.

It's important to communicate your experiences with your healthcare providers before any future surgeries so they can adjust your anesthesia and pain management plan accordingly. They may also consider alternative medications or dosage adjustments based on your unique response.

It's always a good idea to discuss any concerns or unusual responses to medications with your healthcare provider to ensure you receive the best care possible.

229.question: 20 year old old Female. I’m taking 500mg of Keppra every morning for my epilepsy and I’ve been on it for about two years. I’ve just recently stopped taking amitriptyline 25mg about a week now. I’ve been going through the withdrawals but it’s been easing and the symptoms weren’t too bad besides the chills and shakes. I also take Ventolin inhalers for my asthma as well as paracetamols for migraines here and there. Anyway, I’ve had this sort of pain months ago. The stomach pain was unbearable and lasted a week or so until it soothed. It completely went away after a month or so. I think the annoying part was I constantly felt like I needed the bathroom. After the first day I didn’t actually need to use the bathroom but it just constantly felt like I did. It was very uncomfortable. I think eating made it worse but I can’t be too sure. I stopped drinking sodas or spicy foods and drank decaffeinated green tea with honey everyday. It went away and now suddenly it’s back. I’m also late with my period by 23 days but I usually have irregular periods. My stomach gurgles a lot too. If my stomach pain isn’t so bad it’s me needing to use the bathroom or my stomach making noises. My distress triggers anxiety attacks and that also doesn’t help.
229.answer:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through all of this. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of different symptoms and it can be really frustrating when they all seem to be happening at once. It's possible that the stomach pain and discomfort you're experiencing could be related to your medication, changes in your diet, or even stress and anxiety.

It's always a good idea to talk to your doctor about any new or worsening symptoms, especially if they're affecting your daily life. They can help you determine the cause of your stomach issues and recommend the best course of action. In the meantime, continue to avoid triggers like spicy foods and caffeine, and try to manage your stress and anxiety as best you can.

As for your late period, irregular periods can be common for some individuals, but it's also worth mentioning to your doctor, especially if it's causing you concern. They can help determine if there may be an underlying medical reason for the irregularity.

Overall, taking care of your physical and mental health is important, so don't hesitate to reach out for support and guidance. Take care of yourself and I hope you start feeling better soon.

230.question: Gender: Female, Age: 9, Height: Idk tbh, Location: Head, How long ago: 1 week.So my co-workers daughter was just diagnosed with grey matter heterotopia. She was crying her eyes out today, and I felt really bad. She brings her daughter to work quite often and we love her here. She is a wonderful kid, and we were all really sad with the news. I was hoping to shed a little bit of light, maybe some information on what their options are. They have to wait until October for their doctor to talk to them about the subject while her daughter still has seizures and her parents just suffer. I wanted to brighten up her day, and even if the news are bad or there aren’t many options... at least I wanna give her some clarity. Any and all responses are welcomed.Thank you!
230.answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your co-worker's daughter's diagnosis. Grey matter heterotopia is a rare neurological condition where a person's brain develops abnormal clusters of grey matter in the wrong location. It can cause seizures and other neurological issues.

Treatment options for grey matter heterotopia typically include medications to control seizures, and in some cases, surgery may be recommended to remove the abnormal tissue. It's important for your co-worker to consult with the doctor and discuss the best treatment plan for her daughter.

In the meantime, it's important for your co-worker to know that she is not alone in this journey. There are support groups and resources available for families dealing with similar conditions, where they can find guidance, comfort, and information.

It's wonderful that you want to support your co-worker during this difficult time. Simply being there to listen, offering a shoulder to lean on, and showing your care and compassion can make a big difference. Your presence and support can bring some light into their lives during this challenging period.

231.question: 25F, 200lb, 5’4, asthma, current medications wellbutrin SR, vyvanse, lexapro, montelukast, spironolactone. i do not drink any alcohol, use cannabis 5-7x a weekOccasionally, I will have an intense sensation of deja vu, followed by a sensation that I can only describe as disoriented. It’s almost like a combination of intense nausea, dizziness, and confusion, which will be very intense for a few seconds before dissipating. After the initial peak, I will feel “weird” for anywhere between 10 mins to a half hour afterwards, sometimes I will be nauseous for awhile, sometimes I will need to lay down, sometimes I feel too overwhelmed to socialize, etc. (I do sometimes experience deja vu WITHOUT the weird sensations too, just the general feeling of unease that comes with a cognitively dissonant experience like deja vu.)This used to happen a lot more as a kid, and stopped for awhile, but recently it’s happened once or twice and made me wonder why it happens. When I was younger I think I used to be able to “control” whether it progressed if I caught the sensation early enough? For example, if I started having that “I’ve been here before” feeling, if I leaned into it and tried to figure out if it was a dream, what came next, etc, the strange feelings would come on; occasionally if I tried to move on from the topic it would just stop at the deja vu and leave me just a little bit weirded out by the experience.I do tend to remember my dreams very vividly, and I have read online that people who do tend to be more susceptible to deja vu. Occasionally I can even tell when I have the sensation and am in fact experiencing the set-up to a dream (i.e opening a closet and then waiting for the “next scene” so to speak from the dream). I am just curious if this is normal, if these weird feelings are just part of deja vu or if it’s something else?
231.answer:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a type of aura, which can be a symptom of certain medical conditions, such as epilepsy or migraines. Auras are often described as feelings of deja vu, disorientation, dizziness, confusion, and nausea, and can sometimes be followed by other symptoms, such as headaches or fatigue.

Given your history of asthma and current medications, it may be worth discussing these symptoms with a healthcare provider to rule out any potential underlying medical issues. They may recommend further evaluation, such as neurological testing or imaging, to determine the cause of these episodes.

In the meantime, keeping a journal of when these episodes occur, any triggers or patterns you notice, and any other symptoms you experience may help provide valuable information for your healthcare provider. It's always important to prioritize your health and seek professional medical advice if you have any concerns or unusual symptoms.

232.question: ’m a 60yr old fit male with Gerd due to a Hiatal hernia. Have been on PPIs for 22 years. Have had a history of passing out on occasion after weight lifting/working out. Doctors did cardio tests /tilt table with no results for explanation. One neurologist said I had epilepsy another one said absolutely not. No one seemed to take into account the PPI and Gerd condition and that this only happened after work outs. Could the weight lifting be affecting the Vagus nerve and causing the light headedness and the seizure like passing out episodes?
232.answer:
It is possible that the weight lifting and strain on the body during workouts could be affecting the vagus nerve, which plays a role in regulating heart rate, blood pressure, and digestion. In individuals with GERD and a hiatal hernia, there may be additional pressure on the vagus nerve due to the positioning of the stomach and esophagus.

When the vagus nerve is affected, it can lead to symptoms such as lightheadedness, fainting, and potentially seizure-like episodes. It is important to discuss this possibility with your healthcare provider and explore potential strategies to alleviate strain on the vagus nerve during workouts, such as modifying the intensity or type of exercise, ensuring proper hydration, and maintaining stability during weight lifting.

Additionally, it may be helpful to consider alternative treatments or lifestyle changes to manage your GERD and decrease reliance on long-term PPI use, as these medications may also have potential side effects that can impact neurological symptoms. It is important to work closely with your healthcare team to address your symptoms and determine the best course of action for managing your condition.

233.question: 29F, height 165cm, weight 74kg, caucasian. I do not smoke or have regular dairy. Weekly alcohol consumption would be 2-7 standard drinks per week at most.  also regularly have lean meat and 3 veg for lunch and dinner and a fruit smoothie for breakfast. Current diagnoses: epilepsy, mild chronic pancreatitis Regular medications are: AM: 500mg Kepra, vitamins D+magnesium PM: 500mg Kepra, vitamin D+magnesium I am awaiting follow-up with a gastroenterologist about why my pancreas could be nibbling on itself (lypase has been found to be between 70-100 on multiple occasions). I have a history of treating my anxiety with alcohol and fast food but over the last 8 years or so (since my early 20's) I've gone to therapy and gotten it really well under control. I never had these symptoms before when I had unhealthy habits but over the last year my pancreas has not been having a good time. Every month or 2 I get these very specific pains that I now know is mild chronic pancreatitis. It's never brought on by a change in routine, it's always random.
233.answer:
Given your history of mild chronic pancreatitis and the fact that you are awaiting follow-up with a gastroenterologist, it's important to continue to follow up with your healthcare provider for further evaluation and management of your condition. It's also important to continue managing your anxiety in a healthy way, such as through therapy and other coping mechanisms.

In terms of your diet and lifestyle, it's great that you have made positive changes over the years to improve your overall health. It's important to continue to follow a healthy diet, such as incorporating lean meats and vegetables into your meals and choosing nutritious options like fruit smoothies for breakfast. Limiting your alcohol consumption is also important, as alcohol can exacerbate pancreatitis.

Make sure to take your medications as prescribed and discuss any concerns or questions with your healthcare provider. Keep track of any symptoms you experience and discuss them with your healthcare provider during your follow-up appointments. It's important to stay proactive in managing your health and working with your healthcare team to address any concerns or issues that may arise.
